10' Pole.description: A 10-foot-long wooden pole, useful for prodding suspicious areas, triggering traps from a distance, or bridging small gaps. The pole is about 2 inches in diameter and sturdy enough to support a moderate amount of weight.
10' Pole.name: 10' Pole
10' Pole.unidentifiedDesc: A 10-foot-long wooden pole, useful for prodding suspicious areas, triggering traps from a distance, or bridging small gaps. The pole is about 2 inches in diameter and sturdy enough to support a moderate amount of weight.

Acrobatics.description: The character can perform impressive acrobatic feats, balance on ropes and wires, and so forth. A successful skill roll is required to perform any acrobatic feat; failure may result in the character falling. A successful roll allows the character to reduce the effective height of a fall by 10 feet. This skill also grants a +2 bonus on saves vs. mechanical traps where agility would help, such as tilting floors and pit traps.
Acrobatics.name: Acrobatics

Acting.description: The Acting skill enables a character to convincingly portray different personalities, emotions, or even other characters. It is used to deceive others, blend into a new role, or perform on stage. This skill can be crucial when impersonating someone or maintaining a disguise, and can also help in social situations where creating the right impression is essential.
Acting.name: Acting

Aerial Servant.description:
This spell summons an intelligent elemental being called an Aerial Servant to retrieve a specified item or creature and return it to the caster. The servant appears immediately, and the cleric must describe the target and its location, or the servant will depart.

The aerial servant is ethereal at will, allowing it to bypass most barriers, but it cannot pass through a Protection from Evil effect.

Task and Duration: The servant will attempt to find and bring back the target within the spell's duration (1 day per caster level). If the spell ends before the task is completed—whether the servant is still searching or already returning—it is considered a failure.

Strength and Carrying Capacity: The aerial servant has 18 Strength and can carry up to 500 lbs (5,000 cn).

Failure Consequences: If the aerial servant cannot complete its task within the spell duration, it goes insane and immediately returns to attack the caster.
Aerial Servant.name: Aerial Servant
Aerial Servant.spellEffect: Servant fetches one item or creature

Agate.description: An agate gem is a type of chalcedony known for its distinctive banding patterns and vibrant colors. It often features layers in hues like white, blue, red, or brown, and can have a polished surface with a smooth, glassy appearance. Agates are prized for their unique, natural beauty and are used in jewelry and decorative items.
Agate.name: Agate
Agate.unidentifiedDesc: An agate gem is a type of chalcedony known for its distinctive banding patterns and vibrant colors. It often features layers in hues like white, blue, red, or brown, and can have a polished surface with a smooth, glassy appearance. Agates are prized for their unique, natural beauty and are used in jewelry and decorative items.

Alchemy.description: This skill provides the ability to recognize and identify common alchemical substances, potions, and poisons. Success with this skill will allow a character to create an antidote potion for one specific type of poison—if the DM says that this is possible in his campaign.
Alchemy.name: Alchemy

Alertness.description: This skill allows the character to draw a weapon without losing any time, avoid the effects of surprise, and wake up at the slightest out-of-place noise.
Alertness.name: Alertness

Alternate Magics.description: This skill gives a character basic familiarity with magics that are not related to standard spellcasting. It includes knowing many magical abilities of well-known Prime Plane and extraplanar monsters and of Immortal beings. The DM defines what types of knowledge this skill provides in his or her campaign.
Alternate Magics.name: Alternate Magics

Amber.description: Amber is a gemstone with a warm, golden-orange hue, often containing natural inclusions or bubbles. It has a smooth, polished surface and a unique texture as it is formed from fossilized tree resin. Amber's rich color and transparency make it highly valued for jewelry and decorative items.
Amber.name: Amber
Amber.unidentifiedDesc: Amber is a gemstone with a warm, golden-orange hue, often containing natural inclusions or bubbles. It has a smooth, polished surface and a unique texture as it is formed from fossilized tree resin. Amber's rich color and transparency make it highly valued for jewelry and decorative items.

Amethyst.description: Amethyst is a purple variety of quartz known for its rich color and clarity. It often forms in clusters with pointed crystals and ranges in shade from light lavender to deep violet. Amethyst is popular in jewelry and is believed to have calming and healing properties.
Amethyst.name: Amethyst
Amethyst.unidentifiedDesc: Amethyst is a purple variety of quartz known for its rich color and clarity. It often forms in clusters with pointed crystals and ranges in shade from light lavender to deep violet. Amethyst is popular in jewelry and is believed to have calming and healing properties.

Analyze.description:
This spell allows the caster to handle one item and learn about its enchantment. The caster must use the item correctly: helms must be worn, swords held, bracelets worn on the wrist, etc. Any consequences, such as from cursed or trapped items, will affect the caster as usual, with saving throws if applicable.

The caster has a 15% chance plus 5% per level to determine one magical property, or to confirm that the item is non-magical. The spell provides general information, such as whether a weapon’s bonus is “many” or “few,” and estimates the number of charges within 25% accuracy.
Analyze.name: Analyze

Animal Training (choose type).description: This skill allows the character to raise, train, and care for one specific type of animal. The animal can be taught simple tricks or basic commands. For each additional type of animal the character wishes to train, they must take this skill again. For example, horse training and dog training are separate skills, but a horse trainer can handle any horse or pony, and a dog trainer can train any breed of dog. This skill is commonly found in cultures with a strong bond to a specific animal type.
Animal Training (choose type).name: Animal Training (choose type)

Animate Dead.description:
This spell animates skeletons or zombies from normal skeletons or dead bodies within range. The animated undead creatures will follow the spellcaster's commands until destroyed by a cleric or a *Dispel Magic* spell.

Hit Dice: For each level of the caster, one Hit Die of undead may be animated. Skeletons have the same Hit Dice as the original creature, while zombies gain one extra Hit Die. Humans and demihumans are considered 1 HD creatures for this spell.

Animated undead cannot cast spells but are immune to sleep, charm effects, and poison.
Animate Dead.name: Animate Dead

Animate Dead (C).description:
This spell animates normal skeletons or dead bodies within range, transforming them into enchanted skeletons or zombies. These undead obey the caster until destroyed by a dispel magic spell or another cleric.

Effect: For each experience level, the caster can animate 1 HD of undead. Skeletons retain the HD of the original creature, while zombies have +1 HD.

Humans and demihumans are treated as 1 HD for this spell. A human’s corpse would be animated as a 1 HD skeleton or a 2 HD zombie.

Notes: Animated undead are immune to sleep, charm, and poison effects. Using this spell for good is advised for lawful casters, as animating the dead is often seen as a Chaotic act.
Animate Dead (C).name: Animate Dead (C)

Animate Objects.description:
This spell allows the cleric to animate non-living, non-magical objects, causing them to move and attack. Magical objects are unaffected.

The spell can animate either:

  • One object up to 400 lbs (4,000 cn), roughly the size of two men.
  • Multiple smaller objects, as long as their total weight does not exceed 400 lbs.

Combat Abilities: The DM determines the movement rate, number of attacks, damage, and armor class of animated objects. As a guideline:

  • A man-sized statue might move at 30' per round, attack once per round for [[/r 2d8 #points of damage]] damage, and have AC 1.
  • A chair might move at 180' per round, attack twice per round for [[/r 1d4 #points of damage]] damage per attack, and have AC 6.

All animated objects use the cleric’s chance to hit in combat.
Animate Objects.name: Animate Objects

Anti-Animal Shell.description:
This spell creates an invisible protective barrier surrounding the druid, less than an inch from their body.

Effects:

  • Prevents all physical attacks from normal and giant-sized animals, including insects and other non-fantastic creatures of animal intelligence (0-2).
  • The barrier prevents the druid from physically attacking animals, but they may still use spells against them.
Anti-Animal Shell.name: Anti-Animal Shell

Anti-Magic Shell.description:
This spell creates an invisible magical barrier around the caster, forming a protective shell that completely blocks all magic.

Effects:

  • The barrier surrounds the caster’s body at a distance of less than an inch.
  • It prevents all magic from passing through, including the caster's own spells.
  • The caster may end the effect at will before the duration expires.
  • The barrier lasts for 12 turns unless dismissed.
  • No form of magic (except for a wish) can cancel or dispel the shell—not even dispel magic.
Anti-Magic Shell.name: Anti-Magic Shell

Anti-Plant Shell.description:
This spell creates an invisible barrier around the druid's body (less than an inch away) that blocks all plant attacks and prevents damage from plant-like monsters.

Effect on Movement: While protected, the druid can push through dense growth, creating a path that others may follow. The barrier prevents the druid from physically attacking plants, though spells may still be cast against them.
Anti-Plant Shell.name: Anti-Plant Shell
Anti-Plant Shell.spellDuration: 1 round per level of the druid

Appear*.description:
This spell negates invisibility within a 20' x 20' x 20' area. It affects all invisible creatures and objects inside the area, making them fully visible.

Effect:

  • Affects all forms of invisibility (both magical and natural).
  • Creatures on the Astral and Ethereal planes are not affected.
  • All affected creatures cannot become invisible again for 1 full turn.
Appear*.name: Appear*
Appear*.spellEffect: Reveals all invisible creatures/objects in a 20' cube

Aquamarine.description: Aquamarine is a gemstone with a light blue color and a smooth, polished surface. It has a crystalline appearance that reflects light, showcasing its clarity and delicate hue. Often used in jewelry, aquamarine is valued for its brilliance and tranquil color.
Aquamarine.name: Aquamarine
Aquamarine.unidentifiedDesc: Aquamarine is a gemstone with a light blue color and a smooth, polished surface. It has a crystalline appearance that reflects light, showcasing its clarity and delicate hue. Often used in jewelry, aquamarine is valued for its brilliance and tranquil color.

Arcane Spellcasting (E).description:
Elves harness arcane energy through natural affinity and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Elves must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Elves have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Elves must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire. Unlike Magic-Users, however, Elves also train in combat, allowing them to wield swords and bows while wearing armor without disrupting their spellcasting.
Arcane Spellcasting (E).name: Arcane Spellcasting (E)

Arcane Spellcasting (M).description:
Magic-Users harness arcane energy through intense study and careful memorization of spells recorded in their spellbooks. Unlike Clerics, who receive divine magic, Magic-Users must prepare spells in advance by studying their books each day. Once a spell is cast, it is erased from memory until re-memorized.

Magic-Users have a limited selection of spells they can prepare per day, increasing as they gain levels. Their spells range from minor utilities such as Read Magic to devastating attacks like Fireball and reality-warping incantations at higher levels​.

Because of their reliance on spellbooks, Magic-Users must protect and expand their libraries, seeking out lost tomes, scrolls, and ancient knowledge to improve their magical repertoire.
Arcane Spellcasting (M).name: Arcane Spellcasting (M)

Arrows.description: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.
Arrows.name: Arrows

Arrows (silver).description: An arrow made with a silver tip. This can be used to damage certain types of creatures like lycanthropes.
Arrows (silver).name: Arrows (silver)

Arrows +1.description:
Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Arrows +1.name: Arrows +1
Arrows +1.unidentifiedDesc: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.

Arrows +2.description:
Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Arrows +2.name: Arrows +2
Arrows +2.unidentifiedDesc: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.

Arrows +3.description:
Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Arrows +3.name: Arrows +3
Arrows +3.unidentifiedDesc: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.

Arrows +4.description:
Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Arrows +4.name: Arrows +4
Arrows +4.unidentifiedDesc: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.

Arrows +5.description:
Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Arrows +5.name: Arrows +5
Arrows +5.unidentifiedDesc: Fletched arrows in a quiver. Can be used with a long bow or short bow.

Art (Choose Type).description: This skill covers the creation of art, such as painting, sculpture, woodcarving, or mosaic. The player must specify the type of art the character practices. A successful skill check allows the character to create works that can improve NPC reactions. For example, presenting a well-crafted portrait or sculpture to an NPC may provide a +2 bonus to reaction rolls. If preferred, the player can choose to base this skill on Wisdom instead of Intelligence.
Art (Choose Type).name: Art (Choose Type)

Art (choose type).description: This skill involves creating art, such as painting, sculpture, or woodcarving. The character must choose one form of art they specialize in, and can take this skill multiple times to learn different forms. Successful use of the skill can improve NPC reactions; for instance, presenting a portrait to an NPC can grant a +2 bonus to reaction rolls. The character can choose to base this skill on Wisdom instead of Intelligence.
Art (choose type).name: Art (choose type)

Artillery.description: This skill enables a character to command the crew of a piece of artillery, such as a catapult or trebuchet. While knowledge of the skill suffices for general operation, a skill check is required each time the artillery is aimed at a new target. This skill also allows the character to make precise calculations regarding trajectory, distance, and throw weight. It can be taken multiple times to learn both operation and construction of siege weapons. If an artillery device is improperly operated or built without a character possessing this skill, it is more prone to malfunction or failure.
Artillery.name: Artillery

Asleep.description:
A sleeping character is helpless. If an attacker can come up to a sleeping character without waking that character, he can kill the sleeper with a single blow of any edged weapon, regardless of the victim's hit points.

Attacks on a sleeping character made with other (i.e., blunt) hand-to-hand weapons automatically hit; ranged attacks are made against the victim as if he were AC 9.

Any sleeping creature, including one hit by a sleep spell, can be awakened by force, such as a shake, slap, or kick.

Some types of sleep are so heavy that the character will not awaken when disturbed; they are defined with individual spell or combat-result descriptions and are normally referred to as unconsciousness. A victim of unconsciousness is much like a sleeper but will not awaken and cannot resist when being tied up.
Asleep.name: Asleep

Avenger.description:
A Chaotic traveling fighter can achieve the title of Avenger if they meet specific requirements. Fighters who do not meet these conditions may instead become knights (described separately).

  1. Fealty to a Clerical Order: To become a avenger, the fighter must swear an oath of service to a Chaotic clerical order. Only fighters of Name level or higher are eligible. Once accepted, the avenger is bound to serve the order and may be summoned by its leaders at any time to perform tasks that align with the powers of Evil.

  2. Detect Evil: A avenger can detect evil, as per the cleric spell, once per round by concentrating. This ability has a range of 120 feet but cannot be used in the same round as an attack.

  3. Cleric Spells: A avenger with a Wisdom score of 13 or higher can cast cleric spells as if they were a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 17th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 5th-level cleric.
  4. Fighters with Wisdom scores of 12 or less can still become avengers but cannot cast spells. Avengers are trained in meditation and spellcasting by the clerics of their order, who provide this service without accepting compensation.

  5. Turn Undead: Avengers can turn undead with the same ability as a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the avenger turns undead as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 16th or 17th level, the avenger turns undead as a 5th-level cleric.

  6. Hireling Limit: An avenger is prohibited from having human or demihuman hirelings. However, they are allowed to try and persuade Chaotic monsters to become their hirelings.

    • If a Chaotic creature is not immediately hostile, the avenger can offer food or treasure, signaling friendship through words or gestures.

    • If this approach fails, using threats or engaging in combat and achieving surrender might work similarly.

    • If the creature's Reaction roll results in friendship, it is convinced to follow and obey the avenger. This effect lasts as long as a charm spell cast by a magic-user; once it ends, it cannot be renewed.

    • The avenger can have as many Chaotic monster hirelings as their Charisma score permits; once one is lost, they may attempt to persuade another.

  7. Requesting Sanctuary:

    An avenger may approach any castle, ruin, or dungeon overseen by an intelligent Chaotic creature or individual, and using their alignment language, request Sanctuary (see knight, above). The avenger can also pose as a knight to seek Sanctuary from other rulers. If they successfully fool the ruler (and evade any magic that reveals alignment), the ruler will offer them standard Sanctuary.

Legend:

  • 7, 9, 11: Roll 2d6 and meet or exceed this number to turn undead.
  • T: Automatically turn undead.
  • D: Automatically destroy undead.
  • D+: Automatically destroy [[/r 3d6 #Hit Dice]] Hit Dice of undead.
Avenger.name: Avenger

Awareness.description: The mystic is only surprised on a roll of 1 (on 1d6)
Awareness.name: Awareness

Axe, Battle +1.description: A battle axe is a two-handed axe 2'-4' in length, usually with a double blade or a spike on the reverse of the blade.
Axe, Battle +1.name: Axe, Battle +1
Axe, Battle +1.unidentifiedDesc: A battle axe is a two-handed axe 2'-4' in length, usually with a double blade or a spike on the reverse of the blade.

Axe, Battle@cmPtfMLPOc8Qdt2X.description: A battle axe is a two-handed axe 2'-4' in length, usually with a double blade or a spike on the reverse of the blade.
Axe, Battle@cmPtfMLPOc8Qdt2X.name: Axe, Battle
Axe, Battle@cmPtfMLPOc8Qdt2X.unidentifiedDesc: A battle axe is a two-handed axe 2'-4' in length, usually with a double blade or a spike on the reverse of the blade.

Axe, Hand +1.description: A hand axe is a one handed axe 1’-2’ in length, usually with a single blade. A hand axe is often thrown while its owner rushes towards melee range.
Axe, Hand +1.name: Axe, Hand +1
Axe, Hand +1.unidentifiedDesc: A hand axe is a one handed axe 1’-2’ in length, usually with a single blade. A hand axe is often thrown while its owner rushes towards melee range.

Axe, Hand@KlE02jJDCz0W1OGA.description: A hand axe is a one handed axe 1’-2’ in length, usually with a single blade. A hand axe is often thrown while its owner rushes towards melee range.
Axe, Hand@KlE02jJDCz0W1OGA.name: Axe, Hand
Axe, Hand@KlE02jJDCz0W1OGA.unidentifiedDesc: A hand axe is a one handed axe 1’-2’ in length, usually with a single blade. A hand axe is often thrown while its owner rushes towards melee range.

Babble*.description:
The reverse of *Speak with Monsters*, this spell prevents one creature from communicating in any way.

Effects:

  • The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells, but with a -2 penalty.
  • If the save fails, the victim is unable to communicate for the spell’s duration.
  • This includes all forms of communication: speech, hand gestures, writing, telepathy, etc.
  • The victim can still cast spells but cannot use magic items requiring command words, as the words turn into gibberish.

Duration: 1 turn per level of the caster.
Babble*.name: Babble*
Babble*.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Backpack.description: A sturdy pack used to carry equipment on the character's back. The shoulder straps leave the character's hands free for other actions. It has a capacity of 400 coins.
Backpack.name: Backpack
Backpack.unidentifiedDesc: A sturdy pack used to carry equipment on the character's back. The shoulder straps leave the character's hands free for other actions. It has a capacity of 400 coins.

Backstab.description: When attacking an unaware opponent from behind, the attacker gains a +4 bonus to hit and deals double damage.
Backstab.name: Backstab

Banded Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of chain mail with horizontal metal strips fastened into the mail. Banded mail gives a character an armor class of 4. It doesn’t quite have the protection of plate mail, but is cheaper and lighter.
Banded Mail.name: Banded Mail
Banded Mail.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of chain mail with horizontal metal strips fastened into the mail. Banded mail gives a character an armor class of 4. It doesn’t quite have the protection of plate mail, but is cheaper and lighter.

Banded Mail +1.description:
This is a magic suit of armor primarily composed of chain mail with horizontal metal strips fastened into the mail. Banded mail gives a character an armor class of 4, but this armor provides an additional bonus. It doesn’t quite have the protection of plate mail, but is cheaper and lighter.

Magic armor weighs half that of its nonmagic counterpart.
Banded Mail +1.name: Banded Mail +1
Banded Mail +1.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of chain mail with horizontal metal strips fastened into the mail. Banded mail gives a character an armor class of 4. It doesn’t quite have the protection of plate mail, but is cheaper and lighter.

Bard.description:
The Bard: Keeper of Legends, Master of Song

From the dawn of history, bards have roamed the world as keepers of lore, song, and heroism. They are the wandering minstrels, the poetic warriors, the storytellers whose words shape the deeds of kings and heroes alike. Bards are more than mere entertainers—they are the voice of history, the heart of culture, and, when needed, an inspiration on the battlefield.

Unlike the common thief-turned-minstrel, a true Bard has honed both the martial and mystical aspects of their craft. They wield the power of spell-songs, enchanting allies and bewitching foes with melodies imbued with arcane energy. These spell-songs, much like the incantations of wizards or the prayers of clerics, draw upon an ancient tradition that blends magic with performance. Through song and instrument, they can heal wounds, bolster courage, cloud minds, or even weave illusions so vivid they seem real.

Though bards may fight alongside warriors and thieves, their true strength lies in their ability to influence the world with words, music, and guile. They are welcome in the courts of kings as much as in the taverns of common folk, gathering news, uncovering secrets, and spreading the tales of legends—sometimes their own.

Each bard carries an enchanted instrument, a tool of their trade that is as vital as a wizard’s spellbook. Without it, their magic is silent. Some are gifted such instruments by mentors, while others must quest to find their own. A bard’s skill with an instrument is as much a part of their identity as the songs they know, and a seasoned bard can earn a fortune simply by performing for the right audience.

Whether they choose to settle and establish a great conservatory to pass their wisdom on to students, or continue their travels as a lone wanderer chronicling the stories of the world, all bards share a common purpose: to ensure that no great deed goes unsung, no legend is forgotten, and no soul is left without a melody to guide them.

Adapted from Geoff Gander and Marco Dalmonte’s article at Pandius.

Key Characteristics

Prime Requisite

Dexterity and Charisma. A Bard gains a 5% experience bonus if both Dexterity and Charisma are 13–15, and a 10% bonus if both are 16 or higher.

Combat Skills

  • Bards may use any one-handed melee weapon and all missile weapons.
  • They cannot use two-handed weapons, as these interfere with playing instruments.
  • Bards may wear armor up to chain mail, but heavier armor imposes penalties on their Thief skills.
  • A Bard may wield shields of medium size or smaller, but doing so prevents playing an instrument.

Hit Dice

  • Bards roll 1d6 for hit points per level until 9th level, after which they gain +2 hit points per level. Constitution adjustments no longer apply at this point.

Special Abilities

Bards possess several skills similar to Thieves, along with unique abilities that set them apart.

  • Thief Abilities (affected by armor type):

    Armor TypeHide in ShadowsMove SilentlyHear NoiseClimb Walls
    Leather Armor————
    Scale Mail-5%-15%-5%-15%
    Chain Mail-10%-20%*-10%-20%

    *This penalty may be halved if wearing Elven Chain Mail.

  • Read Languages: At 4th level, a Bard can read non-magical languages with an 80% chance.

  • Use Magic Scrolls: At 10th level, a Bard can attempt to use magic-user scrolls, with a 10% chance of backfire.

  • Bardic Charm: At 3rd level, a Bard gains the ability to charm others through song or poetry (similar to charm person). This improves at higher levels to affect intelligent monsters and, later, even plants.

  • Spell-Songs: Bards can cast spell-songs, a unique form of magic that functions similarly to spells but requires performance and an enchanted instrument.

  • Backstab (Modified):

    • When striking an unaware opponent, a Bard gains +2 to attack rolls and deals 1.5x damage (round down).
    • This allows for precision strikes without the raw lethality of a Thief’s backstab.

Advancement at Name Level (9th Level)

At 9th level, a Bard earns renown and may establish a Conservatory, a place dedicated to training apprentices, preserving history, and refining spell-songs. This Conservatory attracts 1d8 1st-level apprentice Bards, eager to learn from a master of the craft. These apprentices are loyal and dedicated students, though they will not follow the Bard into direct danger.

A Conservatory serves as a center of culture, storytelling, and music, drawing the attention of nobles, scholars, and fellow adventurers. It may take many forms—a grand hall in a city, a secluded retreat in the mountains, or a hidden sanctuary where lost songs and stories are recovered. The Bard may use this stronghold to research new spell-songs, store historical knowledge, and influence the world through their art.

Stronghold Options

Bards who choose to establish a Conservatory are expected to offer shelter and hospitality to traveling Bards who seek knowledge or rest. In exchange, these visitors bring news, songs, and secrets from across the land. The Conservatory may gain influential patrons, such as kings or powerful wizards, who see value in the Bard’s wisdom and the knowledge housed within.

Not all Bards settle in one place. Some prefer to remain travelers, continuing their journey as wandering minstrels, historians, and adventurers. These Traveling Bards have a unique connection to the world’s hidden stories. Once per month, they may learn of an unsung epic, a forgotten tale, or a legendary figure whose story has yet to be told. This knowledge can lead to lost treasures, rare spell-songs, or even legendary quests.

While a Bard may choose the life of a wanderer, they are always welcome at the Conservatories of their peers. These sanctuaries provide a place to rest, study, and exchange knowledge, ensuring that no great deed or legend is forgotten.
Bard.name: Bard

Bardic Charm.description:
A Bard of 3rd level or higher can charm others through song, poetry, or music, similar to the charm person spell. The Bard must perform for three consecutive rounds, after which the target must make a saving throw vs. Spells at +3 or be charmed. The effect lasts until dispelled, the Bard dismisses it, or the Bard harms the target.

At 9th level, this ability improves, allowing the Bard to charm intelligent monsters (as charm monster).

At 15th level, the Bard can charm plants (as charm plant), influencing intelligent vegetation such as treants or magical flora.
Bardic Charm.name: Bardic Charm

Bargaining.description: The Bargaining skill allows a character to negotiate favorable terms in transactions or agreements. It covers haggling over prices, making persuasive arguments in trade deals, and finding compromises that satisfy all parties. A successful Bargaining check can result in better prices, advantageous terms, or profitable contracts.
Bargaining.name: Bargaining

Barrier*.description:
This spell creates a magical barrier up to 30' in diameter and 30' high, consisting of whirling and dancing hammers. The barrier is obviously dangerous to any who pass through it.

Damage: Any creature passing through the barrier takes [[/r 7d10 #points of damage]] (7-70) points of damage. No saving throw is allowed.

This spell is commonly used to block entrances, corridors, or other key passages.
Barrier*.name: Barrier*

Bedroll.description: A heavy wooden blanket with a small pillow.
Bedroll.name: Bedroll
Bedroll.unidentifiedDesc: A heavy wooden blanket with a small pillow.

Blackjack@RksAN1Xa2JeKa7Im.description:
A blackjack, also known as a cosh, is a small leather club usually filled with sand. Blackjacks are too soft to do significant damage, but are very useful for temporarily knocking people unconscious without doing permanent damage.

The weapon has no effect on those wearing metal armor of any sort, or any unarmored monster of AC 0 or less. See rules for other details about this weapon, including the ability to knockout, stun and delay the victim.
Blackjack@RksAN1Xa2JeKa7Im.name: Blackjack
Blackjack@RksAN1Xa2JeKa7Im.unidentifiedDesc:
A blackjack, also known as a cosh, is a small leather club usually filled with sand. Blackjacks are too soft to do significant damage, but are very useful for temporarily knocking people unconscious without doing permanent damage.

The weapon has no effect on those wearing metal armor of any sort, or any unarmored monster of AC 0 or less. See rules for other details about this weapon, including the ability to knockout, stun and delay the victim.

Blankout.description: By concentrating for 1 round, the mystic makes his presence "disappear." No living or undead creature can see him, and there is no saving throw involved. This effect lasts for 1 round for each level of the mystic and is automatically dispelled if he makes an attack. He can use this ability only once per day.
Blankout.name: Blankout

Bless*.description:
This spell enhances the morale of friendly creatures by +1 and grants them a +1 bonus to all attack and damage rolls. It affects only those within a 20' x 20' area and only those who are not yet engaged in melee combat.

The reversed form, blight, imposes a -1 penalty to morale, attack rolls, and damage rolls of enemies. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid these penalties.
Bless*.name: Bless*

Blessed.description: This effect improves the morale of friendly creatures by +1 and gives the recipients a +1 bonus on all attack and damage rolls. It will only affect creatures in a 20' X 20' area, and only those who are not yet in melee.
Blessed.name: Blessed

Blight*.description:
Blight, imposes a -1 penalty to morale, attack rolls, and damage rolls of enemies. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid these penalties.

It affects only those within a 20' x 20' area and only those who are not yet engaged in melee combat.
Blight*.name: Blight*

Blighted.description: Blight, places a -1 penalty on enemies' morale, attack rolls, and damage rolls. Each victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the penalties. It will only affect creatures in a 20' X 20' area.
Blighted.name: Blighted

Blind Shooting.description: This skill allows the character to shoot at a target without seeing it, typically used in darkness or when the target is outside the range of sight or infravision. The character must be able to hear the target to evaluate its position. A successful skill check allows a shot with no penalties due to darkness, though an attack roll is still required to hit the target.
Blind Shooting.name: Blind Shooting

Blinded.description:
Characters can be blinded by a variety of effects. For example, a light or continual light spell may be cast directly on a character's eyes, or a character without infravision may find himself in an area of complete darkness.

A character who is completely blind, for whatever reason, suffers a -4 penalty to all saving throws, a -6 penalty to all attack rolls (he has to guess where his target is by hearing), and a +4 penalty to his armor class for the duration of his blindness.

A character who is forced to travel great distances while blind must move very slowly. If he is to walk slowly enough that he will not fall down steps and walk unknowingly into pits, he must move at one-third his normal speed, and whether he is indoors or outdoors, that speed is measured in feet, not yards.

A blind character who is guided by a sighted character can move safely at two-thirds his normal rate, and his movement is measured in yards when outdoors. A character mounted on a horse suffers no movement penalty if someone else is guiding that horse.
Blinded.name: Blinded

Blissful Slumber.description:
When this song is sung, all within 10' of the bard instantly feel as though they have had a full night's sleep. Fatigue penalties are eliminated, and those affected do not need to rest for the night.

Effects:

  • Instantly removes all fatigue penalties.
  • Replaces the need for a full night's sleep.

Limitations:

  • This spell cannot be used for more than three consecutive days.
  • The bard cannot sing this song more than four times per week.
  • If overused, fatigue penalties apply as normal, as the body cannot go without sleep indefinitely.
Blissful Slumber.name: Blissful Slumber
Blissful Slumber.spellEffect: Removes fatigue and eliminates the need for sleep

Blowgun, Long.description:
This weapon is a tube that measures between 6 inches and 4 feet in length. The user inserts a small dart or thorn into the tube, aims it at a target, and blows air into it, propelling the dart toward the target. The darts themselves do not cause any damage; however, they are typically coated with poison. A blowgun dart only scratches the victim, resulting in minimal penetration and no significant harm. If struck, the victim must make a saving throw against poison or experience its effects. Depending on the victim's size or level of experience, they may receive a bonus to the saving throw (refer to the Weapon Special Effects Table). No undead creatures or any beings immune to poison can be affected by a blowgun.

Using lethal poison as a weapon is considered an immoral act. Due to its risks, local or regional authorities may outlaw poison, and in such cases, Lawful characters generally refrain from using it. The Dungeon Master (DM) may decide to prohibit player characters from utilizing poisons in their campaign. Players should be informed that if they choose to equip their characters with blowguns, they should expect that monsters will also possess them.

Longer blowguns require two hands to wield; therefore, the user cannot use a shield and will always lose individual initiative to characters wielding one-handed weapons. Halflings and small nonhumans, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.
Blowgun, Long.name: Blowgun, Long

Bola@4u775b0uMAQXFZp4.description:
This weapon consists of a cord with weighted balls at the ends, designed to be whirled and thrown at a target. While it deals minimal damage (1d2 points), it has the potential to entangle, slow, or delay the victim.

  • Critical Effect: If the attack roll is a natural 20 (excluding modifiers), the victim must make a saving throw vs. death ray. On a failed save, the victim is immediately paralyzed and will die from strangulation in [[/r 1d6+2#Rounds before dying of strangulation]] (3-8 rounds total) unless rescued. If freed, the victim remains paralyzed for [[/r 2d6#Rounds paralyzed]] (2-12 rounds). Creatures that do not breathe (e.g., constructs) are immune to this effect.

  • Normal Effect: If the attack roll succeeds but is not a natural 20, the victim must still make a saving throw vs. death ray. A successful save negates all effects except for damage. On a failed save, the effect depends on the victim’s size or experience level, as determined by the Weapon Special Effects Table.

  • Escaping the Bola:

    • The victim may attempt a new saving throw during the hand-to-hand combat phase of each round. A successful save means the bola has been removed.
    • If another character helps to remove the bola, the victim rolls their own saving throw vs. death ray with a +2 bonus.
    • The bola can also be destroyed. If the victim has an edged weapon and chooses to destroy it, they may spend 1 round doing so. Otherwise, the bola remains intact, and the victim may choose to drop it or hold onto it.

  • Possible Effects (from the Weapon Special Effects Table):

    • Entangle: The victim cannot attack, move, or cast spells until they successfully make a saving throw.
    • Slow: The victim is slowed, moving and attacking at half their normal rate and unable to cast spells.
    • Delay: The victim automatically loses individual initiative for the next round.

This weapon only affects solid creatures. Creatures such as wraiths, spectres, ethereal beings, or water-based monsters (e.g., water elementals) are immune.

  • Encumbrance: Bolas are cumbersome to carry and can become tangled. For each additional bola carried, the encumbrance triples:

    • 1 bola = 5 cn
    • 2 bolas = 15 cn
    • 3 bolas = 45 cn, and so on.
Bola@4u775b0uMAQXFZp4.name: Bola

Bow, Long +1.description:
This weapon is crafted from a piece of wood bent into a curve, held in shape by a tightly drawn string. It is used to launch arrows.

This bow requires two hands to operate, preventing the wielder from using a shield and always losing individual initiative to those wielding one-handed weapons. It is unsuitable for halflings and other small creatures, such as goblins.
Bow, Long +1.name: Bow, Long +1

This bow requires two hands to operate, preventing the wielder from using a shield and always losing individual initiative to those wielding one-handed weapons. It is unsuitable for halflings and other small creatures, such as goblins.

Bow, Short +1.description: A short bow is a 3’-4’ bow, either made from a single piece of wood or a composite of different woods. A short bow requires both hands to fire. Bows require the use of arrows as ammunition.
Bow, Short +1.name: Bow, Short +1
Bow, Short +1.unidentifiedDesc: A short bow is a 3’-4’ bow, either made from a single piece of wood or a composite of different woods. A short bow requires both hands to fire. Bows require the use of arrows as ammunition.

Bow, Short@CnlBl1rnFo1yEYZE.name: Bow, Short

Bravery.description: This skill allows the character to resist the effects of magical fear, as well as the results of morale checks or skills like Intimidation. NPCs using this skill can ignore fear effects with a successful skill check.
Bravery.name: Bravery

Breath Resistance (H).description:
Upon reaching 2,100,000 XP, a Halfling gains resistance to breath weapons, including dragon breath and other breath-based attacks. They automatically take half damage from such effects, and if a saving throw is allowed, a successful save further reduces the damage to one-quarter.

As with magic resistance, fractions are rounded down, and any final damage of ½ a point or less results in 1 point of damage taken.
Breath Resistance (H).name: Breath Resistance (H)

Breathstealer.description:
When sung, this spell-song begins to rob the air from those within its area of effect, potentially leading to suffocation.

Effects:

  • Affects all creatures within a 30' x 30' x 30' area.
  • Each round, all within the area must make a saving throw vs. Spells at -2 or begin suffocating.
  • On a failed save, the victim loses 3 points of Constitution temporarily.
  • Those who fail a save must also make a Constitution check to move normally.
  • Movement speed is halved while suffocating.
  • Suffocating victims cannot cast spells, speak, or attack.
  • If a creature’s Constitution reaches 0, they die.

Duration:

  • The bard may sing for as many rounds as their Constitution score.
  • If the bard sings until reaching 0 Constitution, they pass out for [[/r 2d6 #Rounds Unconscious]].

Recovery:

  • Lost Constitution points recover at a rate of [[/r 1d3 #Points per full day of rest]].

Special Notes:

  • All creatures in the area—including the bard’s allies—are affected.
  • Creatures who succeed a saving throw take no penalties that round.
Breathstealer.name: Breathstealer
Breathstealer.spellEffect: Causes victims to suffocate, losing Constitution each round

Call Lightning.description:
This spell allows the druid to call lightning bolts from a storm. A storm of any type must be present within 360' of the druid for the spell to work, though the druid need not be within the storm itself.

Effect: The druid may call 1 lightning bolt per turn, striking any target point within 360'. Each bolt affects an area 20' across. Creatures in this area take 8d6 (8-48) electrical damage, though they may make a saving throw vs. spells to take half damage.

The druid can call a bolt each turn as long as the storm or spell duration continues.
Call Lightning.name: Call Lightning
Call Lightning.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster
Call Lightning.spellEffect: Calls lightning bolts from a storm

Caltrops (bag of 20).description:
Small metal spikes sufficient to cover a 5’ square area. Creatures moving through the area have a 2-in-6 chance of treading on a spike. Victims suffer a 50% reduction of movement rate until they are healed.

Three uses max.
Caltrops (bag of 20).name: Caltrops (bag of 20)
Caltrops (bag of 20).unidentifiedDesc:
Small metal spikes sufficient to cover a 5’ square area. Creatures moving through the area have a 2-in-6 chance of treading on a spike. Victims suffer a 50% reduction of movement rate until they are healed.

Three uses max.

Carbuncle.description: A carbuncle is not a specific gemstone but rather a term historically used to refer to any red gemstone, particularly a deep red garnet or ruby. It is characterized by its rich, dark red color and smooth, polished surface. Carbuncles were highly valued in ancient times for their striking appearance and were often set in jewelry and ceremonial objects.
Carbuncle.name: Carbuncle
Carbuncle.unidentifiedDesc: A carbuncle is not a specific gemstone but rather a term historically used to refer to any red gemstone, particularly a deep red garnet or ruby. It is characterized by its rich, dark red color and smooth, polished surface. Carbuncles were highly valued in ancient times for their striking appearance and were often set in jewelry and ceremonial objects.

Cause Critical Wounds*.description: This spell inflicts [[/r 3d6+3 # points of damage]] points of damage on a creature touched by the caster. A successful melee attack roll is required.
Cause Critical Wounds*.name: Cause Critical Wounds*
Cause Critical Wounds*.spellEffect: Inflicts critical damage on one creature

Cause Disease*.description: This spell infects the victim with a hideous wasting disease unless they successfully make a saving throw against spells. A diseased victim suffers a -2 penalty on all attack rolls. Additionally, the victim's wounds cannot be magically cured, and natural healing takes twice as long as usual. The disease is fatal within [[/r 2d12 #Cure Disease duration in days]] days unless removed by a cure disease spell.
Cause Disease*.name: Cause Disease*

Cause Fear*.description: The reversed form of the spell, cause fear, will make any one creature flee for two turns. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect. This reversed spell has a range of 120'.
Cause Fear*.name: Cause Fear*

Cause Light Wounds*.description:
This spell cures one living (not undead or non-living) creature of [[/r 1d6+1 #Cure Light Wounds]] points of damage. The caster can cure themselves with this spell.

Alternately, the spell can be used to cure paralysis (except that caused by a Hold Person or Hold Monster spell), although if it does so then no damage will be cured at the same time.

The spell will not increase the target's maximum hit points.

When reversed, this spell, cause light wounds, causes [[/r 1d6+1 #Cause Light Wounds]] points of damage to the target. No saving throw is allowed, but the caster must make a normal attack roll to inflict this damage.
Cause Light Wounds*.name: Cause Light Wounds*

Cause Serious Wounds*.description: This spell inflicts 2d6 + 2 points of damage on a creature touched by the caster. A successful melee attack roll is required to deliver the spell.
Cause Serious Wounds*.name: Cause Serious Wounds*

Caving.description: The character with this skill always knows their location while exploring underground caves, caverns, and river systems. They automatically recall the route taken as long as they were conscious. This skill is especially useful for dwarves and can also help characters navigate mazes. If disoriented or forced to flee for a long distance, a skill check is required to avoid becoming lost.
Caving.name: Caving

Ceremony (choose specific Immortal).description: The character knows how to honor an Immortal through ritual and ceremony. This skill allows a cleric to perform normal rituals of their order and could permit a character to gain an Immortal's attention through devout prayer, fasting, or sacrifice. This skill includes knowledge of rituals pleasing to the Immortal.
Ceremony (choose specific Immortal).name: Ceremony (choose specific Immortal)

Cestus@zuJutH4zGWRzZltK.description: The cestus (plural: cesti) is a type of glove or hand-wrap with rough, cutting edges on the back, designed to increase the damage of punching attacks. If the campaign includes the optional rules for using two weapons, a character does not incur the -4 penalty when using a cestus on their offhand.
Cestus@zuJutH4zGWRzZltK.name: Cestus
Cestus@zuJutH4zGWRzZltK.unidentifiedDesc: The cestus (plural: cesti) is a type of glove or hand-wrap with rough, cutting edges on the back, designed to increase the damage of punching attacks. If the campaign includes the optional rules for using two weapons, a character does not incur the -4 penalty when using a cestus on their offhand.

Chain Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of small metal rings that are linked together to form a flexible protective material. Chain mail gives a character an armor class of 5.
Chain Mail.name: Chain Mail
Chain Mail.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of small metal rings that are linked together to form a flexible protective material. Chain mail gives a character an armor class of 5.

Chain Mail +1.description:
This is a magic suit of armor primarily composed of small metal rings that are linked together to form a flexible protective material. Chain mail gives a character an armor class of 5, but this armor provides an additional bonus.

Magic armor weighs half that of its nonmagic counterpart.
Chain Mail +1.name: Chain Mail +1
Chain Mail +1.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of small metal rings that are linked together to form a flexible protective material. Chain mail gives a character an armor class of 5.

Charm Monster.description:
This spell is identical in effect to the *Charm Person* spell but can affect any creature except an undead monster.

Multiple Targets: When cast on creatures with 3 Hit Dice or less, it charms 3d6 (3-18) creatures. For creatures with more than 3 Hit Dice, it affects only one target.

Each creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect.
Charm Monster.name: Charm Monster

Charm Person.description:
This spell affects humans, demihumans, and certain other creatures. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells; if failed, the target views the caster as a “best friend” and will defend them against any perceived threat. The spell does not affect animals, magical creatures, undead, or creatures larger than ogres.

The charmed creature obeys friendly commands but resists those that go against its nature or cause self-harm. The duration depends on the target’s Intelligence, allowing periodic saving throws:

  • High Intelligence (13-18): Save every day
  • Average Intelligence (9-12): Save every week
  • Low Intelligence (3-8): Save every month
Charm Person.name: Charm Person

Charm Plant.description:
This spell functions similarly to charm person, but affects plants instead.

The spell charms one of the following:

  • 1 tree
  • 6 medium-sized bushes
  • 12 small shrubs
  • 24 small plants

Charmed plants will understand and obey all commands from the caster, as long as the tasks are within their capabilities. This includes entangling nearby creatures, but does not grant mobility, sensory perception, or intelligence.

Saving Throw: Normal plants receive no saving throw. Plant-like monsters (such as treants or shriekers) may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to resist the effect.

Duration: The effect lasts for 6 months, unless:

  • The spell is dispelled.
  • The affected plants enter winter dormancy.

This spell is highly useful in fortifications, especially when combined with growth of plants and permanence.
Charm Plant.name: Charm Plant
Charm Plant.spellEffect: Charms one tree or multiple smaller plants

Cheating.description: This is the skill of winning at gambling games by cheating, such as dealing cards from the bottom of the deck. A Cheating skill roll is made against each character being cheated. If any of them make a successful check against the cheater's roll, they detect the cheating. This skill is limited to characters of Chaotic alignment.
Cheating.name: Cheating

Chest, Large.description:
Chests are reinforced wooden boxes with lids and sides that are made tight to prevent anything from getting out or into the box. The price is for a box with integrated lock and strong metal reinforcements.

Coin Capacity: 50k

Dimensions: 36" x 18" x 18"

Volume: 11,664 cubic inches

Empty Weight: ~35 lbs (wood and metal reinforcements)
Chest, Large.name: Chest, Large
Chest, Large.unidentifiedDesc:

Coin Capacity: 25k

Dimensions: 24" x 16" x 16"

Volume: 6,144 cubic inches

Empty Weight: ~20 lbs (wood and metal reinforcements)
