Chest, Small.description:
Chests are reinforced wooden boxes with lids and sides that are made tight to prevent anything from getting out or into the box. The price is for a box with integrated lock and strong metal reinforcements.

Coin Capacity: 10k

Dimensions: 18" x 12" x 12"

Volume: 2,592 cubic inches

Empty Weight: ~10 lbs (wood and metal reinforcements)
Chest, Small.name: Chest, Small
Chest, Small.unidentifiedDesc:
Chests are reinforced wooden boxes with lids and sides that are made tight to prevent anything from getting out or into the box. The price is for a box with integrated lock and strong metal reinforcements.

Coin Capacity: 10k

Dimensions: 18" x 12" x 12"

Volume: 2,592 cubic inches

Empty Weight: ~10 lbs (wood and metal reinforcements)

Clairvoyance.description:
This spell allows the caster to see through the eyes of any single creature within 60'. Each turn, the caster can switch to another creature's eyes within range without needing to recast the spell.

Restrictions: The spell's effect is blocked by two feet of rock or a thin coating of lead. No saving throw applies.
Clairvoyance.name: Clairvoyance

Cleric.description:
A cleric is a human character devoted to a significant cause, such as serving an Immortal or embodying the ideals of their alignment. Clerics combine martial prowess with divine magic, using their faith and beliefs to heal, protect, and combat evil. They are restricted to blunt weapons like maces and staves, reflecting their spiritual focus.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Wisdom, granting an experience bonus for scores of 13 or higher.
  • Combat and Armor: Clerics can wear any armor and use shields, but they are limited to non-edged weapons.
  • Special Abilities: Clerics can turn undead, using their divine power to repel or destroy them. They begin casting clerical spells at 2nd level, focusing on healing, protection, and divination.
  • Experience Table: They advance steadily, gaining hit points and new spell slots with each level.

Advancement:

  • At 9th level, a cleric reaches "Name level" and is referred to as a patriarch or matriarch. They have the option to establish a stronghold, which can be a fortress or temple serving their clerical order.
  • Stronghold Details: Building a stronghold requires land, which is usually granted by their clerical hierarchy or local rulers. The cleric's order may subsidize construction costs, often covering up to 50%.
  • A stronghold attracts retainers: 1d6 x 50 loyal troops of the cleric’s alignment and 1d6 low-level clerics to assist with religious duties. These followers do not require pay and have high morale, reflecting their devotion.
  • Alternatively, a cleric may choose to remain a traveling cleric, free from the responsibilities of landownership, focusing on aiding others and spreading their faith through quests and adventures.

Clerics are pivotal in both spiritual and martial roles, capable of influencing the world through faith, leadership, and divine power. Their journey often balances personal growth, the needs of their order, and the demands of their adventuring life.
Cleric.name: Cleric

Climb Sheer Surface.description: The use of this ability allows for climbing steep surfaces, such as walls, cliffs, or even ceilings, with a base chance of success determined by the user's level.
Climb Sheer Surface.name: Climb Sheer Surface

Climb Sheer Surface (B).description:
A Bard can climb walls, cliffs, and other vertical surfaces with the same chance as a Thief of the same level. The Bard must have both hands free and cannot climb while holding a weapon or instrument. Climbing takes one round per 10 feet and failure means slipping at the halfway point, with a chance to catch themselves if the DM allows.

Armor Penalties:

  • Scale Mail: –15%
  • Chain Mail: –20% (–10% if Elven Chain)
  • Shield Worn: Additional –5% (if slung on the back)
Climb Sheer Surface (B).name: Climb Sheer Surface (B)

Cloak, long.description: A long cloak to cover one's shoulders and back. Some have hoods. Prices can vary greatly depending on quality and ornateness.
Cloak, long.name: Cloak, long
Cloak, long.unidentifiedDesc: A long cloak to cover one's shoulders and back. Some have hoods. Prices can vary greatly depending on quality and ornateness.

Cloak, short.description: A short cloak to cover one's shoulders and back for warmth. Some have hoods. Prices can vary greatly depending on quality and ornateness.
Cloak, short.name: Cloak, short
Cloak, short.unidentifiedDesc: A short cloak to cover one's shoulders and back for warmth. Some have hoods. Prices can vary greatly depending on quality and ornateness.

Clone.description:
The Clone spell creates an exact duplicate of a living creature using a piece of its flesh. The clone is grown over time and, when fully formed, is a non-magical, independent entity. However, cloning intelligent creatures carries serious risks.

Cloning Humans & Demihumans:

  • Material Requirements: 1 pound of flesh + materials costing 5,000 gp per Hit Die of the original.
  • Growth Time: 1 week per Hit Die of the original.
  • Awakening: The clone awakens when fully grown and retains all features, statistics, and memories the original had at the time the flesh was taken.
  • Only One Clone Allowed: Attempting to create multiple clones of the same person automatically fails.
  • Undead & Constructs Cannot Be Cloned: Flesh taken before a person became undead may be cloned, but the resulting clone is a separate entity.

Cloning Risks:

  • If the original is alive when the clone awakens: The clone becomes aware of the original's existence, forming a partial mind-link.
  • Damage Transfer: Both individuals share pain—any damage taken by one is also inflicted on the other (saving throw vs. spells for half damage).
  • The clone is obsessed with killing its original and must do so within 1 day per level of the spellcaster. If the clone succeeds, it may continue its life normally.
  • If the clone fails to kill its original, it goes insane. The original loses 1 Intelligence & 1 Wisdom permanently, and has a 5% daily chance to also go insane.
  • If both go insane: They die after one week, and cannot be revived by any means, even Wish.
  • If the clone and original remain on separate planes: No mind-link occurs, and they remain unaware of each other.

Simulacra (Cloning Non-Humans):

  • Material Requirements: 1% of the creature’s flesh + materials costing 500 gp per hit point of the original.
  • Growth Time: 1 week per Hit Die of the original.
  • Mind & Control: The simulacrum understands all languages known by the caster and obeys all commands within 10' per caster level.
  • Magical Nature: A simulacrum can be blocked by Protection from Evil and can be dispelled.
  • Weakened Form: It has 50% of the original’s Hit Dice, hit points, and damage output. Each special ability has a 50% chance of being present, but no spells or spell-like abilities are retained.
  • Growth Over Time: If the original is dead, the simulacrum gradually gains power, increasing its abilities by 5% per week up to 90% of the original.
  • Final Development: Once at 90%, the DM rolls again to determine regained special abilities, including spells.
Clone.name: Clone
Clone.spellEffect: Grows one duplicate creature from a piece of the original

Close Gate*.description:
This spell closes a planar gate. It can be used to:

Effects:

  • Close a gate created by the normal Gate spell.
  • Seal a permanent elemental vortex or wormhole.

Limitations:

  • Cannot force an Immortal or summoned being to leave.
  • Does not undo a Wish that made a gate permanent.
Close Gate*.name: Close Gate*

Clothes, Fine.description: This set of clothing is made from the finest materials and often decorated with embroidery, jewelry, or other adornments. It is suitable for noble gatherings and other high-status occasions.
Clothes, Fine.name: Clothes, Fine
Clothes, Fine.unidentifiedDesc: This set of clothing is made from the finest materials and often decorated with embroidery, jewelry, or other adornments. It is suitable for noble gatherings and other high-status occasions.

Clothes, Good.description: These are high-quality clothes, possibly adorned with minor decorative elements. They are suitable for attending social events and for characters wishing to make a good impression.
Clothes, Good.name: Clothes, Good
Clothes, Good.unidentifiedDesc: These are high-quality clothes, possibly adorned with minor decorative elements. They are suitable for attending social events and for characters wishing to make a good impression.

Clothes, Plain.description: A set of simple clothing such as a tunic and pants, a blouse and skirt, a dress, or a robe. Suitable for most travel and adventuring purposes. No special benefits provided.
Clothes, Plain.name: Clothes, Plain
Clothes, Plain.unidentifiedDesc: A set of simple clothing such as a tunic and pants, a blouse and skirt, a dress, or a robe. Suitable for most travel and adventuring purposes. No special benefits provided.

Clothform.description:
This spell creates up to 30' x 30' of non-magical cloth in a single piece. The cloth is permanent and cannot be dispelled.

Shaping: If the caster has an appropriate Craft skill (or similar character background in campaigns without skills), they can shape the cloth during creation, forming objects like tents, sails, garments, or ropes. Unshaped cloth can be cut and fashioned later.

Properties: The cloth resembles tough, undyed linen. It can be created with an unfinished edge to seamlessly join additional cloth created by another *Clothform* spell, making it ideal for sails or large, rugged fabrics.

The cloth extrudes from the caster's hands along the ground, piling up against obstacles without pushing them. It cannot be created in a space occupied by another object or attached to anything except other *Clothform* cloth.

This spell is commonly used for quick shelters or creating rope in adventuring situations.
Clothform.name: Clothform

Cloudkill.description:
This spell creates a poisonous cloud, 30' wide and 20' tall, that appears next to the caster and moves at a rate of 60' (20' per round) in one direction. The cloud is heavier than air and will sink where possible, but it will dissipate when encountering trees or thick vegetation. In confined spaces, the cloud’s size may be limited.

Effects on Creatures: All living creatures within the cloud take 1 point of damage per round. Creatures with less than 5 Hit Dice must make a saving throw vs. poison or die.
Cloudkill.name: Cloudkill

Club.description: A club is a crude blunt weapon—often little more than a roughly shaped piece of wood—that can be used in one hand.
Club.name: Club
Club.unidentifiedDesc: A club is a crude blunt weapon—often little more than a roughly shaped piece of wood—that can be used in one hand.

Club +1.description: A club is a crude blunt weapon—often little more than a roughly shaped piece of wood—that can be used in one hand.
Club +1.name: Club +1
Club +1.unidentifiedDesc: A club is a crude blunt weapon—often little more than a roughly shaped piece of wood—that can be used in one hand.

Combat Bonuses (H).description:
Halflings gain a +1 bonus to all attack rolls when using missile weapons, a +1 bonus to individual initiative, and a -2 AC bonus when attacked by creatures larger than man-sized.

A creature is considered larger than man-sized if its description includes terms like "giant," "gargantuan," or "enormous." Additionally, real-world creatures that the DM deems larger than a human (such as a horse) also fall into this category. As a general guideline, any non-humanoid creature without a specified size can be assumed to be larger than man-sized if it has 4 or more Hit Dice (HD).
Combat Bonuses (H).name: Combat Bonuses (H)

Commune.description:
This spell allows the cleric to ask three yes-or-no questions of the greater powers (such as forces of nature, greater spirits, or Immortals).

Usage: May only be used once per week. The DM may restrict this to once a month if overused. Once a year, the cleric may ask six questions, usually on a day significant to the powers questioned.
Commune.name: Commune

Confuse Alignment*.description:
Confuse alignment, lasts for one turn per level of the spellcaster and can be cast on a creature by touch. No saving throw is allowed. For the duration of the spell, any attempt to discern the recipient's alignment will yield a false result. This false alignment will remain consistent for all subsequent detection attempts during the spell's duration.

This spell allows the spellcaster to determine the alignment (Lawful, Neutral, or Chaotic) of any one creature within 10'. It can also reveal the alignment of an enchanted item or area, if applicable.
Confuse Alignment*.name: Confuse Alignment*

Confused.description:
Confused creatures act randomly. To determine each creature's action, the DM should roll [[/r 2d6 # Find the result on the confusion results table]] each round, using the following chart:

Confusion Results

2-5: Attack the spellcaster's party

6-8: Do nothing

9-12: Attack the creature's own party
Confused.name: Confused

Confusion.description:
This spell causes confusion among creatures within a 30' radius (60' across). The spell affects 3-18 creatures in the area, with victims under 2 + 1 Hit Dice automatically failing their saves. Creatures with 2 + 1 or more Hit Dice can attempt a saving throw vs. spells each round they remain in the area to avoid confusion.

Effects of Confusion: Each round, the DM rolls [[/r 2d6 #confusion effect]] for each affected creature to determine its action, according to the table below:

Confusion Results

2d6 RollResult
2-5Attack the spellcaster's party
6-8Do nothing
9-12Attack the creature's own party
Confusion.name: Confusion

Conjure Elemental.description:
This spell allows the caster to summon one elemental (AC -2, HD 16, Damage 3d8) within range. The caster may only summon one elemental of each type (earth, air, fire, water) per day.

Control: The elemental will follow the caster's commands as long as concentration is maintained. The caster cannot fight, cast other spells, or move more than half speed while maintaining control. If control is lost, the elemental will attempt to kill the caster, attacking anyone in its path while pursuing.

The caster can dismiss a controlled elemental by concentration, while an uncontrolled elemental can be dismissed by a *Dispel Magic* or *Dispel Evil* spell.
Conjure Elemental.name: Conjure Elemental

Contact Outer Plane.description:
This spell allows the caster to contact an Immortal on an outer plane to seek answers to questions. However, contact with such powerful beings carries the risk of insanity. The caster can ask a number of questions equal to the “distance” to the outer plane.

Plane Distance and Insanity: “Distance” to a plane refers to the number of planes one would need to cross to reach it. The caster may choose the distance, up to the maximum, which affects the number of questions, chance of correct answers, and insanity risk. Higher-level casters (21st and above) reduce the insanity risk by 5% per level beyond 20.

If insanity does occur, the caster requires game-time rest equal to the plane’s number to recover.

Chance of Insanity and Knowledge

Distance & QuestionsChance of InsanityChance of KnowingChance of Lying*
35%25%50%
410%30%45%
515%35%40%
620%40%35%
725%50%30%
830%60%25%
935%70%20%
1040%80%15%
1145%90%10%
1250%95%5%

*The chance of lying also includes cases where the Immortal may not know the answer.

This spell can only be cast once per month.
Contact Outer Plane.name: Contact Outer Plane

Contingency.description:
This spell prepares a secondary spell to be automatically cast when a specified condition is met. The spell stored must be a 4th level or lower magic-user spell that does not cause damage.

Contingency Mechanics:

  • The caster defines a specific situation (the trigger) and the spell that will be cast when the situation occurs.
  • Once the condition is met, the stored spell takes effect immediately as if the caster had just cast it.
  • The contingency applies only to events occurring within 120' of the triggering event.
  • No creature or item may have more than one contingency active at a time.
  • A wish cannot override this restriction.
  • The contingency remains indefinitely until triggered.

Example Contingencies:

  • "If I am struck by a living creature that is not a Lawful or Neutral cleric, except for my allies Charlie McGonigle and Sally Silvernose, then cast Charm Monster on the attacker."
  • "If I fall below 8 HP and am about to take damage, then cast Dimension Door on myself to a location I have seen in the last 12 hours."

Duration:

  • The contingency lasts indefinitely until the event occurs.
  • It may remain dormant for centuries if the situation never arises.
Contingency.name: Contingency

Continual Darkness*.description: Continual darkness, creates a volume of complete darkness in a 30' radius. Torches, lanterns, and even a light spell will not affect it, and infravision cannot penetrate it. If cast on a creature's eyes, the creature must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded until the spell is removed. A continual light spell will cancel its effects.
Continual Darkness*.name: Continual Darkness*

Continual Darkness* (C).description: Continual darkness, creates a similarly-sized area of total darkness, unaffected by normal light sources and infravision. A continual light spell can cancel it. If cast on a creature’s eyes, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded.
Continual Darkness* (C).name: Continual Darkness* (C)

Continual Light*.description:
This spell creates a globe of light 60' across. It is much brighter than a torch but not as bright as full daylight. It will continue to glow forever, or until it is magically removed. It may be cast on an object, just as the first level light spell. If cast at a creature's eyes, the victim must make a saving throw vs. spells. If the saving throw is failed, the victim is blinded permanently, or until the spell is dispelled. If the saving throw is successful, the globe will remain in the place it was cast, and the intended victim will suffer no ill effects.

The reverse of this spell, continual darkness, creates a volume of complete darkness in a 30' radius. Torches, lanterns, and even a light spell will not affect it, and infravision cannot penetrate it. If cast on a creature's eyes, the creature must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded until the spell is removed. A continual light spell will cancel its effects.
Continual Light*.name: Continual Light*

Continual Light* (C).description:
This spell creates light as bright as daylight in a spherical volume with a 30' radius. It lasts until dispelled or countered by a continual darkness spell. Creatures that suffer penalties in bright daylight also suffer them within the area of effect.

If cast on a creature’s eyes, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded until the effect is removed. This spell can be cast in an area, on an object, or directly on a creature's eyes to cause blindness.

The reverse, continual darkness, creates a similarly-sized area of total darkness, unaffected by normal light sources and infravision. A continual light spell can cancel it. If cast on a creature’s eyes, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be blinded.
Continual Light* (C).name: Continual Light* (C)

Control Temperature 10' Radius.description:
This spell allows the druid to alter the temperature within a 10' radius (20' across) by up to 50 degrees Fahrenheit, either warming or cooling the air. The temperature changes instantly and remains as long as the druid maintains concentration and the spell's duration has not expired.

The effect moves with the druid, and the temperature can be adjusted by concentrating for one round. This spell is especially useful for surviving in extreme cold or heat.
Control Temperature 10' Radius.name: Control Temperature 10' Radius
Control Temperature 10' Radius.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Control Winds.description:
This spell allows the druid to control all air within range, causing it to increase to gale force or slow to dead calm as desired. The caster must concentrate for one full turn (without moving or attacking) to achieve a complete change in wind force.

Effect on Air Creatures: If the spell is directed at an air creature (like an air elemental), it may make a saving throw vs. spells. If it fails, the druid may slay or control the creature by manipulating the wind. The creature remains controlled as long as the druid concentrates and the spell remains active; if concentration is broken or the spell ends, the creature will turn hostile and attack the druid.

Countering: A higher-level spellcaster using *Control Winds* can easily counter this spell.
Control Winds.name: Control Winds
Control Winds.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster
Control Winds.spellRange: 10' radius per level of the caster

Coral.description: Coral is a gemstone known for its vibrant red or pink color. It has a smooth, polished surface with subtle natural patterns, reflecting its organic origin from marine life. Coral is often used in jewelry and decorative pieces for its unique texture and bold hue.
Coral.name: Coral
Coral.unidentifiedDesc: Coral is a gemstone known for its vibrant red or pink color. It has a smooth, polished surface with subtle natural patterns, reflecting its organic origin from marine life. Coral is often used in jewelry and decorative pieces for its unique texture and bold hue.

Craft.description: The Craft skill represents proficiency in a particular trade or profession, such as armor-making, bow-making, leatherworking, or weapon-smithing. The player must specify the type of craft the character knows when this skill is chosen. A successful roll allows the character to produce high-quality goods, make expert opinions, and even identify the craftsmanship of other items within the chosen craft. Multiple types of Craft skills can be taken, with each representing a different trade. This skill is essential for characters wishing to create or repair equipment and items within their area of expertise.
Craft.name: Craft

Create Air.description:
This spell provides breathable air in a volume of 8,000 cubic feet (such as a 20' x 20' x 20' room) for 1 hour per caster level.

Stationary Use: Typically cast in enclosed spaces, it remains in one area, providing air for all within.

Mobile Use: The spell can be cast on enclosed vehicles, living creatures, or items to travel with them, including underwater or in airless environments. For example, a pegasus-rider could cast it on themselves and their mount to travel into outer space. Stealthy movement underwater is impossible due to visible air bubbles.

The spell does not protect against poison gases unless the gas is a natural atmospheric component.
Create Air.name: Create Air

Create Any Monster.description:
This spell is the most powerful version of the Create Monsters series, allowing the caster to summon nearly any creature.

Spell Details:

  • Summoned creatures appear out of thin air and obey the caster’s commands.
  • The maximum total Hit Dice of all creatures created is equal to the caster’s level (drop fractions).
  • Creatures disappear when the duration ends, unless a construct is created.

Creature Restrictions:

  • The spell cannot create humans or demihumans.
  • Unlike lesser versions, this spell can summon creatures with any number of special abilities (asterisks).
  • To create a creature with three or more asterisks, the caster must have studied such a creature (alive or dead) for at least one hour.

Construct Creation:

  • The spell can create a permanent construct, provided the necessary materials are used.
  • Only one construct can be created per casting, regardless of the caster’s level.
  • The construct remains permanent but can be destroyed by Dispel Magic (normal chances for success).
  • The cost of materials is 5,000 gp per asterisk, or double for constructs with four or more asterisks (e.g., a drolem).
  • Chapter 16 contains more rules for enchanting nondispellable constructs.

Countermeasures:

  • Summoned creatures cannot penetrate a Protection from Evil or Anti-Magic Shell.
Create Any Monster.name: Create Any Monster

Create Food.description:
This spell creates enough food to feed up to 12 men and their mounts for one day. For every level above 8th, it creates enough for 12 more people and mounts.

Note: Created food spoils after 24 hours and cannot be stored for future use.
Create Food.name: Create Food

Create Magic Items.description:
At higher experience levels, magic-users and clerics can create magical items, with most creators being magic-users. When a cleric attempts to create magical items, their Wisdom is substituted for the magic-user's Intelligence when using the methods outlined in this section.

To create any magical item, the character must be at least 9th level, although some items may require the character to be of a higher level. Several factors need to be considered when making magical items, including spell effects, the specialists or skills needed, spell components, and the chance of success.
Create Magic Items.name: Create Magic Items

Create Magical Monsters.description:
This spell functions like the Create Normal Monsters spell but allows the creation of monsters with up to two asterisks (special abilities). The range and duration are doubled compared to the lesser spell.

Monster Creation

  • The caster chooses the type of monsters created.
  • Creatures appear out of thin air and vanish at the end of the duration.
  • The total number of Hit Dice created equals the level of the caster (fractions are dropped).
  • Undead can be created, but humans and demihumans cannot.
  • Monsters with 1-1 Hit Dice count as 1 HD, while creatures with 1/2 HD or less count as 1/2 HD.

Construct Creation

This spell can also create a construct (see Chapter 14) if the caster provides the necessary materials. Only one construct will appear, but it is permanent and does not vanish when the duration ends.

Construct Rules

  • The construct may have a maximum of two special abilities (two asterisks).
  • The cost of materials is at least 5,000 gold pieces per asterisk, though the DM may require more.
  • The construct can be dispelled under normal rules unless enchanted as a nondispellable construct (see Chapter 16).
Create Magical Monsters.name: Create Magical Monsters
Create Magical Monsters.spellEffect: Creates one or more magical monsters

Create Normal Animals.description:
This spell allows the cleric to create normal animals out of thin air. The animals appear at a chosen point within 30' and will obey the cleric at all times. They can be commanded to fight, carry items, guard areas, or perform other tasks within their natural abilities.

Once created, the animals can be sent up to 240' away but will continue to follow the cleric's commands. However, if instructions are not carefully worded, they may act according to their natural instincts.

Number and Size of Animals: The cleric chooses the number of animals, but not their exact type. The DM determines the specific creatures, which may include:

  • 1 large animal (e.g., elephant, hippopotamus)
  • 3 medium-sized animals (e.g., bear, great cat)
  • 6 small animals (e.g., wolf, rock baboon)

The spell cannot create giant animals. The animals disappear when slain or when the spell duration ends.
Create Normal Animals.name: Create Normal Animals

Create Normal Monsters.description:
This spell causes monsters to appear out of thin air, obeying the caster's commands for the spell duration.

Effects:

  • The caster may summon one or more monsters within 30'.
  • The summoned creatures obey the caster's commands—fighting, carrying objects, fetching items, etc.
  • Each monster appears fully equipped with its normal weapons and armor (if any) but no other possessions.
  • At the end of 1 turn (10 minutes), all summoned monsters vanish, along with any equipment they dropped.

Summoning Rules:

  • The total number of summoned Hit Dice (HD) equals the caster’s level.
  • Only monsters with no special abilities (i.e., no asterisk * next to their Hit Dice in the monster manual) may be summoned.
  • The caster chooses the specific monsters within these limitations.
  • This spell cannot create humans, demihumans, or undead.
  • Monsters of 1-1 HD count as 1 HD each.
  • Monsters of 1/2 HD or less count as 1/2 HD each.

Examples:

A 15th-level caster could summon:

  • 30 giant bats, rats, or kobolds (1/2 HD creatures).
  • 15 goblins, orcs, or hobgoblins (1 HD creatures).
  • 7 rock baboons, gnolls, or lizard men (2 HD creatures).
  • 5 boars, draco lizards, or bugbears (3 HD creatures).
  • 3 black bears, panthers, or giant weasels (5 HD creatures).
Create Normal Monsters.name: Create Normal Monsters
Create Normal Monsters.spellEffect: Summons monsters up to caster's level in total HD

Create Poison*.description:
This spell creates poison in a creature or container upon touch. A creature must succeed on a saving throw vs. poison or die instantly. When cast on a container, the poison affects its contents with no save.

Notes: Poisoning is usually considered a Chaotic act.
Create Poison*.name: Create Poison*
Create Poison*.spellEffect: Creates poison in a creature or container

Create Water.description:
This spell summons an enchanted spring from the ground or a wall, flowing for 6 turns and producing enough water for 12 men and their mounts (about 50 gallons).

Each level above 8th allows the cleric to create water for an additional 12 men and mounts. The caster can control the amount of water produced, up to the spell’s maximum.
Create Water.name: Create Water

Creeping Doom.description:
This spell summons a massive swarm of 1,000 creeping insects that appear anywhere within 120 feet of the druid.

Effects:

  • The swarm initially covers a 20' x 20' area but can be spread to cover up to 60' x 60'.
  • The swarm moves at a rate of 60' per round if the druid remains within 120 feet of any part of it.
  • Any creature caught in the swarm takes 100 points of damage per round (no saving throw).
  • The insects remain for the spell’s duration or until the druid moves more than 120 feet away.

  • Normal attacks only partially damage the swarm:

    • A fireball only destroys 100 insects (reducing the total damage by 10 points).
    • Other attacks can destroy similar small portions of the swarm.
  • The swarm can move over most obstacles at normal speed and ignores protection from evil effects.
  • A dispel magic can destroy the swarm at normal chances of success.
Creeping Doom.name: Creeping Doom

Crossbow, Hvy.description:
This is a ranged weapon consisting of a sturdy bow (like a short bow but smaller and sometimes made of metal) mounted horizontally across a stock with a trigger mechanism. It fires short bolts known as quarrels.

Heavy crossbows are cumbersome, requiring two hands to operate and slow to reload. A character with 18 strength can draw the string back single-handedly, allowing them to fire each round. Characters with less strength must place the crossbow on the ground, brace it with a foot, and use both hands to pull the string back, limiting them to firing every two rounds.

This crossbow requires both hands, so the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to opponents using one-handed weapons. Small creatures, such as halflings and goblins, cannot use this weapon.
Crossbow, Hvy.name: Crossbow, Hvy
Crossbow, Hvy.unidentifiedDesc:
This is a ranged weapon consisting of a sturdy bow (like a short bow but smaller and sometimes made of metal) mounted horizontally across a stock with a trigger mechanism. It fires short bolts known as quarrels.

Heavy crossbows are cumbersome, requiring two hands to operate and slow to reload. A character with 18 strength can draw the string back single-handedly, allowing them to fire each round. Characters with less strength must place the crossbow on the ground, brace it with a foot, and use both hands to pull the string back, limiting them to firing every two rounds.

This crossbow requires both hands, so the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to opponents using one-handed weapons. Small creatures, such as halflings and goblins, cannot use this weapon.

Crossbow, Hvy +1.description:
This is a ranged weapon consisting of a sturdy bow (like a short bow but smaller and sometimes made of metal) mounted horizontally across a stock with a trigger mechanism. It fires short bolts known as quarrels.

Heavy crossbows are cumbersome, requiring two hands to operate and slow to reload. A character with 18 strength can draw the string back single-handedly, allowing them to fire each round. Characters with less strength must place the crossbow on the ground, brace it with a foot, and use both hands to pull the string back, limiting them to firing every two rounds.

This crossbow requires both hands, so the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to opponents using one-handed weapons. Small creatures, such as halflings and goblins, cannot use this weapon.
Crossbow, Hvy +1.name: Crossbow, Hvy +1
Crossbow, Hvy +1.unidentifiedDesc:

Heavy crossbows are cumbersome, requiring two hands to operate and slow to reload. A character with 18 strength can draw the string back single-handedly, allowing them to fire each round. Characters with less strength must place the crossbow on the ground, brace it with a foot, and use both hands to pull the string back, limiting them to firing every two rounds.

This crossbow requires both hands, so the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to opponents using one-handed weapons. Small creatures, such as halflings and goblins, cannot use this weapon.

Crossbow, Lt.description:
This weapon resembles the heavy crossbow but is smaller in size. It requires two hands to load, though only one hand is needed to fire.

This crossbow is a two-handed weapon; the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters using one-handed weapons. Halflings and small races, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.
Crossbow, Lt.name: Crossbow, Lt
Crossbow, Lt.unidentifiedDesc:
This weapon resembles the heavy crossbow but is smaller in size. It requires two hands to load, though only one hand is needed to fire.

This crossbow is a two-handed weapon; the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters using one-handed weapons. Halflings and small races, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.

Crossbow, Lt +1.description:
This weapon resembles the heavy crossbow but is smaller in size. It requires two hands to load, though only one hand is needed to fire.

This crossbow is a two-handed weapon; the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters using one-handed weapons. Halflings and small races, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.
Crossbow, Lt +1.name: Crossbow, Lt +1
Crossbow, Lt +1.unidentifiedDesc:
This weapon resembles the heavy crossbow but is smaller in size. It requires two hands to load, though only one hand is needed to fire.

This crossbow is a two-handed weapon; the wielder cannot use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters using one-handed weapons. Halflings and small races, such as goblins, are unable to use this weapon.

Crystal.description: A crystal gemstone is typically transparent, showcasing a clear and faceted structure that reflects light, creating a sparkling effect. Its clarity and sharp edges make it highly valued for its brilliance and aesthetic appeal, commonly used in jewelry and decorative items.
Crystal.name: Crystal
Crystal.unidentifiedDesc: A crystal gemstone is typically transparent, showcasing a clear and faceted structure that reflects light, creating a sparkling effect. Its clarity and sharp edges make it highly valued for its brilliance and aesthetic appeal, commonly used in jewelry and decorative items.

Cure Blindness.description: This spell cures almost any form of blindness, including those caused by light or darkness spells. It will not affect blindness caused by a curse.
Cure Blindness.name: Cure Blindness

Cure Critical Wounds*.description: This spell heals one living creature of 3d6 + 3 points of damage.
Cure Critical Wounds*.name: Cure Critical Wounds*

Cure Disease*.description:
This spell cures any disease, including those caused by mummies or green slime. At 11th level or higher, it can also cure lycanthropy.

The reverse, cause disease, infects the target with a wasting disease. The target must make a saving throw vs. spells or suffer a -2 penalty on attack rolls and hindered healing. The disease is fatal within [[/r 2d12 #Cure Disease duration in days]] days unless removed by a cure disease spell.
Cure Disease*.name: Cure Disease*

Cure Light Wounds*.description:
This spell cures one living (not undead or non-living) creature of [[/r 1d6+1 #Cure Light Wounds]] points of damage. The caster can cure themselves with this spell.

Alternately, the spell can be used to cure paralysis (except that caused by a Hold Person or Hold Monster spell), although if it does so then no damage will be cured at the same time.

The spell will not increase the target's maximum hit points.

When reversed, this spell, cause light wounds, causes [[/r 1d6+1 #Cause Light Wounds]] points of damage to the target. No saving throw is allowed, but the caster must make a normal attack roll to inflict this damage.
Cure Light Wounds*.name: Cure Light Wounds*

Cure Serious Wounds*.description: This spell heals 2d6 + 2 points of damage on one living creature when touched by the caster.
Cure Serious Wounds*.name: Cure Serious Wounds*

Cureall.description:
This is the most powerful healing spell available. When used to cure wounds, it restores nearly all damage, leaving the recipient with only [[/r 1d6 #damage remains]] points of damage remaining.

Healing Process: Restore the target to full starting hit points, then roll 1d6 and subtract that amount from their total.

Alternative Uses: Instead of healing damage, Cureall may be used to cure one of the following conditions:

  • Remove a curse
  • Neutralize poison
  • Cure paralysis
  • Cure disease
  • Cure blindness
  • Remove a Feeblemind effect

If the recipient is suffering from multiple afflictions (such as wounds and a curse), the cleric must specify which one the spell is curing.

Effect on Recently Raised Creatures: If cast on someone who has just been affected by Raise Dead, Cureall eliminates the need for two weeks of bed rest, allowing the target to function normally immediately. This is the only magical healing that works on a newly raised creature.
Cureall.name: Cureall

Curse*.description:
This spell imposes a misfortune or penalty on the target. Curses are limited only by the caster's imagination but should be balanced to avoid backfiring on the caster at the DM's discretion.

Typical curse effects include a -4 penalty on attack rolls, -2 on saving throws, or a halved prime requisite. The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the curse.
Curse*.name: Curse*
Curse*.spellEffect: Inflicts a curse on one target

Curse* (C).description: Curse imposes a penalty or misfortune on the target, with effects limited only by the caster's imagination. If the curse is too powerful, it may rebound on the caster (DM's discretion). Typical curses include a -4 penalty to attack rolls, a -2 penalty to saving throws, halving of a prime requisite, or a -4 penalty on others' reaction rolls. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the curse.
Curse* (C).name: Curse* (C)

Cursed.description: Curse imposes a penalty or misfortune on the target, with effects limited only by the caster's imagination. Typical curses include a -4 penalty to attack rolls, a -2 penalty to saving throws, halving of a prime requisite, or a -4 penalty on others' reaction rolls.
Cursed.name: Cursed

Dagger +1.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon. This dagger has a damage bonus of [[@mod.dmg]] and a to-hit bonus of [[@mod.toHit]].
Dagger +1.name: Dagger +1
Dagger +1.unidentifiedDesc: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon.

Dagger, Silver.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon. Because it is made of silver, this weapon can be used to damage certain magical creatures, such as Lycanthropes.
Dagger, Silver.name: Dagger, Silver
Dagger, Silver.unidentifiedDesc: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon. Because it is made of silver, this weapon can be used to damage certain magical creatures, such as Lycanthropes.

Dagger, Silver +1.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon. Because it is made of silver, this weapon can be used to damage certain magical creatures, such as Lycanthropes.
Dagger, Silver +1.name: Dagger, Silver +1
Dagger, Silver +1.unidentifiedDesc: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon. Because it is made of silver, this weapon can be used to damage certain magical creatures, such as Lycanthropes.

Dagger@GDdHrRnx7lkkKkmJ.description: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon.
Dagger@GDdHrRnx7lkkKkmJ.name: Dagger
Dagger@GDdHrRnx7lkkKkmJ.unidentifiedDesc: A small blade with a one-handed grip. It can be used in melee or thrown as a ranged weapon.

Dance.description:
This spell forces the touched victim to dance uncontrollably, performing a wild jig or similar movement, preventing them from taking meaningful actions.

Effects:

  • The caster must touch the target (requires a successful melee attack roll).
  • The victim receives no saving throw to resist.

  • While dancing, the victim:

    • Cannot attack, cast spells, or flee.
    • -4 penalty to all saving throws.
    • +4 penalty to Armor Class.

Duration:

The duration of the effect is based on the caster’s level:

  • Levels 18-20: [[/r 3 #Rounds of dancing]]
  • Levels 21-24: [[/r 4 #Rounds of dancing]]
  • Levels 25-28: [[/r 5 #Rounds of dancing]]
  • Levels 29-32: [[/r 6 #Rounds of dancing]]
  • Levels 33-36: [[/r 7 #Rounds of dancing]]
Dance.name: Dance

Danger Sense.description: A successful skill roll allows the character to detect imminent danger. The nature or source of the danger is not revealed, and the DM rolls in secret. The player is only informed if the roll is a success and danger is present.
Danger Sense.name: Danger Sense

Dark Allegiance.description:
An Avenger cannot have human or demihuman hirelings but may attempt to persuade Chaotic monsters to serve them. If a Chaotic creature is not immediately hostile, the Avenger may offer food or treasure, using words or gestures to signal friendship. If this fails, the Avenger may use threats or force, and if the creature surrenders, they may become a follower.

If the creature’s Reaction Roll indicates friendship, they agree to follow and obey the Avenger. This effect lasts as long as a charm person spell, after which the creature is freed from influence and cannot be re-charmed.

An Avenger may control a number of Chaotic monster hirelings equal to their Charisma limit. If one is lost, the Avenger may attempt to recruit another.
Dark Allegiance.name: Dark Allegiance

Darkness*.description: Darkness, creates a 30' diameter circle of darkness that blocks all sight except infravision. Darkness can counter light and vice-versa. If cast at a creature’s eyes, the target must save vs. spells or be blinded until the effect ends.
Darkness*.name: Darkness*

Darkness* (C).description: Darkness, creates a sphere of darkness instead. It will block all sight except infravision. Darkness cancels a light spell if cast upon it, but may itself be canceled by another light spell. If cast at an opponent's eyes, darkness causes blindness for the duration of the spell or until canceled. If the victim makes a successful saving throw vs. spell, the spell has no effect.
Darkness* (C).name: Darkness* (C)

Deafened.description: A character made deaf by magic (a curse or a horn of blasting, for example) is certainly inconvenienced. Since he cannot hear, he will miss many warnings shouted at him by his allies. The deaf character should make a saving throw vs. death ray; if he fails it, he is facing the wrong way when the warning is called. A curse of deafness would be cured by a remove curse spell, while deafness caused by a horn of blasting could be cured by a cureall spell.
Deafened.name: Deafened

Death Ray or Poison.description: The Death Ray or Poison saving throw is a roll made by a character to resist deadly effects like instant death or paralysis from poisons, spells, or traps. The player rolls a d20 and compares it to their class- and level-specific target number on the saving throw table; success means avoiding or mitigating the harm. A failed roll often results in death (for poison) or other severe consequences, though optional rules may instead inflict substantial damage​​​.
Death Ray or Poison.name: Death Ray or Poison

Death Spell.description:
This spell instantly slays 4d8 Hit Dice worth of creatures within a 60' x 60' x 60' area.

Effects:

  • All affected creatures must make a saving throw vs. death ray or die instantly.
  • The spell affects the weakest creatures first, beginning with those of the lowest Hit Dice.
  • Creatures with 8 or more Hit Dice (or experience levels) are immune.
  • Normal plants and insects are automatically slain, but those too small to have hit points (e.g., tiny insects, grass, moss) are ignored.
  • Undead are unaffected by this spell.
Death Spell.name: Death Spell
Death Spell.spellEffect: Slays 4d8 (4-32) Hit Dice of creatures within a 60' x 60' x 60' area

Deception.description: The Deception skill enables a character to lie convincingly, mislead others, and create believable falsehoods. It is used to conceal intentions, bluff, or forge information. This skill can be vital for characters trying to hide the truth or manipulate others' perceptions in various social or investigative situations.
Deception.name: Deception

Delayed Blast Fireball.description:
This spell creates a fireball with a delayed explosion, allowing the caster to set a detonation timer.

Effects:

  • The caster selects a delay between 0 to 60 rounds before detonation.
  • A small rock-like magical "gem" shoots toward the chosen location and remains there until detonation.
  • When the delay ends, the "gem" explodes in a 20' radius sphere, dealing fire damage.
  • The fireball inflicts 1d6 damage per caster level to all creatures in the area.
  • Each victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to take half damage.
  • The "gem" cannot be moved magically (via telekinesis, teleport, etc.), but it can be picked up and carried.
  • Once cast, the explosion cannot be hurried or further delayed, except with a wish.
  • The "gem" is pure magic and can be dispelled before detonation.
Delayed Blast Fireball.name: Delayed Blast Fireball

Despair.description: The afflicted actor is filled with sorrow and sympathy; they will believe all action is hopeless, and cannot perform any action.
Despair.name: Despair

Detect Danger.description:
This spell allows the caster to sense hazards by concentrating on places, objects, or creatures within range. The caster needs a full round of concentration to examine one square foot of area, one creature, or one small object. Larger objects require more time.

After examination, the caster knows if the target is immediately dangerous, potentially dangerous, or benign, from the caster's point of view. The spell can detect poisons, which other spells might not. The duration is one hour in natural outdoor settings on the Prime Plane; elsewhere, it lasts for only three turns.
Detect Danger.name: Detect Danger

Detect Deception.description: The character can recognize deceptive behavior in an NPC. This skill does not reveal the truth of specific statements, motivations, or the exact nature of the deception. It only warns the character to distrust the deceptive NPC. The DM rolls secretly, informing the character only if successful. This skill does not work on player characters.
Detect Deception.name: Detect Deception

Detect Evil.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to see a glow surrounding all evilly enchanted objects within 60'. It will also cause creatures that want to harm the spellcaster to glow when they are within range. However, the spell does not allow the spellcaster to hear the actual thoughts of the creatures.

Remember that Chaotic alignment is not automatically the same as evil, although many Chaotic monsters have evil intentions. Traps and poison are neither good nor evil but are merely dangerous.
Detect Evil.name: Detect Evil

Detect Evil (AV).description: An Avenger can use Detect Evil (as the cleric spell) once per round by concentrating. This ability has a 120' range but cannot be used in the same round as an attack.
Detect Evil (AV).name: Detect Evil (AV)

Detect Evil (C).description: When the spell is cast, the caster will see evilly enchanted objects within 120' glow dark red. It also causes creates that intent to harm the caster to glow when they are within the area of effect. Not all Chaotic alignment creatures will have evil intentions, but many do. Traps and poisons are neither good nor evil, merely dangerous; this spell does not reveal them.
Detect Evil (C).name: Detect Evil (C)

Detect Evil (PA).description: A Paladin can detect evil (as per the cleric spell) once per round by concentrating. This ability has a 120' range but cannot be used in the same round as an attack.
Detect Evil (PA).name: Detect Evil (PA)

Detect Invisible.description: This spell enables the spellcaster to see all invisible creatures and objects within range. The range is 10' for each level of the spellcaster. For example, a 3rd level spellcaster can use this spell to see invisible things within 30'.
Detect Invisible.name: Detect Invisible

Detect Magic.description:
This spell allows the caster to see a glow surrounding all magical objects, creatures, and places within 60'. The caster can see the glow only if the objects are visible; hidden items will not show their glow. No saving throw is allowed.

Example: After casting the spell, a magic-user can see a glowing door (locked by magic) and a glowing potion. A magical wand inside a treasure chest would not be visible as the chest hides its glow.
Detect Magic.name: Detect Magic

Detect Magic (C).description:
This spell allows the caster to see a glow around any magical creature, object and place within range. Magical creatures do not get a saving throw against this effect.

The glow only extends a couple of inches around the magical object, so if it is in a container or behind another object then some or all of the glow may not be visible.
Detect Magic (C).name: Detect Magic (C)

Detect Secret Door.description:
To detect a secret door, a character must specify the exact area being searched. The process typically takes one turn (10 minutes) for each 10-foot section of wall, floor, or ceiling. Elves, due to their keen sight, are given a bonus of 1 to their roll.
Either the Dungeon Master should roll or the roll should be blind, regardless of whether a secret door is present, to maintain player uncertainty. Once found, the location of the secret door can be noted, allowing future discovery without a roll.
Detect Secret Door.name: Detect Secret Door

Detection (D).description: Dwarves can detect traps, sliding walls, sloping corridors, and new construction with a 1 in 2 chance. To search, the dwarf must actively look for these features, and the DM rolls 1d6; a roll of 1 or 2 indicates success.
Detection (D).name: Detection (D)

Diamond.description: A diamond is a gemstone known for its clear and transparent appearance. It has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted design that enhances its brilliance and reflective properties. Diamonds are highly valued for their unmatched sparkle and elegance, making them a popular choice in jewelry.
Diamond.name: Diamond
Diamond.unidentifiedDesc: A diamond is a gemstone known for its clear and transparent appearance. It has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted design that enhances its brilliance and reflective properties. Diamonds are highly valued for their unmatched sparkle and elegance, making them a popular choice in jewelry.

Dimension Door.description:
This spell transports one creature (either the caster or a target within 10') to a location up to 360' away. The caster specifies the destination, either by choosing a known location or by stating the direction and distance (up to a maximum of 360').

Destination: If the specified location is occupied by a solid object, the spell fails with no effect.

Saving Throw: An unwilling target can make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being transported.
Dimension Door.name: Dimension Door

Disarm.description:
This combat option allows a character to attempt to disarm an opponent armed with a weapon. When making the attack, the character applies their usual Strength and magic bonuses to the attack roll. If the attack hits, no damage is dealt. Instead, the opponent rolls 1d20, subtracts their Dexterity bonuses, and adds the character’s Dexterity bonuses. If the final result exceeds the opponent's Dexterity score, they drop their weapon.

For example, a character faces a warrior they wish to capture alive. The warrior has AC 0 and a Dexterity of 13. The character has a Strength of 16 and wields a +2 sword, giving them a +4 to attack rolls. Their Dexterity is 12, with no bonus. The character needs a 7 to hit AC 0. They roll a 6, adding their +4 bonus to make a total of 10, successfully hitting the warrior.

The warrior then rolls 1d20 and gets a 15. Subtracting their Dexterity bonus of +1 (from their Dexterity of 13) results in 14. Since the character has no Dexterity bonus, the final roll remains 14, which is greater than the warrior’s Dexterity score of 13. The disarm attempt succeeds.

Once disarmed, the opponent can either switch weapons, losing initiative for the next round, or attempt to retrieve the dropped weapon. To retrieve it, the opponent must retreat and pick up the weapon.
Disarm.name: Disarm

Diseased (Dying).description: This condition represent a deadly disease that kill in a number of days if not treated.
Diseased (Dying).name: Diseased (Dying)

Diseased (Incapacitated).description: This condition represent a serious disease causes the victim to be sick in bed, unable to adventure.
Diseased (Incapacitated).name: Diseased (Incapacitated)

Diseased (Wasting).description: This condition represents a severe affliction that can be inflicted upon a living creature. When affected, the creature suffers from a hideous wasting disease unless it successfully makes a saving throw against spells. The afflicted individual incurs a -2 penalty on all attack rolls, significantly hindering its combat effectiveness. Additionally, the victim's wounds cannot be magically cured, and natural healing processes take twice as long as usual. If the disease is not removed by a cure disease spell, it is fatal within a duration of 2d12 days (ranging from 2 to 24 days).
Diseased (Wasting).name: Diseased (Wasting)

Disguise.description: The Disguise skill allows a character to alter their appearance convincingly to impersonate someone else. This requires a successful skill roll for each individual or group the character attempts to deceive. Targets of the disguise must make a Wisdom check against the character's Disguise roll to see through the impersonation. This skill is invaluable for covert operations, espionage, and any situation where a character must appear as someone else. A failure may result in the disguise being detected, exposing the character to potential danger or hostility.
Disguise.name: Disguise

Disintegrate.description:
This spell causes a single creature or nonmagical object to crumble into dust, destroying it instantly.

Effects:

  • Affected targets include creatures of any size (such as dragons) and nonmagical objects (such as ships or 10' sections of walls).
  • The victim may attempt a saving throw vs. death ray to avoid the effect.
  • This spell does not affect magical items or ongoing spell effects.
  • Anything disintegrated is completely reduced to fine dust with no remains left intact.
Disintegrate.name: Disintegrate

Dispel Evil.description:
This spell affects all undead and enchanted monsters within 30'. Each affected creature must make a saving throw vs. spells or be destroyed. If cast on a single creature, it takes a -2 penalty to its saving throw.

Effect: Banishes creatures from other planes if they fail their saving throw. Those that save must flee and stay away as long as the caster concentrates, remaining stationary.

The spell can also remove a curse from one item or dispel a magical charm effect on a creature.
Dispel Evil.name: Dispel Evil
Dispel Evil.spellEffect: Affects undead, enchanted creatures, or one curse or charm

Dispel Magic.description:
This spell removes existing spell effects within a 20' x 20' x 20' area. Spell effects cast by a spellcaster of equal or lower level are automatically dispelled.

Higher-Level Casters: Effects created by a higher-level spellcaster may resist dispelling. The chance of failure is 5% per level difference. For example, a 7th-level magic-user dispelling a spell cast by a 9th-level cleric has a 10% chance of failure.

Magical Items: This spell does not affect magical items themselves, but it can disrupt active effects they produce. For instance, dispel magic can free a person from the control of a ring of human control.
Dispel Magic.name: Dispel Magic

Dispel Magic (C).description:
This spell destroys other spell effects within a 20' x 20' x 20' area. It does not affect magical items but can cancel temporary effects they produce.

Effect: Automatically dispels spells from casters of equal or lower level. For higher-level casters, there is a 5% chance of failure per level difference.

Examples: A 7th-level caster trying to dispel a spell from a 9th-level caster has a 10% chance of failure.
Dispel Magic (C).name: Dispel Magic (C)

Dissolve.description:
This spell turns soil or rock (but not constructed materials) within 240' into mud, affecting an area up to 3,000 square feet and up to 10' deep. The caster can determine the shape of the area within these limits (e.g., 20' x 150', 30' x 100').

Movement Effects: Creatures moving through the mud are slowed to 10% of their normal speed and may become stuck. At the DM's discretion, creatures in the area may need to make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being stuck.

Duration: The effect lasts for [[/r 3d6 #days]] 3-18 days.
Dissolve.name: Dissolve

Dissolve*.description:
This spell turns soil or rock (but not constructed materials) within 120' into mud. The affected area may be up to 3,000 square feet in surface area and 10' deep. The caster can shape the area within these limits (e.g., 20' x 150', 30' x 100').

Movement Effects: Creatures moving through the mud are slowed to 10% of their normal speed and may become stuck. A saving throw vs. spells may be required to avoid being stuck, at the DM's discretion.

Duration: The effect lasts for 3-18 days [[/r 3d6 #days]].
Dissolve*.name: Dissolve*

Divine Magic (AV).description:
If an Avenger has a Wisdom score of 13 or higher, they can cast cleric spells as if they were a cleric of one-third their level (rounding down). For example, a 12th–14th level Avenger casts spells as a 4th-level cleric. If the Avenger’s Wisdom is 12 or lower, they cannot cast spells but can still be an Avenger.

To gain this ability, the Avenger must learn meditation and spellcasting from clerics of their order. This training comes at a cost determined by the DM, with a suggested minimum of 10,000 gp per cleric spell level gained.
Divine Magic (AV).name: Divine Magic (AV)

Divine Magic (PA).description:
If a Paladin has a Wisdom score of 13 or higher, they can cast cleric spells as if they were a cleric of one-third their level, rounding down. For example, a 9th-level Paladin casts spells as a 3rd-level cleric, while a 17th-level Paladin casts as a 5th-level cleric.

If the Paladin’s Wisdom is 12 or lower, they cannot cast spells but can still be a Paladin.

The Paladin learns meditation and spellcasting from clerics of their order. The clerics refuse any payment or compensation for this training.
Divine Magic (PA).name: Divine Magic (PA)

Divine Spellcasting.description: Clerics do not cast spells at 1st level but gain access to divine spells at 2nd level, progressing in power as they level up. Clerics do not need spellbooks but must pray for spells each day.
Divine Spellcasting.name: Divine Spellcasting

Dragon Breath.description: The saving throw against Breath Weapons is used to resist or mitigate the effects of a wide range of powerful exhaled attacks, not limited to dragons. This includes attacks like a dragon’s fiery or icy breath, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a chimera's elemental breath. Each creature’s breath weapon has specific effects, such as damage, paralysis, or petrification. A successful saving throw generally halves the damage or avoids the secondary effect (such as paralysis or petrification), while failure applies the full consequences. The target number for the saving throw is determined by the character’s class and level.
Dragon Breath.name: Dragon Breath

Dragon Breath Resistance (E).description: Elves gain resistance to dragon breath weapons upon reaching 1,600,000 XP, aka level 14. At this point, they automatically take only half damage from any breath weapon, including dragon breath and similar attacks. If the breath weapon allows a saving throw, a successful save reduces the damage to one-quarter​.
Dragon Breath Resistance (E).name: Dragon Breath Resistance (E)

Druid.description:
A druid is a Neutral-aligned cleric who dedicates themselves to preserving and balancing nature, transitioning from traditional clerical duties upon reaching 9th level. To become a druid, a cleric must spend 1–4 months meditating in a woodland home under the guidance of a higher-level druid. Druids emphasize harmony with nature and avoid spells or actions tied to Good or Evil.

Druids have several distinct characteristics:

  • Armor and Weapons: They cannot use metal items, relying on leather armor, wooden shields, and non-metal, non-piercing weapons like staves.
  • Living and Philosophy: Druids must live in a natural setting, caring for and protecting a specific woodland area. They view themselves as stewards of nature, punishing deliberate harm while tolerating minor, necessary disruptions.
  • Spells: Druids can cast clerical spells along with a unique set of nature-oriented spells, including abilities to control plants, predict weather, and summon animals.
  • Advancement: Higher-level druids must challenge and defeat others of equal rank to advance, with only one "Great Druid" existing at the 36th level.

Druids blend magical abilities with a deep commitment to the balance and protection of nature.
Druid.name: Druid

Dwarf.description:
A dwarf is a sturdy, short-statured demi-human standing about 4 feet tall and weighing approximately 150 pounds. Known for their resilience and practicality, dwarves are experts in mining, construction, and combat. They often form close-knit clans and value craftsmanship and treasure.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Strength, granting experience bonuses for high scores (5% for a score of 13–15, 10% for 16 or higher). A Constitution score of 9 is required to play a dwarf.
  • Combat Abilities: Dwarves are skilled fighters, able to wield small and medium-sized weapons and use shields. They gain access to Fighter Combat Options, including advanced maneuvers like multiple attacks at higher levels.
  • Armor and Weapons: They can wear any armor but are restricted from using longbows or large melee weapons.

  • Special Abilities:

    • Infravision: Dwarves can see up to 60 feet in the dark.
    • Stonework Detection: Their expertise allows them to detect traps, sliding walls, sloping passages, and new construction with a 1–2 roll on a d6.
    • Magic Resistance: As they gain experience, dwarves take reduced damage from spells and magical effects.
    • Dwarves can speak the languages of Dwarves, Gnomes, Goblins, and Kobolds, in addition to Common and Alignment tongues.

Advancement:

  • Dwarves can progress to a maximum of 12th level.
  • Upon reaching 9th level, a dwarf may establish a stronghold in the wilderness. These are typically underground and located in hills or mountains, reflecting their cultural heritage.
  • The stronghold attracts a community of loyal dwarves (up to 200), including skilled craftsmen, warriors, and other retainers, creating a self-sustaining settlement.

Dwarves are resilient and resourceful adventurers, excelling in combat and defensive roles while contributing practical skills and unparalleled durability to any group.
Dwarf.name: Dwarf

ESP*.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to "hear" thoughts. The caster must concentrate in one direction for six rounds (one minute) to hear the thoughts (if any) of a creature within range. The spell allows the caster to understand the thoughts of any single living creature, regardless of language. It does not allow the caster to hear the thoughts of undead creatures.

If more than one creature is within range and in the direction the caster is concentrating, the spellcaster will "hear" a confused jumble of thoughts. The caster can sort out the jumble only by concentrating for an extra six rounds to find a single creature.

ESP is not hindered by any amount of wood or liquid and will penetrate up to two feet of rock, but a thin coating of lead will block the spell. Targets can make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effects.

The reverse of this spell, mindmask, may be cast by touch on any one creature. The recipient is completely immune to ESP and all other forms of mind-reading for the spell's duration.
ESP*.name: ESP*

Earthquake.description:
This powerful spell causes the ground to shake violently, creating cracks and destruction in an area up to 60' square. The affected area increases by 5' per caster level above 17th.

Area of Effect:

  • 17th level cleric: 60' square
  • 18th level cleric: 65' square
  • 19th level cleric: 70' square
  • +5' to each dimension per additional level

Effects:

  • Small dwellings collapse into rubble.
  • Larger structures suffer severe cracks.
  • Hills, cliffs, and earthen formations trigger rockslides.
  • Cracks may open in the ground, randomly engulfing 1 in 6 creatures.

A creature in danger of falling into a crack may attempt a saving throw vs. death to avoid being crushed.
Earthquake.name: Earthquake

Elf.description:
Elves are slender, graceful demi-humans with delicate features and pointed ears. They typically stand between 5 and 5½ feet tall and weigh around 120 pounds. As a blend of fighters and magic-users, elves are skilled in combat and capable of casting spells, making them versatile and powerful adventurers.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisites: Strength and Intelligence. If both scores are 13 or higher, the elf gains a 5% experience bonus. If Intelligence is 16 or greater, this bonus increases to 10%.
  • Combat and Spellcasting: Elves can use all types of armor and weapons while also casting magic-user spells. They are particularly effective in combat when uninjured and can utilize both fighting and magical strategies.
  • Hit Dice: Elves roll 1d6 per level for hit points, with a maximum level of 10. They gain an additional +2 hit points at 10th level.

  • Special Abilities:

    • Infravision allows them to see up to 60 feet in the dark.
    • A natural immunity to ghoul paralysis.
    • They excel at finding secret doors, succeeding on a 1 or 2 when rolling a d6.
    • Elves gain resistance to dragon breath attacks at higher experience levels, taking half or one-quarter damage depending on their saving throw success.
    • Elves can speak the languages of Elves, Gnolls, Hobgoblins, and Orcs, in addition to Common and their alignment tongue.

Advancement and Strongholds:

Elves reach Name level at 9th level and may establish a stronghold in a natural, beautiful location, such as atop great trees or near waterfalls. These strongholds foster harmony with nearby animals, enabling communication and mutual protection. Elves can only advance to 10th level, but their combination of skills and magical abilities balances this limitation.

Their dual nature as fighters and magic-users makes elves both formidable allies and dangerous foes in any adventure.
Elf.name: Elf

Emerald.description: Emerald is a gemstone known for its rich green color and vibrant hue. It typically has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted appearance, enhancing its brilliance and clarity. Highly valued in jewelry, emeralds are prized for their striking beauty and elegance.
Emerald.name: Emerald
Emerald.unidentifiedDesc: Emerald is a gemstone known for its rich green color and vibrant hue. It typically has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted appearance, enhancing its brilliance and clarity. Highly valued in jewelry, emeralds are prized for their striking beauty and elegance.

Endurance.description: The Endurance skill allows a character to perform strenuous activities over extended periods without succumbing to fatigue or exhaustion. It covers activities such as running, swimming, or marching for long distances, as well as withstanding harsh environmental conditions like extreme heat or cold. A successful Endurance check may be required to avoid penalties from prolonged exertion or to maintain performance in challenging circumstances.
Endurance.name: Endurance

Engineering.description: This skill covers the planning, design, and construction of large-scale projects like buildings, bridges, and dams. A character with this skill can oversee such projects to ensure they are structurally sound and meet the desired specifications. The skill can also be used to assess the stability and integrity of existing structures, determining their age, origin, and current condition. Without proper engineering oversight, large projects may collapse or otherwise fail catastrophically. In certain situations, the skill may also be applied to analyze and solve complex mechanical problems or to disable traps and devices constructed with advanced engineering.
Engineering.name: Engineering

Entangle.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to use any rope-like object of living or once-living material (roots, vines, leather ropes, plant-fiber ropes, etc.) to behave as they order. About 50' of normal 1/2" diameter vine plus 5' per level of the caster can be affected.

The commands which can be given during an entangle spell include: coil (form a neat stack), coil and knot, loop, loop and knot, tie and knot, and the reverses of all the above. The vine or rope must be within 1' of any object it is to coil around or tie up, so it often must be thrown at the target. This spell is very useful in climbing situations; a spellcaster can toss a rope up the side of a wall or cliff and command it to loop and knot itself around a projection at the height of the throw. Coil and knot effectively ties up a victim.

A person or monster attacked by any use of the spell may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effects of the entangle.
Entangle.name: Entangle

Entranced.description: The afflicted actor is completely entranced and cannot perform any action.
Entranced.name: Entranced

Escape.description: The Escape skill allows a character to slip free from bonds, such as ropes or manacles, and to break out of physical restraints or confined spaces. Success may depend on the quality of the bindings and the character’s current condition. This skill is also used to evade grapples and similar situations in combat.
Escape.name: Escape

Establish Stronghold (C).description:
A cleric who chooses to establish a stronghold with the approval of his clerical order is known as a "land-owning cleric." This term is convenient, as a land-owning cleric can still adventure with friends and is not bound to his land.

Advantages: The cleric can advance within his order, receive financial support for building the stronghold, and potentially expand his lands, leading to significant wealth.

Disadvantages: The cleric becomes the primary authority for his order in the area, bearing responsibilities to the local populace that may hinder his ability to travel with old adventuring companions or present him with challenging issues.

When a 9th-level cleric decides to build a stronghold, he must seek permission from a superior, either an official of his order or a local ruler. The ruler should grant the land unless there are past issues; in such cases, the ruler may require a service, like a quest, before approval. The DM will determine if the cleric's order has the authority to grant land based on the campaign's setting.

If the cleric has a clean record, his order may assist with construction costs, typically covering up to 50% of the expenses. The player can design the stronghold, and the DM will assess the costs, deciding what portion the order will fund. Regardless of the financial support, the stronghold remains the cleric's property, and he cannot deny access to order members, nor can he be reassigned against his will.

Once the stronghold is built, a number of lower-level clerics (typically 1d6) will arrive to assist with its clerical functions. These clerics are there to help operate the stronghold, not to join the cleric on adventures. The DM should create each assistant cleric with their own name, personality, background, goals, and abilities.

If the cleric manages his land and serves his order well, he is likely to gain power within the clerical hierarchy, receive additional land, and see an increase in tax income from the growing settlements around his stronghold.
Establish Stronghold (C).name: Establish Stronghold (C)

Establish Stronghold (D).description:
Upon reaching Name Level (9th level, 660,000 XP), a Dwarf is recognized as a Dwarf Lord (or Dwarf Lady for female characters) and may establish a stronghold. This stronghold is typically an underground cavern complex built in mountainous or hilly terrain, in keeping with dwarven tradition.

If the Dwarf has forsaken their Clan and lives among humans, they may construct a sturdy stone fortress in human style. However, even in such cases, the Dwarf will still prefer to have an underground complex connected to their dwelling.

Stronghold Forces & Defenses

  • The Dwarf may hire only dwarven mercenaries for their military forces.
  • Specialists and hirelings of other races may still be employed, such as human engineers, elven scouts, or halfling messengers.
  • The stronghold is expected to be heavily fortified, often featuring stone walls, hidden tunnels, reinforced gates, and mechanical traps to repel invaders.

This stronghold serves as the Dwarf’s seat of power, a center of trade, craftsmanship, and military strength, often attracting fellow dwarves seeking refuge or work within its halls.
Establish Stronghold (D).name: Establish Stronghold (D)

Establish Stronghold (E).description:
At Name Level (9th level), an Elf may construct a stronghold deep in the wilderness. Unlike the castles of human lords, an Elven stronghold is designed to blend harmoniously with its natural surroundings. Common locations include the tops of massive trees, the edges of secluded valleys, or behind waterfalls. The effort required to beautify the structure makes its cost equivalent to a human-built stone castle​.

Clan Support and Settlers

When an Elf builds a stronghold, their Clan will assist in finding a suitable location. If the Elf does not have enough gold, the Clan will provide an interest-free loan of up to 50% of the cost. Additionally, if the Clan's existing stronghold is smaller, they may relocate entirely to the new site. Otherwise, they will still offer resources and settlers, with up to 40% of the Clan moving to support the new domain​.

If the stronghold is threatened by enemies, the entire Clan may rally in its defense. In extreme cases, multiple allied Clans may join forces to protect the settlement. Many monsters hesitate to engage in direct warfare against an organized Elven Clan stronghold due to their magical and martial prowess​.

Friendship with the Forest

Once the stronghold is completed, the Elf develops a mystical bond with the local wildlife. All normal animals within five miles of the stronghold become friendly toward the Elf and their kin. These animals can:

  • Warn of approaching strangers
  • Carry news of events
  • Deliver short messages

In return, the animals expect protection and aid from the Elves, fostering a symbiotic relationship between the stronghold and the surrounding wilderness​.
Establish Stronghold (E).name: Establish Stronghold (E)

Establish Stronghold (F).description: At 9th level (Lord/Lady), a Fighter can build a castle and attract a small army of loyal followers to defend their domain.
Establish Stronghold (F).name: Establish Stronghold (F)

Establish Tower (M).description:
Upon reaching 9th level, a Magic-User may choose to build a tower, establishing themselves as a land-owning wizard. Unlike Fighters or Clerics, a Magic-User does not need permission from the local ruler to construct a stronghold, as rulers generally avoid antagonizing powerful wizards​.

Attracting Apprentices

Once a tower is built, the Magic-User will attract 1d6 apprentices, all Magic-Users of levels 1–3. These apprentices seek training, and while they are loyal, they will not sacrifice themselves for their master. The DM determines their names, backgrounds, and personalities​.

Stronghold and Dungeon Construction

A wizard's tower may include a dungeon beneath or near it. Some wizards construct dungeons as secure laboratories, while others leave an opening, attracting wandering monsters that take up residence. Some wizards encourage this, using monsters for research, spell experimentation, or personal defense​. However, monster-infested dungeons often cause conflict with local communities and attract adventurers seeking treasure.

Alternative to a Tower: Becoming a Magist

Instead of building a tower, a Name-level Magic-User may seek employment as a Magist in an existing stronghold. A Magist serves a ruler as an advisor on magical matters, handles magical needs, and is well-compensated—typically at least 3,000 gp per month. However, this requires the Magic-User to swear an oath of fealty to the ruler​.

Would you like additional details, such as construction costs or typical tower layouts?
Establish Tower (M).name: Establish Tower (M)

Ethereal.description: When a monster or character is in ethereal form, they become nonmaterial and unable to be damaged at all from the Prime Plane.
Ethereal.name: Ethereal

Ethereal Form.description: The ability to become nonmaterial and unable to be damaged at all from the Prime Plane.
