Ethereal Form.name: Ethereal Form

Explosive Cloud.description:
This spell creates a 30' diameter, 20' tall cloud of greenish gas filled with sparkling explosions, appearing next to the caster. It visually resembles the Cloudkill spell but has different effects.

Effects:

  • The cloud moves away from the caster at a speed of 20' per round in a direction chosen by the caster.
  • Poisonous Gas: Each creature in the cloud must make a saving throw vs. spells or be **paralyzed** for 1 round. They may attempt a new saving throw each round.
  • Explosions: The cloud is filled with **tiny detonations**, dealing damage each round to all creatures inside.

Damage:

Each creature inside the cloud takes 1 point of damage per 2 caster levels (rounded down). This damage ignores resistances (affecting creatures immune to fire, gas, electricity, etc.).

  • Levels 18-19: [[/r 9 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 20-21: [[/r 10 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 22-23: [[/r 11 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 24-25: [[/r 12 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 26-27: [[/r 13 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 28-29: [[/r 14 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 30-31: [[/r 15 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 32-33: [[/r 16 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Levels 34-35: [[/r 17 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]
  • Level 36: [[/r 18 #Explosive Cloud Damage]]

Duration:

The cloud persists for 6 turns (60 rounds).
Explosive Cloud.name: Explosive Cloud

Fading.description:
A character under the effect of this condition gradually becomes translucent over the course of 24 hours, eventually resembling a spectral hound in appearance. Their equipment remains unaffected. Once fully faded, the character is unable to hold normal items or communicate with unfaded characters through hearing or speech.

From the faded character's perspective, normal objects appear translucent, while faded entities, including other affected characters and spectral hounds, seem solid and normal.

The condition can be reversed at any time by a dimension door spell, allowing the affected character(s) to step through and return to the normal world.
Fading.name: Fading

Faerie Fire.description:
This spell outlines one or more creatures or objects with a pale, flickering, greenish fire, which does not cause damage. The outlined creatures or objects become more visible, granting a +2 bonus to attack rolls against them. The druid can outline one man-sized creature for each 5 levels of experience, up to a maximum of 48 feet of fire at 20th level.

The objects or creatures need only be detected in some way (such as by sight, or a detect invisible spell) to be the object of this spell.
Faerie Fire.name: Faerie Fire

Faerie Lights.description:
This enchanting song conjures shimmering, flickering lights that dance around a chosen target, illuminating a 30' radius as brightly as a conventional light spell. The lights appear to move with a life of their own, weaving and shifting unpredictably.

Effects:

  • Illuminates a 30' radius with bright, magical light.
  • Creatures with animal intelligence (2 or less) must save vs. paralysis or be stunned for [[/r 1d6]] rounds.
  • The lights have no physical form and cannot be extinguished by wind, water, or other natural forces.
  • The lights do not follow a moving target but remain fixed at the chosen location.
Faerie Lights.name: Faerie Lights
Faerie Lights.spellEffect: Creates dancing lights that illuminate a 30' radius

Fear@QMnq62lBb1rxYaMF.description: The target(s) of this ability must make a saving throw against spells or flee in fear. Some variants of the ability may automatically affect creatures of a certain hit dice or lower (no saving throw), causing them to refuse to return to the area where the ability was used until the situation changes.
Fear@QMnq62lBb1rxYaMF.name: Fear

Feeblemind.description:
This spell affects only magic-users, elves, or other creatures capable of casting magical spells (excluding cleric and druid casters). The target's Intelligence is reduced to 2, rendering them helpless and unable to cast spells or think clearly.

Saving Throw: The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells, with a -4 penalty, to resist the effect. The feeblemind effect lasts until removed by a *Dispel Magic* or *Cureall* spell.
Feeblemind.name: Feeblemind

Fighter.description:
A fighter is a human whose primary focus is martial combat. Renowned for their strength and endurance, fighters excel in melee and ranged combat, often taking the lead in battle to protect their allies. They have the highest hit points among classes, enabling them to withstand significant damage.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Strength, granting experience bonuses for high scores (5% for 13–15, 10% for 16–18).
  • Combat Prowess: Fighters can use any weapon and wear any type of armor, including shields. They are also adept in specialized maneuvers like Lance Attack and Set Spear vs. Charge.
  • Hit Dice: Fighters roll a d8 for hit points at each level up to the 9th. Beyond that, they gain a fixed 2 hit points per level.
  • Maximum Level: 36th.

Advancement:

At 9th level, fighters achieve Name level and may choose one of two paths:

  • Land-Owning Fighter: Fighters can petition a ruler for land, often gaining the title of Baron (or equivalent). With their stronghold established, they attract up to 50 loyal fighters (levels 1–3) as retainers. In times of war, they may offer military aid to their ruler and receive assistance if their lands are threatened.
  • Traveling Fighter: These fighters eschew land ownership for a life of adventure. Depending on their alignment, they may adopt roles such as knights or paladins, gaining unique abilities like turning undead or detecting evil.

Stronghold Details:

Fighters who build a stronghold must secure land either by petitioning a ruler, claiming wilderness territory, or purchasing land. As rulers, they manage their dominion, attract settlers, and lead their men-at-arms in defense or expansion of their holdings. Titles can grow with their dominion's success, from Baron to Duke and beyond.

Fighters are essential to any adventuring party for their durability and combat capabilities, serving as the backbone of both offense and defense. They excel in both leadership roles and frontline combat, making them versatile and resilient characters.
Fighter.name: Fighter

Find Trap.description: To search for traps, the player must specify the exact area they are examining, such as a 20-foot square room or a 20-foot corridor. Searching takes one turn (10 minutes) per area, and the Dungeon Master rolls to determine success. Thieves have a percentage-based chance to detect traps, determined by their level, while dwarves have a superior chance to locate large mechanical traps, such as pit traps, due to their natural affinity with stonework. The DM may modify the difficulty for especially hidden traps. Non-thief characters generally cannot detect traps unless their presence is obvious​​.
Find Trap.name: Find Trap

Find Traps (B).description:
A Bard can detect hidden or magical traps with the same chance as a Thief of the same level. This requires careful inspection and takes one round per 10-foot area. Unlike a Thief, a Bard cannot Remove Traps but can warn others of their presence.

Armor Penalties:

  • Scale Mail: –5%
  • Chain Mail: –10% (–5% if Elven Chain)
Find Traps (B).name: Find Traps (B)

Find Traps@8S7I45ND2XGwlJ45.description: The user of this ability can detect traps on walls, floors, and ceilings, with a base chance of success determined by their level.
Find Traps@8S7I45ND2XGwlJ45.name: Find Traps

Find Traps@ruJLZD4L4Qkzg8RU.description: This spell causes all mechanical and magical traps within 30' of the spellcaster to emit a faint blue glow. While it reveals the presence of traps, it does not provide information on their type or how to disarm them. Ambushes or natural hazards like quicksand are not considered traps and will not be revealed by this spell.
Find Traps@ruJLZD4L4Qkzg8RU.name: Find Traps

Find the Path.description:
By casting this spell, the cleric gains the ability to navigate toward a specific place, even if they have never been there before. For the duration of the spell, the cleric instinctively knows the direction to their destination.

Special Knowledge: In addition to knowing the correct path, the cleric gains magical awareness of any special knowledge needed to reach the location. This may include:

  • The location of secret doors
  • Hidden or obscured passages
  • Passwords required to gain entry

Duration Effects: When the spell ends, the cleric retains only a general sense of the direction to the destination; all other special knowledge is forgotten.

Restriction: If the cleric attempts to record or disclose the special knowledge to others in any way, the spell is instantly negated.

This spell is often used to find fast escape routes or to navigate unknown terrain.
Find the Path.name: Find the Path
Find the Path.spellDuration: 6 turns + 1 turn per level of the caster
Find the Path.spellEffect: Shows the path to an area

Finger of Death*.description:
The reversed form of *Raise Dead*, this spell creates a death ray that kills a single living creature within 60' unless the target succeeds on a saving throw vs. death ray.

Undead Effect: If cast on an undead creature with 10 or more Hit Dice (such as a phantom, haunt, spirit, nightshade, or special), it restores 3d10 hit points instead of dealing damage.

A Lawful cleric will typically only use *Finger of Death* in life-or-death situations.
Finger of Death*.name: Finger of Death*
Finger of Death*.spellEffect: Kills one living creature or heals high-HD undead

Fire Resistant.description: Those with this condition are immune to damage from normal fire and heat. They also receive a +2 bonus to all saving throws against magical fire (such as dragon breath or fireball). Additionally, any damage taken from such magical fire is reduced by 1 point per die of damage, with each die dealing at least 1 point of damage. For red dragon breath, the damage is reduced by 1 point per Hit Die of the dragon, but never below 1 point per Hit Die.
Fire Resistant.name: Fire Resistant

Fire-Building.description: This skill allows a character to start a fire without using a tinderbox. A character with a tinderbox and this skill can automatically start fires under ordinary conditions. Without a tinderbox, the character must make a skill check each round, igniting the fire on a 1 or 2 on a 1d6 roll. Adverse conditions, such as high winds or wet wood, require a skill check with penalties as determined by the DM.
Fire-Building.name: Fire-Building

Fireball.description:
This spell creates a missile of fire that explodes into a 40' diameter (20' radius) fireball where it strikes. It deals 1d6 fire damage per caster level to every creature in the area.

Saving Throw: Each creature can make a saving throw vs. spells for half damage.

For example, a fireball cast by a 6th-level caster deals 6d6 (6-36) points of damage. On a successful saving throw, the damage is halved.
Fireball.name: Fireball

Flesh to Stone*.description:
The reverse of Stone to Flesh, this spell turns a living creature to stone, including all equipment carried.

The victim may make a saving throw vs. turn to stone to avoid the effect. If the saving throw fails, the transformation is permanent unless dispelled or reversed.
Flesh to Stone*.name: Flesh to Stone*

Flight.description: The Flight ability allows a character or creature to move through the air, either through magical means or natural capabilities, such as having wings. This ability enables the user to ascend, descend, and navigate in three-dimensional space, often at a specified speed. Flight may come with limitations, such as a maximum altitude, duration, or specific conditions for its use.
Flight.name: Flight

Flight Be True.description:
This spell-song allows the bard to temporarily enchant one missile attack per round while singing and playing an instrument. The bard must succeed in all required checks to maintain the song.

Effects:

  • One arrow, quarrel, or sling stone per round is enchanted.
  • The enchanted missile gains +4 to hit.
  • The missile can damage creatures normally immune to non-silvered or non-magical weapons.

Duration:

  • The bard may continue this song for a maximum number of rounds equal to their Constitution score.
  • After reaching this limit, the bard passes out for [[/r 1d4 #Hours Unconscious]] hours.
  • If the bard stops singing before reaching their limit, there are no negative effects.
Flight Be True.name: Flight Be True
Flight Be True.spellEffect: Enhances one missile attack per round

Floating Disc.description: This spell creates an invisible, horizontal disc capable of carrying up to 5000 cn (500 lbs). The disc remains at the caster's waist height and follows them, staying within 6' at all times. It cannot be used as a weapon or pass through obstacles. When the spell ends, the disc disappears, dropping anything it carried.
Floating Disc.name: Floating Disc

Fly.description:
This spell grants the target (including the caster, if desired) the ability to fly at will for a duration of 1d6 turns plus an additional turn per caster level.

The target can move at speeds up to 360' (120') by concentrating and can hover without concentration. Flight can be in any direction.
Fly.name: Fly

Flying.description:
The target (including the caster, if desired) has the ability to fly at will.

The target can move at speeds up to 360' (120') by concentrating and can hover without concentration. Flight can be in any direction.
Flying.name: Flying

Food Tasting.description: The Food Tasting skill provides a character with the ability to detect subtle flavors and potential poisons in food and drink. It can be used to identify the quality and freshness of ingredients or to recognize dangerous substances that might otherwise go unnoticed. A successful check may reveal whether a dish has been tampered with or if it contains any harmful elements. This skill is particularly useful for adventurers wary of sabotage or treachery.
Food Tasting.name: Food Tasting

Force Field.description:
This spell creates an invisible, immovable barrier or object of pure magical force. The field is impervious to all attacks and spells, except for disintegrate or a wish. A dispel magic spell cannot remove it.

Shape & Size:

  • Can be a sphere (up to **20' radius**), hemisphere, flat surface, cylinder, or a box (up to 5,000 square feet in total area).
  • Must have smooth, regular surfaces.
  • The edges are blunt and cause no damage.
  • Cannot form inside a creature or solid object; instead, gaps will appear.

Barrier Properties:

  • The force field cannot be moved, except by a wish.
  • Nothing can pass through—spells, attacks, and breath weapons all bounce off.
  • Bypassing Methods: Teleport, dimension door, or planar travel (such as gate) can bypass the barrier.
  • A sealed force field prevents starvation and suffocation. It magically preserves enclosed creatures from natural death.

Uses:

  • Can be used as an impassable wall, prison, floor, stairway, or object.
  • Can be made permanent with permanence, but remains dispellable.
  • A permanent force field vanishes if destroyed by disintegrate or wished away.

Duration:

The force field lasts for 6 turns (60 rounds).
Force Field.name: Force Field

Free Monster*.description: This spell removes the paralysis effect from up to four creatures affected by *Hold Person* or *Hold Monster*. It has no other effects.
Free Monster*.name: Free Monster*

Free Person*.description: The reverse of *Hold Person*, this spell releases the paralysis of up to four victims of *Hold Person* (including *Hold Person* cast by a cleric). It has no effect on paralysis caused by other sources, such as a ghoul's paralyzing touch.
Free Person*.name: Free Person*
Free Person*.spellEffect: Removes paralysis from up to 4 creatures

Free Person* (C).description:
Free person, lifts the paralysis from up to four victims affected by the normal form of the spell (including *hold person* cast by a magic-user or an elf). It has no effect on other forms of paralysis, such as that caused by a ghoul.

This spell paralyzes up to four creatures, affecting any human, demihuman, or human-like beings such as bugbears, dryads, gnolls, hobgoblins, kobolds, lizard men, ogres, orcs, nixies, pixies, or sprites. It does not affect undead or creatures larger than ogres. Each target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be paralyzed for nine turns. If the spell is cast at a single target, that creature receives a -2 penalty to their saving throw. If cast at a group, up to four creatures of the spellcaster's choice can be affected, but without any penalty to their saving throws. The paralysis can only be removed by the reversed form of this spell or a dispel magic spell.
Free Person* (C).name: Free Person* (C)

Gambling.description: This skill is the ability to win money in games of skill (competitive card games, for example) and betting. It covers honest games only. A successful check increases the character's chances of winning money at these games.
Gambling.name: Gambling

Garlic.description: This aromatic herb is known to repel vampires and some other undead creatures. It is often used by adventurers as a protective measure when facing such enemies.
Garlic.name: Garlic
Garlic.unidentifiedDesc: This aromatic herb is known to repel vampires and some other undead creatures. It is often used by adventurers as a protective measure when facing such enemies.

Garnet.description: Garnet is a gemstone known for its deep red color and glassy appearance. It has a smooth, polished surface that reflects light, showcasing its rich hue and clarity. Garnet is often used in jewelry for its brilliance and vibrant color.
Garnet.name: Garnet
Garnet.unidentifiedDesc: Garnet is a gemstone known for its deep red color and glassy appearance. It has a smooth, polished surface that reflects light, showcasing its rich hue and clarity. Garnet is often used in jewelry for its brilliance and vibrant color.

Gate*.description:
This spell opens a portal between the Prime Material Plane and another plane of existence. The caster must name the target plane and a specific resident of that plane (typically an Immortal or ruler of the plane).

Planar Destinations:

  • Outer Plane: Gate remains open for 1 turn.
  • Other Planes (Ethereal, Astral, Elemental): Gate remains open for [[/r 1d10*10 #Duration in turns]] turns.
  • Elemental Planes: Creates a vortex and wormhole, which can be made permanent with a Wish.

Outer Plane Risks:

  • The caster must speak the name of an Immortal or planar ruler.
  • The entity has a 95% chance to arrive in [[/r 1d6 #Rounds until arrival]].
  • There is a 5% chance that a different being arrives instead.
  • If the caster lacks an excellent reason for opening the gate, the entity may destroy them.
  • Even with a good reason, the being may leave immediately.
  • Only if the request is of supreme importance will the entity consider assisting.

Unintended Visitors:

  • For gates to the Ethereal, Astral, or Elemental Planes, there is a 10% chance per turn that an other-planar creature wanders through.
Gate*.name: Gate*
Gate*.spellEffect: Opens a portal to another plane

Geas*.description:
This spell compels a creature to perform or avoid a stated action, remaining in effect until the task is completed or the geas is removed.

Effects:

  • The geas must be possible to complete and not directly fatal. If impossible or fatal, the spell reflects onto the caster instead.
  • Affected creatures may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect.

  • If the victim ignores the geas, severe penalties (determined by the DM) take effect, such as:

    • Combat penalties (attack roll or AC penalties).
    • Lowered ability scores.
    • Loss of spellcasting abilities.
    • Pain, weakness, or other afflictions.
    • Death if the geas remains ignored for too long.
  • Dispel magic and remove curse cannot break a geas.
  • The spell does not alter the victim's thoughts; once the task is complete, the victim may seek revenge.
Geas*.name: Geas*

Gentle Touch.description:
Once per day, the mystic can use the Gentle Touch on any one living creature (a normal roll to hit is required; if he misses, he can attempt the Gentle Touch again). The mystic must declare his intention to use the Gentle Touch before rolling to hit and must specify which result (explained below) he is aiming for. The victim does not receive a saving throw, but a creature with more Hit Dice than the mystic's experience level is not affected.

The Touch will produce one of the following results (the mystic decides and announces which one before rolling to hit): charm, cureall, death, quest, or paralysis. These effects replicate the same outcomes as the following spells in all respects except for duration: charm person, cureall, death spell, quest, and hold person. The effect lasts for 24 hours, except for death and cureall, which is have permanent effects.
Gentle Touch.name: Gentle Touch

Ghoul Paralysis Immunity (E).description: Elves are immune to the paralyzing attacks of ghouls. They are, however, still affected by other forms of paralysis.
Ghoul Paralysis Immunity (E).name: Ghoul Paralysis Immunity (E)

Glide.description: The Glide ability allows a character or creature to move smoothly through the air, typically descending gently from a height without falling rapidly. This ability enables controlled movement over distances, often allowing for safe landings and navigation in the air.
Glide.name: Glide

Grappling Hook.description: A large 3- or 4-pronged hook made of specially hardened iron, used to anchor a rope. It can be thrown to hook onto surfaces, allowing the user to climb otherwise inaccessible areas. A successful attack roll is needed to secure it properly.
Grappling Hook.name: Grappling Hook
Grappling Hook.unidentifiedDesc: A large 3- or 4-pronged hook made of specially hardened iron, used to anchor a rope. It can be thrown to hook onto surfaces, allowing the user to climb otherwise inaccessible areas. A successful attack roll is needed to secure it properly.

Growth of Animal.description: This spell doubles the size of one normal or giant animal, increasing its strength, damage, and carrying capacity accordingly. The animal’s behavior, armor class, and hit points remain unchanged, and the spell has no effect on intelligent or fantastic creatures.
Growth of Animal.name: Growth of Animal
Growth of Animal.spellEffect: Doubles the size of one animal

Growth of Plants*.description:
This spell causes normal brush or woods to grow densely with vines, creepers, thorns, or similar plant life appropriate to the area. The spell affects up to 3,000 square feet, with dimensions chosen by the caster, and all plants must be entirely within 120' of the caster.

Effect: The overgrown area becomes impassable to creatures except for those of giant size. The effect remains until removed by the reverse of the spell or by a *Dispel Magic* spell.

Reverse Spell - Shrink Plants: The reversed form, *Shrink Plants*, reduces all normal plants within the affected area to a passable state, negating the effect of *Growth of Plants*. It does not affect plant-like monsters, such as treants.
Growth of Plants*.name: Growth of Plants*

Guardian Angels.description:
Once sung, this spell-song grants the bard and all recipients within range a protective blessing for its duration.

Effects:

  • All affected creatures gain a -2 bonus to AC, applied against all attacks.
  • Recipients become immune to all effects from other bardic spell-songs while this effect lasts.

Area of Effect:

  • Affects the bard and all allies within 15' + 5' per bard level.
Guardian Angels.name: Guardian Angels
Guardian Angels.spellEffect: Provides AC bonus and bardic spell-song immunity

Halberd +1.description:
A halberd is a large pole-arm 6’ to 8’ in length, the head of which has a long spike with an axe blade on one side and a hook on the reverse side.
Because of a polearm's length, a character with a polearm may attack a foe even when there is another friend or foe between them. Often, polearm wielders stand in the second rank of the combat, striking over the heads of their front-line comrades to hit front-line fighters of the enemy force. See rules for other special details.
Halberd +1.name: Halberd +1
Halberd +1.unidentifiedDesc:
A halberd is a large pole-arm 6’ to 8’ in length, the head of which has a long spike with an axe blade on one side and a hook on the reverse side.
Because of a polearm's length, a character with a polearm may attack a foe even when there is another friend or foe between them. Often, polearm wielders stand in the second rank of the combat, striking over the heads of their front-line comrades to hit front-line fighters of the enemy force. See rules for other special details.

Halberd@2UWnXlZ2iehdlsuM.description:
A halberd is a large pole-arm 6’ to 8’ in length, the head of which has a long spike with an axe blade on one side and a hook on the reverse side.
Because of a polearm's length, a character with a polearm may attack a foe even when there is another friend or foe between them. Often, polearm wielders stand in the second rank of the combat, striking over the heads of their front-line comrades to hit front-line fighters of the enemy force. See rules for other special details.
Halberd@2UWnXlZ2iehdlsuM.name: Halberd
Halberd@2UWnXlZ2iehdlsuM.unidentifiedDesc:
A halberd is a large pole-arm 6’ to 8’ in length, the head of which has a long spike with an axe blade on one side and a hook on the reverse side.
Because of a polearm's length, a character with a polearm may attack a foe even when there is another friend or foe between them. Often, polearm wielders stand in the second rank of the combat, striking over the heads of their front-line comrades to hit front-line fighters of the enemy force. See rules for other special details.

Halfling.description:
A halfling is a small, childlike demi-human standing about 3 feet tall and weighing around 60 pounds. Known for their love of comfort and community, halflings are woodland folk who excel in outdoor abilities and camaraderie with elves and dwarves. Despite their size, they are resourceful and capable combatants.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisites: Strength and Dexterity, granting an experience bonus (5% for either score of 13 or higher, 10% for both).

  • Abilities:

    • Halflings receive a +2 bonus to AC against larger creatures, a +1 bonus to attack rolls with missile weapons, and a +1 bonus to individual initiative.
    • They have a 90% chance to hide in woodlands and a 33% chance to hide in shadows within buildings or dungeons, provided they remain motionless.
  • Weapons and Armor: Halflings may use any small-sized weapons (e.g., short swords, daggers) and wear any armor specifically tailored to their size. Shields are allowed.
  • Combat Skills: They gain access to fighter combat options, including multiple attacks at higher levels.

Advancement:

  • Halflings can advance to a maximum of 8th level, gaining the title "Sheriff" upon reaching this level.
  • As they progress, halflings develop enhanced resistances, such as taking half damage from spells and breath weapons at high experience thresholds.

Strongholds:

  • Halflings can construct strongholds at any level if they have the resources. A stronghold often attracts a community of other halflings, creating a new settlement or shire.
  • These strongholds are typically located in tranquil, scenic areas like rolling hills or near streams, reflecting their preference for a peaceful lifestyle.

Halflings balance their physical limitations with their keen abilities and resilience, making them adaptable and valuable members of any adventuring party.
Halfling.name: Halfling

Hallucinatory Terrain.description:
This spell creates an illusion of a terrain feature, either indoors or outdoors, to hide or mimic terrain. The caster could create an illusory terrain over pits or quicksand, or a forest around a camp.

Area: The spell affects up to a 240' radius, and the caster may choose a smaller area, such as a room or a specific feature. For larger areas (such as hills), the entire terrain feature must be within 240' of the caster. Features over 480' in diameter cannot be affected.

Duration: The illusion lasts until an intelligent creature touches it or until dispelled.
Hallucinatory Terrain.name: Hallucinatory Terrain
Hallucinatory Terrain.spellEffect: Changes or hides terrain in 240' radius (or less)

Hammer, Small.description: Used to drive iron spikes into hard surfaces such as stone or wood. It can also be wielded as a weapon, dealing 1d3 points of damage. This item is necessary for setting up certain equipment like ropes or tents.
Hammer, Small.name: Hammer, Small
Hammer, Small.unidentifiedDesc: Used to drive iron spikes into hard surfaces such as stone or wood. It can also be wielded as a weapon, dealing 1d3 points of damage. This item is necessary for setting up certain equipment like ropes or tents.

Hammer, Throwing +1.description: A throwing hammer is a one-handed hammer with a short haft, and is weighted for throwing. Despite the name, it can also be used in melee.
Hammer, Throwing +1.name: Hammer, Throwing +1
Hammer, Throwing +1.unidentifiedDesc: A throwing hammer is a one-handed hammer with a short haft, and is weighted for throwing. Despite the name, it can also be used in melee.

Hammer, Throwing@HkT7WoeYJNCRi5JJ.description: A throwing hammer is a one-handed hammer with a short haft, and is weighted for throwing. Despite the name, it can also be used in melee.
Hammer, Throwing@HkT7WoeYJNCRi5JJ.name: Hammer, Throwing
Hammer, Throwing@HkT7WoeYJNCRi5JJ.unidentifiedDesc: A throwing hammer is a one-handed hammer with a short haft, and is weighted for throwing. Despite the name, it can also be used in melee.

Hammer, War +1.description: A war hammer is a large one-handed hammer, usually 2' to 3' in length. The head of a war hammer is often symmetrical to aid in balance.
Hammer, War +1.name: Hammer, War +1
Hammer, War +1.unidentifiedDesc: A war hammer is a large one-handed hammer, usually 2' to 3' in length. The head of a war hammer is often symmetrical to aid in balance.

Hammer, War@JbGxnUvAzBMKZuBX.description: A war hammer is a large one-handed hammer, usually 2' to 3' in length. The head of a war hammer is often symmetrical to aid in balance.
Hammer, War@JbGxnUvAzBMKZuBX.name: Hammer, War
Hammer, War@JbGxnUvAzBMKZuBX.unidentifiedDesc: A war hammer is a large one-handed hammer, usually 2' to 3' in length. The head of a war hammer is often symmetrical to aid in balance.

Hand Drum.description: A frame drum that was used in various forms of music. Although it can be played with the hand, it is often accompanied by a stick or beater.
Hand Drum.name: Hand Drum

Harden*.description:
This spell turns an area of mud into solid rock, permanently. The affected area can be up to 3,000 square feet in surface area and 10' deep. The caster may shape the area within these limits (e.g., 20' x 150', 30' x 100').

Creatures caught within the area must make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being trapped in the hardened mud.
Harden*.name: Harden*

Harp.description: A stringed instrument played by plucking the strings, often associated with both folk and court music.
Harp.name: Harp

Haste*.description:
This spell increases the movement and attack speed of up to 24 creatures within a 60' diameter area, allowing them to act at double speed for 3 turns.

Effects: Hasted creatures move at twice normal speed and make double the normal number of attacks in melee or with missile weapons. However, magic use is unaffected, so spellcasters can still only cast one spell per round, and magical devices are unaffected.

Reverse Spell: The reverse, *Slow*, either cancels *Haste* or reduces the target’s movement and attack speed by half. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid *Slow*.
Haste*.name: Haste*
Haste*.spellEffect: Up to 24 creatures move double speed

Hasted.description: A hasted creature moves at twice its normal speed and makes double the normal number of attacks in melee or with missile weapons, while magic use remains unaffected, meaning spellcasters can still only cast one spell per round and magical devices are not impacted.
Hasted.name: Hasted

Heal.description:
This powerful spell instantly cures nearly all ailments and injuries of a single creature the caster touches. This spell's effect is identical to that of the 6th level cleric spell cureall.

Effects:

  • Restores nearly all hit points: The target regains full hit points, minus [[/r 1d6 #Remaining damage]] hit points.

  • Removes afflictions: The caster may choose to cure one of the following conditions instead of healing damage:

    • Curses (as Remove Curse).
    • Poison (as Neutralize Poison).
    • Blindness (as Cure Blindness).
    • Disease (as Cure Disease).
    • Feeblemind (restores Intelligence).

Limitations:

  • The spell affects only one chosen condition per casting.
  • It does not restore missing limbs or life to the dead.
Heal.name: Heal
Heal.spellEffect: Cures nearly all wounds or removes one major affliction

Heal Self.description:
Once daily, the mystic can heal himself of [@actor.system.details.level] points of damage. That is 1 point of damage per experience level he possesses by focusing his concentration for a single round.

For instance, a mystic at 10th level can spend one round concentrating and restore 10 hit points of damage he has sustained.
Heal Self.name: Heal Self

Healer's Kit.description:
A sturdy pack with bandages, splints, needles, threads, herbs and other components used for healing. Comes with enough supplies for 15 uses.

Requires successful roll of Healer skill to heal [[/r 1d3 #hp healed]] damage.

Resupply may be purchased separately (10 gp), but this item must be purchased first.
Healer's Kit.name: Healer's Kit
Healer's Kit.unidentifiedDesc:
A sturdy pack with bandages, splints, needles, threads, herbs and other components used for healing. Comes with enough supplies for 15 uses.

Requires successful roll of Healer skill to heal [[/r 1d3 #hp healed]] damage.

Resupply may be purchased separately (10 gp), but this item must be purchased first.

Healer's Kit Supplies.description: Supplies used for a healer's kit. Requires the Healer's Kit item and the Healing skill to be used.
Healer's Kit Supplies.name: Healer's Kit Supplies

Healing.description: Healing allows the treatment of wounds and diagnosis of illnesses among humans and demihumans. A successful skill roll can restore 1d3 hit points to a wounded character. This skill can only be used once per set of wounds, defined as all hit points lost in a single combat. A natural roll of 20 accidentally inflicts [[/r 1d3 #Healing hit points restored]] damage, and the healer may not attempt to treat those wounds again. Success with a roll of 5 or more indicates the healer can determine if an illness is natural or magically induced.
Healing.name: Healing

Healing Herbs.description: This potion restores 1-4 hit points [[/r 1d4 # Healing herbs hit points restored.]] or cures paralysis for a single creature. Its effects take place immediately upon consumption.
Healing Herbs.name: Healing Herbs
Healing Herbs.unidentifiedDesc: This potion restores 1-4 hit points [[/r 1d4 # Healing herbs hit points restored.]] or cures paralysis for a single creature. Its effects take place immediately upon consumption.

Healing Staff (C).description:
This staff, designed exclusively for clerics, has a sturdy, polished appearance, made from a rich, dark wood. The top is adorned with a beautifully carved symbol of healing, surrounded by intricate designs that evoke a sense of divine power.

This staff can heal [[/r 1d6+1 # hit point healed]] hit points per charge expended, as the spell cure light wounds. Alternately, with an expenditure of two charges, the staff can cast cure disease.
Healing Staff (C).name: Healing Staff (C)
Healing Staff (C).unidentifiedDesc: This staff has a sturdy, polished appearance, made from a rich, dark wood. The top is adorned with a beautifully carved symbol of healing, surrounded by intricate designs that evoke a sense of divine power.

Hear Noise.description: Those with this ability possess a heightened sense of hearing, enabling them to detect faint noises such as footsteps, whispers, and the movements of hidden creatures.
Hear Noise.name: Hear Noise

Hear Noise (B).description:
A Bard can detect faint sounds such as footsteps, whispers, or shifting mechanisms with the same chance as a Thief of the same level. The Bard must remain still and concentrate for one round to use this ability. Background noise, such as wind or battle, may impose penalties at the DM’s discretion.

Armor Penalties:

  • Scale Mail: –5%
  • Chain Mail: –10% (–5% if Elven Chain)
Hear Noise (B).name: Hear Noise (B)

Heat Metal.description:
This spell causes one metal object to slowly heat and then cool. It can affect one metal item weighing up to one-half pound (5 cn) per level of the caster. For example, a 12th level caster can heat up to 6 pounds (60 cn), such as a normal sword, while a 20th level caster can heat up to 10 pounds (100 cn), enough to heat a two-handed sword.

The heat does not damage magical items but may severely damage normal weapons or items, especially if they contain both wood and metal. If held, the object causes increasing damage each round: 1 point in the first round, 2 in the second, 4 in the third, and 8 in the fourth. The damage then decreases at the same rate over the remaining rounds. In the fourth round, leather, wood, and other flammable materials in contact with the metal catch fire. Total damage over seven rounds is 22 points.

The holder gets no saving throw, but fire resistance negates all damage. The holder can drop the item at any time, and creatures of low intelligence are 80% likely to do so each round. The spell disrupts concentration, preventing spellcasting for the duration of damage.

Once cast, the spell does not require concentration. Only a dispel magic spell can stop it; normal means, like immersion in water, do not affect it. If cast on an object embedded in a creature (like an arrow or dagger), removing it causes the loss of initiative for that round and inflicts damage for that round as well.
Heat Metal.name: Heat Metal

Hide in Shadows.description: The ability allows one to blend into shadows and become nearly invisible, moving silently as long as they remain still or move cautiously.
Hide in Shadows.name: Hide in Shadows

Hide in Shadows (B).description:
A Bard can remain unseen by blending into shadows, dimly lit areas, or natural cover, using the same chance as a Thief of the same level. This ability requires the Bard to be motionless and cannot be used while being directly observed. Moving while hidden requires a successful Move Silently check.

Armor Penalties:

  • Scale Mail: –5%
  • Chain Mail: –10% (–5% if Elven Chain)
Hide in Shadows (B).name: Hide in Shadows (B)

Hide, Indoors (H).description:
Indoors or in dungeons, a Halfling can attempt to hide in deep shadows or cover, but with less success than in natural environments. If sufficient shadows or concealment exist, they have a 33% chance to remain unseen (rolled secretly by the DM). If there is no available cover, the Halfling cannot hide at all.

A bright light, such as a magical light source that eliminates shadows, prevents hiding. A Halfling cannot use this ability while carrying a light source themselves.
Hide, Indoors (H).name: Hide, Indoors (H)

Hide, Natural (H).description: When outdoors, a Halfling can blend into woods, underbrush, or similar natural terrain, making them extremely difficult to spot. If they remain motionless in such cover, they have a 90% chance to remain unseen (rolled secretly by the DM). This ability functions only in natural environments and does not require shadows. If the Halfling moves, they immediately lose the effect and become visible.
Hide, Natural (H).name: Hide, Natural (H)

Hold Animal.description:
This spell paralyzes normal or giant-sized animals within a range of 180'. The spell does not affect creatures with greater than animal intelligence (2) or fantastic creatures.

Effect: Each animal makes a saving throw vs. spells to resist paralysis for the spell’s duration. The druid can affect 1 Hit Die of animals per caster level, ignoring any “pluses” to Hit Dice. For example, a 20th-level druid could hold 10 giant toads (2 + 2 HD each).

This spell can also affect summoned, conjured, or controlled animals.
Hold Animal.name: Hold Animal
Hold Animal.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Hold Monster*.description:
This spell paralyzes [[/r 1d4 #living creatures]] 1-4 living creatures, with effects similar to a *Hold Person* spell, but able to target any living creature (not undead).

Saving Throw: Each creature must make a saving throw vs. spells to resist. If cast on a single target, the creature suffers a -2 penalty to the saving throw. If cast on a group, it affects 1d4 creatures (chosen by the caster and within range) with no saving throw penalty.

Reverse Spell - Free Monster: The reverse of this spell, *Free Monster*, removes the paralysis from up to four creatures affected by *Hold Person* or *Hold Monster*. It has no other effects.
Hold Monster*.name: Hold Monster*
Hold Monster*.spellDuration: 6 turns + 1 turn per level of the caster

Hold Person*.description:
This spell can paralyze any human, demihuman, or human-like creature (e.g., bugbear, dryad, gnoll, hobgoblin, kobold, lizard man, ogre, orc, nixie, pixie, or sprite). It has no effect on undead or creatures larger than ogres.

Single Target: If cast at a single creature, that creature makes a saving throw vs. spells with a -2 penalty.

Group Target: If cast at a group, it can affect up to four chosen creatures, but without a penalty to their saving throws.

Duration: Creatures failing their saving throw are paralyzed for 1 turn per caster level. The paralysis can only be removed by the reverse of this spell, *Free Person*, or by *Dispel Magic*.
Hold Person*.name: Hold Person*

Hold Person* (C).description:
This spell paralyzes up to four creatures, affecting any human, demihuman, or human-like beings such as bugbears, dryads, gnolls, hobgoblins, kobolds, lizard men, ogres, orcs, nixies, pixies, or sprites. It does not affect undead or creatures larger than ogres. Each target must make a saving throw vs. spells or be paralyzed for nine turns. If the spell is cast at a single target, that creature receives a -2 penalty to their saving throw. If cast at a group, up to four creatures of the spellcaster's choice can be affected, but without any penalty to their saving throws. The paralysis can only be removed by the reversed form of this spell or a dispel magic spell.

The reversed spell, free person, lifts the paralysis from up to four victims affected by the normal form of the spell (including *hold person* cast by a magic-user or an elf). It has no effect on other forms of paralysis, such as that caused by a ghoul.
Hold Person* (C).name: Hold Person* (C)

Hold Portal.description:
This spell magically holds a door, gate, or similar portal shut for [[/r 2d6 #Hold Portal turns]] turns. A knock spell can open it, or a creature with three or more Hit Dice (or levels) above the caster can break it in one round. If the portal closes within the spell’s duration, it will relock.

Example: A 5th level character can break through a hold portal spell cast by a 2nd level spellcaster.
Hold Portal.name: Hold Portal
Hold Portal.spellEffect: One door, gate, or similar portal

Holy Symbol.description: This is a sign or symbol of a cleric's beliefs. It is often used to physically ward off vampires, and DMs may make holy symbols necessary for a cleric to turn undead.
Holy Symbol.name: Holy Symbol
Holy Symbol.unidentifiedDesc: This is a sign or symbol of a cleric's beliefs. It is often used to physically ward off vampires, and DMs may make holy symbols necessary for a cleric to turn undead.

Holy Water.description: This water is made holy by a high-level cleric and can cause damage to undead creatures. It is typically stored in a breakable vial or gourd and can be thrown to splash the target.
Holy Water.name: Holy Water
Holy Water.unidentifiedDesc: This water is made holy by a high-level cleric and can cause damage to undead creatures. It is typically stored in a breakable vial or gourd and can be thrown to splash the target.

Holy Word.description:
This powerful spell affects all creatures, friend or foe, within a 40' radius of the caster. Creatures of alignments other than the cleric's suffer the following effects, with no saving throw allowed:

Creature Level / HDEffect
Up to 5th Level / HDKilled instantly
6th - 8th Level / HDStunned for [[/r 2d10 #turns]] turns
9th - 12th Level / HDDeafened for [[/r 1d6 #turns]] turns
13+ Level / HDStunned for [[/r 1d10 #rounds]] rounds

Saving Throw: Any creature of 13th level / HD or higher, or one that shares the cleric’s alignment, may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to negate all effects.

Obstructions: *Holy Word* is not blocked by stone or solid materials, except for lead. It is also stopped by an *Anti-Magic Shell*.
Holy Word.name: Holy Word

Hunting.description: This skill covers the ability to locate, stalk, and hunt game with weapons like bows, slings, or spears. A successful skill roll grants a +1 to hit against unaware targets in peaceful outdoor settings. This bonus does not apply in combat. The character can automatically supply themselves with food in fertile areas and make skill rolls in less abundant regions. The roll has penalties when trying to supply more than one person, with a -1 penalty per additional person.
Hunting.name: Hunting

Ice Storm.description:
This spell creates a storm of ice in a 20' x 20' x 20' area, or the largest available space within those dimensions, dealing 1d6 cold damage per caster level to all creatures in the area.

Saving Throw: Each creature may make a saving throw vs. spells for half damage. Fire-type creatures (e.g., red dragons, flame salamanders) suffer a -4 penalty to their saving throws, while cold-type creatures (e.g., frost giants, frost salamanders) are unaffected.
Ice Storm.name: Ice Storm

Immunity.description:
This spell grants the recipient powerful protections against spells and weapons for the duration.

Effects:

  • Complete immunity to all 1st-, 2nd-, and 3rd-level spells.

  • Resistance to 4th- and 5th-level spells:

    • Spells of these levels deal half normal effect.
    • Effects are further reduced to one-quarter normal if the target succeeds on a saving throw.
    • All spell effects that are quantifiable (damage, duration, bonuses, penalties) are rounded in the recipient's favor.

  • Weapon Protection:

    • Immune to all missiles (normal and magical).
    • Immune to normal and silver melee weapons.
    • Half damage from magical hand-held weapons.
    • This does not apply to natural attacks such as claws, bites, or breath weapons.

Special Interaction:

  • The recipient can temporarily drop the protection by concentrating (for example, to allow beneficial spells like cure wounds).
  • If dropped, the immunity is absent for one round, but automatically returns.

  • A carefully worded wish spell can extend the protection:

    • Grants immunity to 4th-level spells and +1 magical weapons.
    • Reduces effects of 5th- and 6th-level spells to half or one-quarter on a successful save.
    • No further improvements are possible.
Immunity.name: Immunity
Immunity.spellEffect: Grants immunity or resistance to spells and weapons

Infravision (D).description: Dwarves have infravision, allowing them to see in the dark up to 60 feet. They can perceive creatures and objects based on their temperature difference from the surroundings.
Infravision (D).name: Infravision (D)

Infravision (E).description: Elves have infravision, allowing them to see in the dark up to 60 feet. They can perceive creatures and objects based on their temperature difference from the surroundings.
Infravision (E).name: Infravision (E)

Infravision@C1l3yWeTccS9HEfR.description:
This spell grants the recipient the ability to see in the dark up to a 60' range, similar to the infravision of dwarves and elves. Infravision detects heat and works alongside normal vision, allowing the recipient to discern objects and creatures based on temperature differences.

Limitations: Infravision is ineffective in areas with normal or magical light. Heat sources like fires can obscure infravision, much like a flash of bright light can temporarily blind normal vision.

Vision Detail: Warm objects appear red, cold objects appear blue. Moving creatures appear as red shapes with faint red footprints, while cold water is deep blue. Items matching ambient temperature, such as tables or skeletons, appear as faint, light-blue shapes. Movement highlights these faint objects, making them obvious but blurry.

Infravision cannot be used to read or recognize individuals from a distance. A creature’s unique features may be discerned within 10' if highly distinctive (e.g., very tall or using a crutch).
Infravision@C1l3yWeTccS9HEfR.name: Infravision

Infravision@hYEizXtc25iDKcld.description: Infravision grants the recipient the ability to see in the dark up to a 60' range, similar to the infravision of dwarves and elves. Infravision detects heat and works alongside normal vision, allowing the recipient to discern objects and creatures based on temperature differences.
Infravision@hYEizXtc25iDKcld.name: Infravision

Ink, vial.description: A vial of black ink. Coloured ink costs double. Sufficient for about 50 pages of writing.
Ink, vial.name: Ink, vial
Ink, vial.unidentifiedDesc: A vial of black ink. Coloured ink costs double. Sufficient for about 50 pages of writing.

Insect Plague.description:
This spell summons a vast swarm of insects in a 30' radius, obscuring vision and driving off creatures with less than 3 Hit Dice (no saving throw). The caster can direct the swarm to move up to 20' per round within a range of 480' but must remain still and concentrate.

If the caster is disturbed, the insects scatter and the spell ends. This spell can only be cast outdoors and above ground.
Insect Plague.name: Insect Plague

Intimidation.description:
This skill allows the character to coerce or intimidate non-player characters (NPCs) into complying with their demands. Intimidation typically involves an implicit or explicit threat of violence or other consequences if the target does not comply. A successful skill check means the NPC is cowed into submission or action favorable to the character.

The skill is most effective against NPCs with lower levels or morale and is not usable on player characters. It has no effect on characters of 5th level or higher. NPCs subject to successful Intimidation are unlikely to view the character favorably in the future, and the relationship may be permanently damaged.

In situations where physical presence, strength, or combat prowess can be effectively displayed to bolster the threat, the DM may grant a bonus to the roll. However, this skill does not work against targets who are clearly in a superior position (such as a king surrounded by his elite guards).
Intimidation.name: Intimidation

Invisibility 10' Radius.description:
This spell makes the recipient and all other creatures within a 10' radius invisible at the time of casting. Creatures that move more than 10' away from the recipient lose their invisibility and cannot regain it by returning to the area.

The invisibility effect is similar to the standard *Invisibility* spell, where invisible creatures and items carried remain unseen until the creature attacks or casts a spell.

All items carried by affected creatures are also rendered invisible.
Invisibility 10' Radius.name: Invisibility 10' Radius

Invisibility@AoXEPSwDTZ3Ol3zZ.description: Invisibility allows a character or creature to become unseen by others, rendering them effectively invisible. While invisible, the user may be able to move and perform actions without being detected. Some attacks may require the user to become visible to target an opponent, while others can be executed while remaining invisible, allowing for stealthy strikes or surprise attacks. The duration of invisibility and any conditions that may end it can vary based on the specific context or rules governing the ability.
Invisibility@AoXEPSwDTZ3Ol3zZ.name: Invisibility

Invisibility@CRokTWBgRgtlXqP1.description:
This spell makes any one creature or object invisible. When a creature becomes invisible, all items it carries and wears also become invisible. Any invisible item becomes visible again when it leaves the creature's possession (dropped, set down, etc.). A light source (such as a torch) may be made invisible, but the light given off will remain visible.

If the spellcaster makes an object invisible that is not being carried or worn, it will become visible again when touched by any living creature. An invisible creature remains invisible until they attack or cast any spell.
Invisibility@CRokTWBgRgtlXqP1.name: Invisibility

Invisible.description:
A character who cannot see his opponent due to an invisibility spell suffers a -6 penalty to all attack rolls made against his invisible foe; he has to guess where his target is by hearing. He suffers no penalty to his AC when attacked by an invisible character. Remember, someone who attacks loses the bonuses of invisibility!

When a creature becomes invisible, all items it carries and wears also become invisible. Any invisible item becomes visible again when it leaves the creature's possession (dropped, set down, etc.). A light source (such as a torch) may be made invisible, but the light given off will remain visible.
Invisible.name: Invisible

Invisible Stalker.description:
This spell summons an Invisible Stalker from the elemental plane of air, which will obey the caster until its assigned task is completed.

Effects:

  • The Invisible Stalker will perform one mission as commanded by the caster, regardless of time or distance.
  • The summoned creature is invisible at all times and is a relentless tracker.
  • The creature remains until the task is completed or until it is slain.
  • A dispel evil spell will immediately banish the Invisible Stalker back to its home plane.

For full stats and details on the Invisible Stalker, refer to Chapter 14 in the rulebook.
Invisible Stalker.name: Invisible Stalker

Iron Spike.description: A large, long iron nail that can have either a flat head or an open circular head. It is used to wedge doors open, provide grips for climbing, or anchor ropes. A hammer is required to drive it into hard surfaces like stone or wood.
Iron Spike.name: Iron Spike
Iron Spike.unidentifiedDesc: A large, long iron nail that can have either a flat head or an open circular head. It is used to wedge doors open, provide grips for climbing, or anchor ropes. A hammer is required to drive it into hard surfaces like stone or wood.

Ironform.description:
This spell allows the caster to create a mass of iron, up to 500 square feet in area and up to 2 inches thick. The shape and arrangement are determined by the caster.

Creation Time:

  • Simple designs (walls, flat panels) take 1 round.
  • Moderate designs (stairs, basic structures) take 1 turn (10 rounds).
  • Complex designs (portcullises, detailed reinforcements) take up to 12 turns (2 hours), as determined by the DM.

Rules & Mechanics:

  • The iron must be one solid piece with no moving parts.
  • The caster may cast Ironform again on an existing structure to modify it for up to two hours.
  • Once finalized, the iron is permanently locked in place and cannot be further altered by Ironform.
  • The iron must rest on solid ground or a similar support.
  • Unlike Wall of Iron, the created iron does not have to be vertical.
  • The caster can form seamless joins to previously created Ironform objects.

Durability:

  • The created iron is not dispellable.
  • The iron lasts permanently unless broken or destroyed.
  • It can be destroyed by effects such as Disintegrate or by creatures like Rust Monsters.

  • According to the Fortifications Table:

    • Armor Class: -10 (2)
    • Hit Points: 15 per inch of thickness
Ironform.name: Ironform

Jacinth.description: Jacinth is a gemstone known for its vibrant orange-red hue. It has a polished, faceted surface that enhances its brilliance and clarity. Often used in jewelry, jacinth is valued for its fiery color and striking appearance.
Jacinth.name: Jacinth
Jacinth.unidentifiedDesc: Jacinth is a gemstone known for its vibrant orange-red hue. It has a polished, faceted surface that enhances its brilliance and clarity. Often used in jewelry, jacinth is valued for its fiery color and striking appearance.

Jade.description: Jade is a gemstone known for its smooth, polished surface and vibrant green color. It often has natural variations in hue and subtle patterns, showcasing its fine texture. Jade is traditionally used in carving and jewelry, valued for its beauty and cultural significance.
Jade.name: Jade
Jade.unidentifiedDesc: Jade is a gemstone known for its smooth, polished surface and vibrant green color. It often has natural variations in hue and subtle patterns, showcasing its fine texture. Jade is traditionally used in carving and jewelry, valued for its beauty and cultural significance.

Jasper.description: Jasper is an opaque gemstone featuring earthy tones like red, brown, and yellow. It often has unique natural patterns and a smooth, polished surface, highlighting its rich colors and intricate designs. Jasper is valued for its grounding and protective qualities in various cultures.
Jasper.name: Jasper
Jasper.unidentifiedDesc: Jasper is an opaque gemstone featuring earthy tones like red, brown, and yellow. It often has unique natural patterns and a smooth, polished surface, highlighting its rich colors and intricate designs. Jasper is valued for its grounding and protective qualities in various cultures.

Javelin +1.description: A javelin is a light one-handed throwing spear. Although primarily used as a thrown weapon, it can also be used in melee. Halflings and other small races can use this weapon.
Javelin +1.name: Javelin +1
Javelin +1.unidentifiedDesc: A javelin is a light one-handed throwing spear. Although primarily used as a thrown weapon, it can also be used in melee. Halflings and other small races can use this weapon.

Javelin@4PRKm7wgHL8tjrkB.description: A javelin is a light one-handed throwing spear. Although primarily used as a thrown weapon, it can also be used in melee. Halflings and other small races can use this weapon.
Javelin@4PRKm7wgHL8tjrkB.name: Javelin
Javelin@4PRKm7wgHL8tjrkB.unidentifiedDesc: A javelin is a light one-handed throwing spear. Although primarily used as a thrown weapon, it can also be used in melee. Halflings and other small races can use this weapon.

Knock.description:
This spell unlocks any type of lock, including normal and magically locked doors (such as those affected by hold portal or wizard lock). It can also open secret doors, but the door must be located first. The spell does not permanently remove locking magic, which will re-engage once the door is closed again.

Knock can unstick a gate, cause a barred door to open (forcing the bar to fall), and make treasure chests open easily. However, if a door is both locked and barred, only one of the locks will be affected.

Note: If the lock is affected by a spell, the target can make a saving throw vs. spells to resist.
Knock.name: Knock

Knocked Out.description: Knockout is simply a short sleep. The victim is unconscious and completely helpless. Feel free to cut their throat.
Knocked Out.name: Knocked Out

Know Alignment*.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to determine the alignment (Lawful, Neutral, or Chaotic) of any one creature within 10'. It can also reveal the alignment of an enchanted item or area, if applicable.

The reversed form, confuse alignment, lasts for one turn per level of the spellcaster and can be cast on a creature by touch. No saving throw is allowed. For the duration of the spell, any attempt to discern the recipient's alignment will yield a false result. This false alignment will remain consistent for all subsequent detection attempts during the spell's duration.
Know Alignment*.name: Know Alignment*

Knowledge (choose type).description: The character is an expert in one field of study such as history, theology, or geography. A character can make a living teaching or acting as an expert on the chosen subject. With a successful roll, they can provide detailed commentary or insights on the field of study. The specific type of knowledge must be defined, and multiple skills can be chosen for expertise in different subjects.
Knowledge (choose type).name: Knowledge (choose type)

Labor.description: This skill represents expertise in one type of manual labor such as bricklaying, farming, mining, or stonecutting. Characters can make their living with this skill and interpret information related to their occupation. Specify which type of labor the skill pertains to, such as bricklaying, mining, or stonecutting. A character can select multiple Labor skills, each representing a different proficiency.
Labor.name: Labor

Lance +1.description: A lance is an extremely long spear, 9’ to 12’ long. It is too unwieldy to use on foot, and can only be used when mounted—in which case it can be used in one hand despite its length. See rules for this weapon is used.
Lance +1.name: Lance +1
Lance +1.unidentifiedDesc: A lance is an extremely long spear, 9’ to 12’ long. It is too unwieldy to use on foot, and can only be used when mounted—in which case it can be used in one hand despite its length. See rules for this weapon is used.

Lance Attack.description: When mounted and using a lance, a character can perform a powerful charge attack. If the attack is successful, the character gains double their Strength modifier to the damage roll. This ability is most effective when charging against opponents.
Lance Attack.name: Lance Attack

Lance@gUUAH9zgkDIZn6FS.description: A lance is an extremely long spear, 9’ to 12’ long. It is too unwieldy to use on foot, and can only be used when mounted—in which case it can be used in one hand despite its length. See rules for this weapon is used.
Lance@gUUAH9zgkDIZn6FS.name: Lance
Lance@gUUAH9zgkDIZn6FS.unidentifiedDesc: A lance is an extremely long spear, 9’ to 12’ long. It is too unwieldy to use on foot, and can only be used when mounted—in which case it can be used in one hand despite its length. See rules for this weapon is used.

Language (choose type).description: Allows the character to speak and read a specific language beyond their normal allocation. Each additional language is chosen separately, such as Elvish, Dwarven, or Thyatian. The character must make a skill check to understand technical or fast-paced speech in these additional languages.
Language (choose type).name: Language (choose type)

Lantern.description: An oil lantern illuminates a 30-foot radius and consumes one flask of oil over four hours (24 turns). Most lanterns are designed to be enclosed or equipped with shutters to shield the flame from the wind​​.
Lantern.name: Lantern
Lantern.unidentifiedDesc: An oil lantern illuminates a 30-foot radius and consumes one flask of oil over four hours (24 turns). Most lanterns are designed to be enclosed or equipped with shutters to shield the flame from the wind​​.

Lantern, Bullseye.description:
A bullseye lantern is a portable light source enclosed within a metal casing, designed to focus a beam of light in a single direction. The lantern features a hinged, adjustable hood that can be raised or lowered to focus or block the light as needed. The lantern illuminates an area up to 60 feet away

The lantern burns one flask of oil over the course of four hours (24 turns). Its enclosed design helps protect the flame from wind and rain, making it more reliable in outdoor or adverse conditions compared to an open flame.
Lantern, Bullseye.name: Lantern, Bullseye
Lantern, Bullseye.unidentifiedDesc:
A bullseye lantern is a portable light source enclosed within a metal casing, designed to focus a beam of light in a single direction. The lantern features a hinged, adjustable hood that can be raised or lowered to focus or block the light as needed. The lantern illuminates an area up to 60 feet away

The lantern burns one flask of oil over the course of four hours (24 turns). Its enclosed design helps protect the flame from wind and rain, making it more reliable in outdoor or adverse conditions compared to an open flame.

Law and Justice (choose culture).description:
This skill provides a character with a detailed knowledge of the laws and judicial systems of a specific culture or country. Characters who wish to be a judge or advocate (lawyer) must select this skill. Each culture or nation has its own codes, so characters who wish to be conversant in different nations' legal systems must choose this skill separately for each set of laws they wish to study.

A successful skill check can help the character recall specific laws and customs, advise others in legal matters, and argue effectively in courts or other formal settings.
Law and Justice (choose culture).name: Law and Justice (choose culture)

Leadership.description: The Leadership skill represents a character's ability to inspire, command, and direct others. It is used to coordinate group efforts, boost morale, and make strategic decisions in both peaceful and combat situations. Characters with high Leadership can motivate followers, maintain order, and effectively communicate plans to allies.
Leadership.name: Leadership

Leather Armor.description: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates and strips. The leather is often boiled in wax to harden it. Leather armor gives an armor class of 7, and because it is made from natural materials it can be worn by druids. It is also light and quiet enough to be worn by thieves.
Leather Armor.name: Leather Armor
Leather Armor.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates and strips. The leather is often boiled in wax to harden it. Leather armor gives an armor class of 7, and because it is made from natural materials it can be worn by druids. It is also light and quiet enough to be worn by thieves.

Leather Armor +1.description:
This is a magic suit of armor primarily composed of leather plates and strips. The leather is often boiled in wax to harden it. Magical leather armor gives an armor class of 7 plus magic bonus, and because it is made from natural materials it can be worn by druids. It is also light and quiet enough to be worn by thieves.

Magic armor weighs half that of its nonmagic counterpart.
Leather Armor +1.name: Leather Armor +1
Leather Armor +1.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates and strips. The leather is often boiled in wax to harden it. Non-magical leather armor gives an armor class of 7, and because it is made from natural materials it can be worn by druids. It is also light and quiet enough to be worn by thieves.

Levitate.description:
This spell allows the caster to move vertically, up or down, without support. The caster cannot move side to side without pushing against something. Vertical movement is at a rate of 20' per round.

The spell can only be cast on the caster, who can carry up to 2,000 cn (200 lbs) while levitating. The caster can carry another man-sized creature if it isn’t wearing metal armor or heavily burdened. No saving throw is allowed for the levitated target.

Duration: 6 turns plus 1 turn per level.
Levitate.name: Levitate

Levitating.description:
Allows the caster to move vertically, up or down, without support. The caster cannot move side to side without pushing against something. Vertical movement is at a rate of 20' per round.

Caster can carry up to 2,000 cn (200 lbs) while levitating. The caster can carry another man-sized creature if it isn’t wearing metal armor or heavily burdened. No saving throw is allowed for the levitated target.
Levitating.name: Levitating

Life Drain*.description:
The reverse of Restore, this spell drains one level of experience from the touched victim, just like the touch of a wight or wraith.

Effects:

  • The victim loses one full level of experience immediately.
  • If the victim is reduced to zero levels, they perish.

Cleric Effects:

  • Unlike *Restore*, casting this spell does not cause any level loss to the cleric.
  • No rest is required after casting.

Alignment: This is a Chaotic act, generally avoided by Lawful clerics.
Life Drain*.name: Life Drain*

Light*.description:
This spell creates a large ball of light with a 30' diameter, similar to bright torchlight. If cast on an object, the light moves with it. If cast at a creature’s eyes, the target must save vs. spells or be blinded until the spell ends. If the saving throw succeeds, the light appears behind the target.

The reverse, darkness, creates a 30' diameter circle of darkness that blocks all sight except infravision. Darkness can counter light and vice-versa. If cast at a creature’s eyes, the target must save vs. spells or be blinded until the effect ends.
Light*.name: Light*

Light* (C).description:
This spell creates a sphere of light, as if cast by a bright torch or lamp. If the spell is cast on an object (such as a weapon), the light moves with the object.

If the spell is cast at a creature's eyes, the victim makes a saving throw vs. spell. If the saving throw fails, the victim is blinded by the light for the duration of the spell, or until the spell effect is canceled.

When reversed, this spell, darkness, creates a sphere of darkness instead. It will block all sight except infravision. Darkness cancels a light spell if cast upon it, but may itself be canceled by another light spell. If cast at an opponent's eyes, darkness causes blindness for the duration of the spell or until canceled. If the victim makes a successful saving throw vs. spell, the spell has no effect.
Light* (C).name: Light* (C)

Lightning Bolt.description:
This spell creates a bolt of lightning that begins up to 180' away from the caster and extends 60' further in a straight line. All creatures within the area of effect take 1d6 points of lightning damage per caster level.

Damage: For example, a 6th-level elf would cast a lightning bolt dealing 6d6 points of damage. Each creature in the path of the bolt may make a saving throw vs. spells for half damage.

Special Effect: If the bolt strikes a solid surface, it bounces back toward the caster until it reaches its full length of 60'.
Lightning Bolt.name: Lightning Bolt

Lip Reading.description: Allows the character to "overhear" a conversation by watching the target's lips. The character must be able to see the target and understand the language being spoken. Success means the character understands the conversation. The distance and available light affect the difficulty of the skill check.
Lip Reading.name: Lip Reading

Listen Door.description:
Listening for noises is a skill any character can attempt, commonly used at doors or in other quiet environments. To attempt this, the area must be silent, and all party members must remain still to avoid interfering with the attempt. The Dungeon Master rolls or the player rolls blind, whether or not a sound exists, to maintain player uncertainty. A successful roll allows the character to hear any detectable noises if conditions permit.
Demi-humans, such as dwarves, elves, and halflings, get a bonus of 1 for their listen roll. Thieves also gain increased effectiveness at this task as they progress in levels​​.
Listen Door.name: Listen Door

Locate.description:
This spell allows the druid to sense the direction of one known normal or giant-sized animal or plant within 120 feet. The caster must name the exact type of animal or plant, but does not need to see the specific one to locate it. This spell cannot locate fantastic creatures, plant monsters, or any intelligent creatures or plants.

The animal or plant gets no saving throw. (This spell is most often used to find special rare plants.)
Locate.name: Locate

Locate Object.description:
The caster can locate a specific object within range. The caster must know the exact appearance of the object, or specify a common type such as "any flight of stairs."

The spell will point towards the nearest specified object within range, providing direction but not distance. Range increases by 10' per level of the caster.
Locate Object.name: Locate Object

Locate Object (C).description: This spell allows the caster to sense the direction of a known object within range, but not its distance. It can detect a common object with a partial description, such as "stairs leading up," but will only indicate the direction of the nearest such object. To find a specific object, the caster must know exactly what the object looks like (size, shape, color, etc.). The spell will not locate a creature.
Locate Object (C).name: Locate Object (C)

Lore.description:
This spell grants the caster knowledge of one item, place, or person. The amount of time required depends on the subject being studied.

Identifying an Item:

  • If the caster holds the item being studied, the spell takes [[/r 1d4 #Turns to complete Lore spell]] turns to complete.

  • The caster learns the following details:

    • Name of the item.
    • Method of operation and command words (if any).
    • Approximate number of charges (within 5 of the correct number).
  • If the item has multiple functions or command words, only one function will be revealed per casting.
  • The spell will not hint at additional functions beyond the one revealed.

Investigating a Place, Person, or Distant Item:

  • If the subject is not held by the caster, the spell takes [[/r 1d100 #Days to complete Lore spell]] days to complete.
  • Legendary topics may take the maximum amount of time.
  • Information may be revealed as riddles, poems, or vague descriptions.
  • For large places or powerful beings, the DM may reveal only general details.
Lore.name: Lore
Lore.spellEffect: Reveals details of 1 item, place, or person

Lower Water.description:
This spell causes a body of water to lower to half its normal depth in an area up to 10,000 square feet (width and length).

Effects:

  • The spell affects the area for the entire duration (or until dispelled).
  • If cast on a flowing body of water (such as a river or ocean), the water remains lowered in that area, and surrounding water does not flow in until the spell ends.
  • Ships and boats in the affected area may become stuck.

At Spell Expiration:

  • The water rushes back in suddenly, causing a violent surge.
  • Affected ships suffer 1d12 + 20 (21-32) points of hull damage.
  • Creatures on deck must make a saving throw vs. spells or be swept overboard.

Uses:

  • Ford a river by temporarily reducing its depth.
  • Reveal hidden areas by lowering pools of water.
  • Strand ships by dropping the water level around them.
Lower Water.name: Lower Water

Lute.description: A plucked string instrument with a rounded body and a fretted neck, popular in both secular and sacred music.
Lute.name: Lute

Mace +1.description: A magic mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.
Mace +1.name: Mace +1
Mace +1.unidentifiedDesc: A mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.

Mace +2.description: A magic mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.
Mace +2.name: Mace +2
Mace +2.unidentifiedDesc: A mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.

Mace@BPEBQB0DJ9Vm4E5A.description: A mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.
Mace@BPEBQB0DJ9Vm4E5A.name: Mace
Mace@BPEBQB0DJ9Vm4E5A.unidentifiedDesc: A mace is a one handed melee weapon consisting of a 2’-3’ long shaft with a heavy metal head. The head can be smooth (round or pear shaped), can contain flanges or studs, or can even be sculpted into the shape of a fist or skull or other roundish object.

Magic Door*.description:
This spell creates a magical, invisible doorway that only the spellcaster may use. It forms a passage through up to 10 feet of non-living solid material (wall, floor, ceiling, or ground). The door cannot be created in living objects.

Mechanics & Rules:

  • The door is invisible and can only be detected by Detect Magic.
  • It cannot be destroyed except by Dispel Magic (normal chances for success).
  • The passage remains until it has been used seven times (each one-way passage counts as a use) or is dispelled.
Magic Door*.name: Magic Door*

Magic Jar.description:
This spell transfers the caster's life force into an inanimate object within 30' (referred to as a "magic jar" regardless of its form). The caster’s body falls into a trance. From the magic jar, the caster can attempt to possess a creature within 120' of the jar.

Possession Attempt: The target must make a saving throw vs. spells. If successful, the caster cannot attempt to possess that creature again for one turn. If failed, the caster takes over the creature’s body, and the creature’s life force is transferred to the magic jar.

Actions in Possessed Body: The caster can perform normal actions, but no special abilities (similar to *Polymorph Self*). A *Dispel Evil* spell forces the caster's life force back into the magic jar.

Destruction Effects: If the magic jar is destroyed while the caster's life force is within, the caster dies. If the jar is destroyed while the caster possesses a body, the caster is stranded in that body, and the original owner's life force is destroyed. If the caster’s original body is destroyed, they are stranded in the magic jar until a new body is taken.

Taking over another body is considered a Chaotic act.
Magic Jar.name: Magic Jar

Magic Lock*.description:
This spell permanently locks any one portal (door, gate, hatch, or empty 10' x 10' opening). Unlike Wizard Lock, this cannot be bypassed by Knock or magical items.

Mechanics & Rules:

  • The locked portal remains impassable to all except the spellcaster.
  • The portal appears unchanged and cannot be detected as magical without Detect Magic.
  • The lock lasts until the portal has been used seven times (each time the caster passes through counts as a use) or until Dispel Magic is used.
