Magic Lock*.name: Magic Lock*
Magic Lock*.spellEffect: Seals a portal against all but the caster

Magic Missile.description:
This spell creates a glowing arrow that inflicts [[/r 1d6+1 #Magic missile damage]] (2-7) points of damage to any visible target specified by the caster. The arrow always hits and no saving throw is allowed. After the spell is cast, the arrow appears next to the caster and hovers there (moving with the caster) until shot.

For every 5 levels of experience, two additional missiles are created by the same spell. The caster can direct these missiles at one or multiple targets.
Magic Missile.name: Magic Missile

Magic Resistance (D).description:
Upon reaching 1,400,000 experience points, a Dwarf gains an innate resistance to magic, reducing the damage they take from spells and certain magical effects. This resistance applies to all damage-causing spells and spell-like effects, including those from magical items and special abilities of monsters (such as a beholder’s eye rays). However, it does not apply to dragon breath attacks.

Damage Reduction

  • When subjected to a damage-dealing spell or magical effect, the Dwarf automatically takes only half damage. The total damage rolled is divided by 2, rounding down.
  • If the effect allows a saving throw, a successful save further reduces the damage to one-quarter of the total rolled. In this case, divide the damage by 4, rounding down.

Minimum Damage Rule

  • If the final damage calculation results in ½ a point or less, the Dwarf instead takes 1 point of damage.

This ability reflects the Dwarves' natural toughness and resistance to arcane forces, making them incredibly resilient against hostile magic.
Magic Resistance (D).name: Magic Resistance (D)

Magic Resistance (H).description:
Upon reaching 300,000 XP, a Halfling gains innate resistance to magic. They automatically take half damage from any damage-causing spell or spell-like effect (including magical items). If the effect allows a saving throw, a successful save further reduces the damage to one-quarter.

When calculating reduced damage, always round fractions down. If the final damage is ½ a point or less, the Halfling takes 1 point of damage instead.
Magic Resistance (H).name: Magic Resistance (H)

Magic Wand.description: The Magic Wand saving throw is used to avoid the effects of attacks or abilities activated through magical wands, such as paralysis rays or damage-dealing beams. A successful save, rolled on a d20, indicates that the character avoids or mitigates the harmful effects. The target number to save is determined by the character's class and level, as found on the saving throw table​​.
Magic Wand.name: Magic Wand

Magic's End.description:
When sung, this spell-song dispels all spells and magical effects within its area of effect. However, unlike the Dispel Magic spell, there is always a chance that a spell or effect will resist being dispelled.

Effects:

  • Dispels all spells and magical effects within a 20' x 20' x 20' cube.
  • Each affected spell or effect has a base 20% resistance if its level is equal to or lower than the bard's level.
  • For every level higher than the bard's, the resistance increases by +5%.

Resistance Calculation:

  • Example: A 7th-level bard attempts to dispel a Cloudkill spell cast by a 12th-level magic-user.
  • The resistance chance is 20% + (5% x 5) = 45%.
  • Roll [[/r 1d100 #Dispel Resistance]]; if the result is lower than or equal to the resistance chance, the spell resists being dispelled.

Additional Notes:

  • Applies to spell-like effects from magic items, with the DM estimating the original caster's level.
  • Permanent magical effects are subject to DM discretion for dispelling.
Magic's End.name: Magic's End
Magic's End.spellEffect: Attempts to dispel all magical effects in the area

Magic-User.description:
A magic-user is a human character dedicated to the study of arcane knowledge and the casting of spells. They are among the most versatile and powerful classes but are physically fragile and limited in combat abilities. Their focus on magic allows them to wield extraordinary power as they gain experience.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Intelligence, granting an experience bonus for high scores (5% for 13–15, 10% for 16–18).
  • Combat Skills: Magic-users cannot wear armor or use shields and are restricted to using daggers. At the DM's discretion, other light weapons such as staves or slings may be permitted.
  • Hit Dice: They use a d4 for hit points per level up to 9th level. Beyond that, they gain a fixed 1 hit point per level without Constitution bonuses.
  • Spellcasting: Magic-users learn and prepare spells from a spellbook. Their magic includes a wide range of effects, such as attack spells (e.g., Fireball), utility spells (e.g., Knock), and defensive spells (e.g., Shield).

Advancement:

  • At 9th level (Name level), a magic-user becomes a "Wizard" (male) or "Maga" (female). Wizards can create magic items, such as scrolls or potions.
  • Magic-users may construct a tower as a personal stronghold. Once completed, the tower attracts 1d6 apprentices (1st–3rd level magic-users), who serve the wizard as students and assistants.
  • If a dungeon is built beneath or near the tower and left unguarded, it may attract monsters. Some wizards encourage this to create a ready source of material for research and training.

Stronghold Options:

  • Independent Wizards: Magic-users building their own towers typically do so without seeking approval from local rulers. However, gaining the ruler's favor might result in gifts or an official title to the land.
  • Magists: Magic-users can serve as court wizards, known as Magists, advising rulers on magical matters in exchange for room, board, and a stipend (usually 3,000 gp per month or more). This arrangement allows continued magical research, often funded by the ruler.

Magic-users begin their careers as fragile and vulnerable adventurers but grow into formidable spellcasters capable of altering the course of campaigns with their arcane abilities. Their strongholds often serve as hubs of magical research and influence.
Magic-User.name: Magic-User

Magical Engineering.description: Grants the ability to recognize the basic principles behind unfamiliar magical devices. This does not include training in the design or fabrication of magical artifacts but does allow identification of common magical items with a successful skill check. It doesn't allow a character to recognize uncommon magical items or to distinguish trapped or cursed items from those that are safe.
Magical Engineering.name: Magical Engineering

Mapping / Cartography.description: A character with this skill can understand and create maps, even if they cannot read and write. No roll is needed to comprehend simple maps, but a skill roll is necessary for interpreting or drafting complex layouts. Mapping skill can be used to map an area from memory or to draw accurate maps of places visited. This skill is useful for explorers, adventurers, and merchants.
Mapping / Cartography.name: Mapping / Cartography

Mass Charm*.description:
This spell functions like charm person or charm monster, but affects up to 30 total levels or Hit Dice of creatures.

Charm Effects:

  • Creatures of 31+ levels or HD are immune.
  • Each victim may attempt a saving throw vs. spells (-2 penalty) to resist the charm.
  • Charm duration is based on Intelligence (as per charm person).

Breaking the Charm:

  • If the caster attacks a charmed creature, only that creature's charm is broken.
  • Other charmed creatures witnessing the attack may attempt a new saving throw.
  • Otherwise, other charms remain unaffected.
Mass Charm*.name: Mass Charm*
Mass Charm*.spellEffect: Charms up to 30 levels/HD of creatures

Mass Invisibility*.description:
This spell grants invisibility (as the Invisibility spell) to multiple creatures or objects within a 60' square area up to 240' from the caster.

Effect:

  • Affects up to 6 dragon-sized creatures or 300 man-sized creatures.
  • Each recipient becomes invisible, along with all their carried equipment.
  • Invisibility lasts permanently until broken.
  • Attacking or casting a spell ends the invisibility.
Mass Invisibility*.name: Mass Invisibility*
Mass Invisibility*.spellEffect: Creatures or objects in a 60' square area become invisible

Massmorph.description:
This spell causes up to 100 human- or man-sized creatures within a 240' diameter to appear as trees, such as in an orchard or dense forest. The type of tree or plant life should be appropriate to the terrain and environment (for instance, it typically would not work in a desert without large cacti).

Target Types: Only willing creatures are affected. Larger creatures, like horses, can be included, counting as two or three men-sized creatures each.

Effect: The illusion hides recipients from others moving through the affected area. A creature’s normal appearance returns if it moves out of the area, but movement within the area does not break the illusion. The spell lasts until dispelled or dismissed by the caster.
Massmorph.name: Massmorph
Massmorph.spellEffect: Causes illusion of trees within 240' range

Maze.description:
This spell creates an indestructible maze in the Astral Plane and instantly traps one victim within it. The target does not receive a saving throw.

Escape Time:

The intelligence of the victim determines how long they remain trapped.

  • Non- to Low Intelligence (1-8): [[/r 1d6 #Turns trapped in maze]] turns
  • Average Intelligence (9-12): [[/r 2d20 #Rounds trapped in maze]] rounds
  • High Intelligence (13-17): [[/r 2d4 #Rounds trapped in maze]] rounds
  • Genius Intelligence (18+): [[/r 1d4 #Rounds trapped in maze]] rounds

Mechanics:

  • The victim is removed from the battlefield for the duration.
  • When they escape, they reappear in the exact location where they were originally trapped.
  • The maze is indestructible and exists only in the Astral Plane.
  • Teleportation and dimensional travel cannot bypass this effect.
Maze.name: Maze
Maze.spellEffect: Traps one creature in an astral maze

Metal to Wood.description:
This spell permanently transforms metal into dead wood.

Effects:

  • The caster may transmute up to 5 pounds (50 cn) of metal per caster level.
  • The transformation is permanent and cannot be reversed by dispel magic.
  • Magical metal items have a 90% chance to resist this effect.
  • Armor transformed into wood falls off the wearer.
  • Weapons turned into wood become nonmagical wooden clubs.
Metal to Wood.name: Metal to Wood

Meteor Swarm.description:
This spell creates either 4 large or 8 smaller meteors (chosen by the caster). Each meteor never misses its target and explodes like a fireball upon impact.

Meteor Options:

  • 4 Large Meteors: Each strikes for [[/r 8d6 #Meteor Impact Damage]] points and then explodes for [[/r 8d6 #Explosion Damage]] points of fire damage.
  • 8 Small Meteors: Each strikes for [[/r 4d6 #Meteor Impact Damage]] points and then explodes for [[/r 4d6 #Explosion Damage]] points of fire damage.

Mechanics:

  • Meteors can be aimed at different targets within range, but only one meteor can hit a single creature.
  • Impact damage is automatic (no saving throw).
  • Each meteor creates a 20' radius blast upon impact.
  • Explosion damage: Creatures within the blast may make a saving throw vs. spells to take half damage.
  • Fire-resistant and fire-using creatures are fully affected by impact damage, but may resist explosion damage.
  • Areas affected by overlapping blasts take multiple explosion damages separately.
Meteor Swarm.name: Meteor Swarm
Meteor Swarm.spellEffect: Creates four or eight meteors that explode on impact

Military Tactics.description: This skill allows a character to analyze the movement of enemy forces and effectively position their own troops. The player describes their tactical plan, and the DM rolls a Military Tactics skill check. If successful, the DM confirms the plan is viable and offers additional strategic insights. A failed roll means the character misinterprets the enemy's intentions or chooses an ineffective strategy.
Military Tactics.name: Military Tactics

Mimicry.description: The character can convincingly imitate animal sounds and foreign accents. This is particularly useful in wilderness settings, such as when communicating with allies using animal calls or deceiving enemies by imitating their language or speech patterns. A successful skill check ensures the mimicry is indistinguishable from the real sound or accent.
Mimicry.name: Mimicry

Mind Barrier*.description:
This spell grants one creature powerful protection against mental effects for 1 hour per caster level. An unwilling target may make a saving throw vs. spells to resist.

Effects:

  • The target is completely immune to ESP, clairvoyance, clairaudience, crystal ball gazing, and similar magical detection.
  • Prevents magical information gathering (such as contact higher plane or summon object).
  • For the duration, the caster or recipient effectively does not exist to these effects.
  • The target gains +8 to all saving throws against charm, illusion, phantasms, feeblemind, and other mental attacks.
  • A natural roll of 1 always fails, regardless of bonuses.
Mind Barrier*.name: Mind Barrier*
Mind Barrier*.spellEffect: Grants immunity to mind-affecting magic and +8 to saves vs. mental attacks

Mind Block.description: The mystic is immune to ESP, hold and slow spells, magical charms, quests, and geas spells.
Mind Block.name: Mind Block

Mind Render.description:
When sung, this spell-song induces an overwhelming, paranoid fear in all sentient beings within the area of effect, unless they successfully resist the effect.

Effects:

  • Every creature within a 30' x 30' x 30' area must make a saving throw vs. Spells at -2 each round they remain inside.
  • Creatures that succeed on the save each round or leave the area remain unaffected.
  • Creatures that fail a saving throw while in the area instantly become delusional, believing that all nearby beings are enemies.

Frenzied Assault:

  • Delusional victims have a 50% chance each round to attack the nearest person, regardless of friend or foe.
  • Attacks made while in this state gain +1 to hit and +1 to damage (stacking with Strength bonuses).
  • The effect persists even if the victim leaves the area of effect.
  • The frenzy lasts for a number of **hours** equal to the **bard's level**.

Ending the Effect:

  • The frenzy can be removed with remove curse, wish, or any other spell that removes enchantments.

Duration & Risks:

  • The bard may maintain this song for a number of rounds equal to their Constitution score.
  • If the bard continues playing beyond this limit, they must make a saving throw vs. Spells each round or fall under the **same effects** as the victims.
  • The spell-song affects everyone within the area, including the bard’s allies.

Rolls:

  • Frenzied assault chance: [[/r 1d100 #50% chance to attack the nearest person]]
  • Bard's Constitution limit: [[/r @actor.system.abilities.con.value #Rounds the bard can sing safely]]
Mind Render.name: Mind Render
Mind Render.spellEffect: Causes paranoia and frenzied attacks in affected creatures

Mirror.description: This hand-sized steel mirror is used to look around corners or defend against gaze attacks. When used to observe a foe, the user suffers a -2 penalty to attack rolls and cannot use a shield as they are holding the mirror. The area must be lit for it to be effective.
Mirror.name: Mirror
Mirror.unidentifiedDesc: This hand-sized steel mirror is used to look around corners or defend against gaze attacks. When used to observe a foe, the user suffers a -2 penalty to attack rolls and cannot use a shield as they are holding the mirror. The area must be lit for it to be effective.

Mirror Image.description:
This spell creates [[/r 1d4 #Number of Images]] illusory duplicates of the spellcaster that move and act like them. The images stay within 3' of the caster and imitate their movements and speech without requiring concentration.

The images are not real and cannot take any actions. Any successful attack that would hit the spellcaster instead destroys one of the images, regardless of damage. This continues until all images are gone. Area attacks, such as a fireball, destroy all images at once and also affect the spellcaster.
Mirror Image.name: Mirror Image

Mirror Imaged.description:
The images stay within 3' of the caster and imitate their movements and speech without requiring concentration.

The images are not real and cannot take any actions. Any successful attack that would hit the spellcaster instead destroys one of the images, regardless of damage. This continues until all images are gone. Area attacks, such as a fireball, destroy all images at once and also affect the spellcaster.
Mirror Imaged.name: Mirror Imaged

Mountaineering.description: This skill covers the techniques and physical ability required for climbing steep and hazardous terrains, such as mountains and cliffs. Characters with Mountaineering can navigate difficult slopes, secure safe paths, and assist others in ascent or descent. The skill can also be used to avoid dangers like rockslides or falling.
Mountaineering.name: Mountaineering

Move Earth.description:
This spell allows the caster to move large quantities of soil (but not rock) within a range of 240'. The spell moves soil at a rate of 60' per turn.

Effects:

  • Soil can be moved horizontally to create hills, embankments, or barriers.
  • Soil can be moved vertically to create a pit or trench up to 240' deep (unless stopped by bedrock).
  • Once moved, the soil remains in place permanently at the end of the spell’s duration.

Uses:

  • Construct fortifications or reshape landscapes.
  • Create defensive barriers or block paths.
  • Excavate trenches or tunnels for tactical purposes.
Move Earth.name: Move Earth

Move Silently.description: A user of this ability can move silently, avoiding detection while attempting to sneak past others.
Move Silently.name: Move Silently

Move Silently (B).description:
A Bard can move without making a sound, using the same chance as a Thief of the same level. This allows them to bypass guards, avoid disturbing loose ground, or approach enemies unnoticed. If the Bard is carrying a noisy object, such as coins or metal gear, the DM may impose additional penalties.

Armor Penalties:

  • Scale Mail: –15%
  • Chain Mail: –20% (–10% if Elven Chain)
Move Silently (B).name: Move Silently (B)

Multiple Attacks.description:
This maneuver allows a character to make multiple attacks in melee combat. If the character can hit an opponent with a roll of 2 or higher (after applying all modifiers), they gain two attacks per round against that target. At higher levels, this increases to three attacks per round, and eventually to four attacks per round.

Each attack in this series can be a different type, including a throw, a standard attack, a lance attack, or a disarm. The character can combine these maneuvers in any sequence; for example, with three attacks per round, they could perform an attack, a disarm, and another attack, or throw three knives in succession. This maneuver is most effective under optimal conditions, and the character can replace any attack with movement or another action if desired.
Multiple Attacks.name: Multiple Attacks

Muscle.description:
The Muscle skill represents a character's training in heavy lifting and strenuous physical tasks, such as opening stuck doors, breaking objects, or moving large weights. Characters with this skill can direct groups of laborers to optimize their efforts when moving heavy loads or using simple machinery like pulleys and levers.

With a successful skill check, the character gains a +2 bonus on Strength checks for tasks involving raw physical power, such as forcing open a door or bending bars. This skill is invaluable for characters who frequently engage in physically demanding situations.

The skill also allows the character to apply basic principles of physics to their advantage, using leverage and technique to multiply their effective strength. Many characters who are laborers, warriors, or athletes commonly possess this skill.
Muscle.name: Muscle

Music (choose type).description: The Music skill represents a character's proficiency with a specific type of musical instrument, such as a lute, harp, or drum. The chosen instrument type must be specified when the skill is selected. Characters with this skill can perform melodies that entertain, inspire, or soothe. A successful Music check can influence the mood of an audience, enhance the effects of magical performances, or distract opponents.
Music (choose type).name: Music (choose type)

Mystic.description:
Mystics are monastic individuals who follow a strict discipline of meditation, self-denial, isolation, and mastery of their physical form, excelling in unarmed combat. They live in cloisters—monastic communities—and venture out to seek spiritual growth and life lessons, typically joining diverse adventuring parties rather than traveling with other mystics. Mystics gain experience from treasure only by donating it to the needy, and they must tithe ten percent to their cloister. Their oath is binding; breaking it results in expulsion, an inability to gain new experience levels, a loss of one level per year away from the cloister, and exclusion from similar cloisters, though a Dungeon Master may offer a grand quest for redemption.

Most mystics (75%) are Lawful, yet all are fully devoted to their neutral discipline, relying on inner strength and non-magical abilities rather than nature’s power, unlike druids. Recognizable by their robes or unique garb, mystics also perform a distinctive salute: upon meeting a presumed peaceful creature, they raise a fist, cover it with the other hand, and bow slightly, symbolizing a greeting (the bow), readiness to fight if necessary (the fist), and peaceful intent (the covered fist).

Key Characteristics

  • Minimum Scores: To become a mystic, a character must achieve scores of 13 or higher in both Wisdom and Dexterity abilities.

  • Armor: Mystics are prohibited from wearing any form of armor and are also barred from using protective magical items (such as rings, cloaks, etc.); they depend entirely on their discipline for defense.

  • Weapons: While mystics are trained in the use of all weapons, not all choose to carry them. Higher-level mystics, in particular, often travel unarmed or equipped solely with a walking-staff, which also serves as a quarter-staff.

Special Restrictions

Mystics are not permitted to use protective magical devices (such as rings, cloaks, etc.). All material possessions (money, magical items, etc.) earned, bought, or obtained as treasure by the mystic are considered to be owned by his cloister, rather than by the mystic himself. If the cloister requires something "owned" by a mystic, the head of the cloister need only request it.
Mystic.name: Mystic

Mystic Natural Armor.description:
LevelACMovementHand Attacks (#AT)DamageAbilities
19120'11d4
28130'11d4+1Awareness
37140'11d6
46150'11d6+1Heal Self
55160'21d8
64170'21d8+1Speak with Animals
73180'21d10
82190'21d12Resistance
9*1200'32d8
100210'32d10Speak with Anyone
11-1220'32d12
12-2240'33d8+1Mind Block
13-3260'44d6+2
14-4280'45d6Blankout
15-5300'44d8
16-6320'43d12Gentle Touch

*The mystic receives the Fighter Combat Options (excluding multiple attacks); see the description of them under "Combat Maneuvers" in Chapter 8. The mystic can use these Combat Options with weapons or in unarmed fighting.
Mystic Natural Armor.name: Mystic Natural Armor

Mysticism.description:
This skill allows a character to instinctively know the proper actions to take in order to please the Immortals in general. A successful skill check can indicate the appropriate behavior or ritual to use when encountering sacred objects, places, or situations related to the Immortals.

For example, a successful check might reveal that the party should leave an offering at a shrine or avoid disturbing a holy site. This skill also allows a character to recognize symbols and artifacts of the Immortals, as well as to interpret omens or signs given by them.
Mysticism.name: Mysticism

Nature Lore.description: This skill provides knowledge of plant and animal life in a specific terrain (e.g., desert, forest, jungle). The character can identify edible and poisonous plants, spot signs of unnatural danger, and know when something is out of place in the natural environment. When used in the character's home terrain, they receive a -2 bonus to their skill check; in unfamiliar but similar terrain, no bonus or penalty applies; in very different terrain, a penalty of up to +4 may be imposed.
Nature Lore.name: Nature Lore

Navigation.description: By taking directions from the position of the sun and the stars (or other atmospheric phenomena appropriate in your campaign), the character can always know roughly where they are. Successful skill rolls, with positive or negative modifiers for the character's distance from their home territory and familiarity with their surroundings, will tell the character more precisely where they are. This skill can prevent parties from getting lost and may help them reorient when disoriented in unknown regions. The DM may require a check every day to keep the party on course.
Navigation.name: Navigation

Net (6'x6').description:
A net is an open weave of rope or cord that serves as a versatile tool and weapon. Small nets, measuring up to 10' x 10', are commonly used in hunting and adventuring. They can function as either hand-to-hand or thrown weapons. The encumbrance of a net depends on its size. Widely available in most campaign settings, nets are inexpensive but easily damaged. They are one of humanity’s earliest tools, used since prehistoric times, and are popular among humanoid monsters for hunting and defense.

Nets are only effective against creatures with a solid form. They do not work on wraiths, spectres, ethereal beings, or creatures made of water, like water elementals. While nets cause no physical damage, they can entangle, slow, or delay a target. To ensnare a target, the wielder must succeed on a normal attack roll. If successful, the target must then make a saving throw vs. death ray, potentially with bonuses from the Weapon Special Effects Table. A successful save negates the effect, and the net falls away harmlessly. Failure results in one of several effects depending on the target's size or experience.

An entangled victim may attempt a saving throw each round during the hand-to-hand combat phase to free themselves. Success indicates the net has been removed. If the target has a dagger (but not a longer or non-bladed weapon) in hand when ensnared, they gain a +4 bonus to their saving throw. If successful, the dagger cuts through and destroys the net.

Net and Target Size:

Nets are sized to correspond with the dimensions of their intended targets. Targets larger than the net gain bonuses to their saving throw based on the difference in size. For each size category larger, the target receives a +4 bonus to the save. A natural roll of 1 is always a failure unless the total bonus is +20 or more. The Nets Table provides the appropriate net size for various victim sizes.

Nets Table:

Victim's SizeApproximate HeightNet Size
Very smallUp to 1'2' x 2'
Small1+ to 3'4' x 4'
Medium3+ to 6'6' x 6'
Large6+ to 10'9' x 9'
Very large10+ to 15'12' x 12'
Huge15+ to 20'16' x 16'
Mammoth20+ to 30'25' x 25'

Nets measuring 6' x 6' or smaller can be wielded with one hand. Larger nets require two hands and are subject to penalties associated with two-handed weapons. The wielder cannot use a shield, always loses individual initiative against those not using two-handed weapons, and halflings or small humanoids (like goblins) cannot use nets larger than 6' x 6'.

Magical Nets:

Magical nets are rare and impervious to all but fire or acid. Daggers and other weapons cannot cut through them, and an ensnared victim can only remove the net, not destroy it.

Effects of Ensnarement:

When ensnared, a victim suffers one of the following effects, as determined by the Weapon Special Effects Table:

  • Entangle: The victim cannot move, attack, or cast spells until a successful saving throw.
  • Slow: The victim’s movement and attacks are halved, and they cannot cast spells.
  • Delay: The victim automatically loses initiative in the next round.

Durability and Repair:

A net is easily damaged by edged weapons, claws, or bites. If damaged, it becomes useless unless repaired. Repairing a net requires 1d3 turns of uninterrupted work with rope or cord.

A well-maintained net remains a practical and effective tool for adventurers, offering non-lethal means of control and strategy in combat.
Net (6'x6').name: Net (6'x6')
Net (6'x6').unidentifiedDesc:

  • Delay: The victim automatically loses initiative in the next round.

A well-maintained net remains a practical and effective tool for adventurers, offering non-lethal means of control and strategy in combat.

Neutralize Poison*.description: This spell renders any poison harmless in a creature, container, or on an object. It can revive a creature poisoned within the last 10 rounds but does not heal any other damage.
Neutralize Poison*.name: Neutralize Poison*

Nightwalker Curse.description: The victim has a -4 penalty on all attack rolls and saving throws until the curse is removed. (A dispel evil spell will caned the curse, but a remove curse spell will only work if cast by a 25th or higher level caster.)
Nightwalker Curse.name: Nightwalker Curse

Oath of Aid (PA).description:
A Paladin must assist anyone who requests help, with two exceptions: they are not required to aid evil characters or evil causes, and if they are already on a mission for a higher authority (such as a quest or service to a ruler), they may offer only limited assistance—such as providing shelter, advice, or guidance—along with an explanation for their refusal.

This assistance never involves donating money or items and is only given for a short time through direct service.
Oath of Aid (PA).name: Oath of Aid (PA)

Obliterate*.description:
The reverse of Raise Dead Fully, this spell destroys living creatures the same way the normal version destroys undead.

Effects on Living Creatures:

  • 7 HD or less: The target is immediately slain (no saving throw).
  • 7-12 HD: The target must make a saving throw vs. spells at -4 penalty; failure results in instant death.
  • 12+ HD: The target takes [[/r 6d10 #damage]] damage; a successful saving throw vs. spells reduces damage by half.

Effects on Undead: This spell has the same effect as Cureall would on a living creature:

  • Heals the undead to full hit points, leaving only [[/r 1d6 #damage]] remaining.
  • Can remove afflictions such as blindness, disease, feeblemind, or paralysis.
Obliterate*.name: Obliterate*

Obscure.description:
This spell causes a misty vapor to rise from the ground, forming a large cloud. The cloud's height is 1 foot per caster level, and its diameter is 10 feet per level. For example, a 20th-level caster could create a cloud 20 feet high and 200 feet in diameter.

The cloud blocks vision, though the caster and creatures that can see invisible objects can see dimly through it. Other creatures in the cloud are effectively blind, delayed, and confused by the effect.
Obscure.name: Obscure
Obscure.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Oil, flask.description: Oil is burned in a lantern for light. A flask of oil may also be thrown as a missile weapon or poured out and ignited to delay pursuit.
Oil, flask.name: Oil, flask
Oil, flask.unidentifiedDesc: Oil is burned in a lantern for light. A flask of oil may also be thrown as a missile weapon or poured out and ignited to delay pursuit.

Onyx.description: Onyx is a gemstone characterized by its deep black color, often with subtle white banding or lines. It has a smooth, polished surface with a glossy appearance, making it popular in jewelry and decorative pieces for its sleek and elegant look.
Onyx.name: Onyx
Onyx.unidentifiedDesc: Onyx is a gemstone characterized by its deep black color, often with subtle white banding or lines. It has a smooth, polished surface with a glossy appearance, making it popular in jewelry and decorative pieces for its sleek and elegant look.

Opal.description: Opal is a gemstone known for its captivating play of colors, displaying flashes of blue, green, red, and yellow on a smooth, polished surface. Its iridescence and unique patterns make it highly valued in jewelry, adding a vibrant and mesmerizing effect to any piece.
Opal.name: Opal
Opal.unidentifiedDesc: Opal is a gemstone known for its captivating play of colors, displaying flashes of blue, green, red, and yellow on a smooth, polished surface. Its iridescence and unique patterns make it highly valued in jewelry, adding a vibrant and mesmerizing effect to any piece.

Open Door.description:
The Open Doors roll represents a character's ability to force open stuck doors. At the DM's discretion, it may also be used to determine the character's capability to perform other feats of strength, such as moving obstacles. Characters with high Strength apply their Strength adjustment to the roll.
Each character may attempt this action once per round. However, if the initial attempt fails, any monsters on the other side of the door will not be surprised, as they will have heard the noise.
Open Door.name: Open Door

Open Locks.description: The character can attempt to pick a lock. Success is based on a percentage determined by their level.
Open Locks.name: Open Locks

Open Locks (B).description: A Bard can pick mechanical locks, including doors, chests, and bindings, using the same chance as a Thief of the same level. This requires thieves’ tools and one round per attempt. A failed attempt means the lock remains secured but may be tried again if circumstances allow. Magically sealed locks cannot be opened with this skill.
Open Locks (B).name: Open Locks (B)

Open Mind*.description:
This spell removes mental defenses from a target, making them highly vulnerable to psychic attacks for 1 hour per caster level. The caster must touch the target, requiring a normal attack roll.

Effects:

  • The target becomes highly susceptible to ESP, clairvoyance, clairaudience, crystal ball gazing, and similar magical detection.
  • All saving throws vs. charm, illusion, phantasms, feeblemind, and similar effects suffer a -8 penalty.
  • The victim receives no warning that their mind is exposed.
  • The spell requires a successful touch attack to take effect.
Open Mind*.name: Open Mind*
Open Mind*.spellEffect: Target suffers -8 to saves vs. mental attacks and is vulnerable to mind-affecting spells

Paladin.description:
A Lawful traveling fighter can achieve the title of paladin if they meet specific requirements. Fighters who do not meet these conditions may instead become knights (described separately).

  1. Fealty to a Clerical Order: To become a paladin, the fighter must swear an oath of service to a Lawful clerical order. Only fighters of Name level or higher are eligible. Once accepted, the paladin is bound to serve the order and may be summoned by its leaders at any time to perform tasks that align with the powers of Good.

  2. Detect Evil: A paladin can detect evil, as per the cleric spell, once per round by concentrating. This ability has a range of 120 feet but cannot be used in the same round as an attack.

  3. Cleric Spells: A paladin with a Wisdom score of 13 or higher can cast cleric spells as if they were a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 17th level, the paladin can cast spells as a 5th-level cleric. Fighters with Wisdom scores of 12 or less can still become paladins but cannot cast spells. Paladins are trained in meditation and spellcasting by the clerics of their order, who provide this service without accepting compensation.

  4. Turn Undead: Paladins can turn undead with the same ability as a cleric of one-third their actual level, rounded down. For example:

    • At 9th level, the paladin turns undead as a 3rd-level cleric.
    • At 16th or 17th level, the paladin turns undead as a 5th-level cleric.

  5. Hireling Limit: The paladin can be accompanied by a number of hirelings equal to or less than their effective clerical level. For example, a paladin with the abilities of a 5th-level cleric may travel with up to five hirelings.

  6. Assisting Others: A paladin must provide aid to anyone who requests it, except in the following cases:

    • The paladin is not obligated to assist evil individuals or support evil goals.
    • If engaged in a mission for a higher authority (such as a quest or serving a noble), the paladin may offer limited help, such as advice or temporary shelter, and must explain their inability to provide further assistance. Aid is limited to services and does not include monetary or material donations.

Paladin Turn Undead Table

Undead9-1112-1415-1718-2021-2324-2627-3233-36
SkeletonTDDDDDDD+
ZombieTTDDDDDD
Ghoul7TTDDDDD
Wight97TTDDDD
Wraith1197TTDDD
Mummy--1197TTDD
Spectre----1197TTD
Vampire------1197TT
Phantom--------1197T
Haunt----------1197
Spirit------------119
Nightshade--------------11
Lich----------------
Special----------------

Legend:

  • 7, 9, 11: Roll 2d6 and meet or exceed this number to turn undead.
  • T: Automatically turn undead.
  • D: Automatically destroy undead.
  • D+: Automatically destroy [[/r 3d6 #Hit Dice]] Hit Dice of undead.
Paladin.name: Paladin

Paralysis.description: Any creature hit by an attack must make a saving throw against paralysis or become paralyzed for a duration determined by rolling [[/r 2d4 #Paralyzed for this many turns.]] turns. This paralysis can be cured through magical means or will eventually wear off on its own.
Paralysis.name: Paralysis

Paralyzed.description:
Various types of spells and monster attacks can paralyze, or "freeze," a character. If a character is hit by a paralyzing attack and fails a saving throw vs. paralysis, the character is immobilized and unable to do anything. The character is not dead, and a character cannot die from mere paralysis.

A paralyzed character remains awake and aware of what is happening around him but cannot do anything that requires movement (including speaking, spellcasting, and so forth) until the paralysis ends.

Hand-to-hand attacks on a paralyzed character automatically hit, but an edged-weapon attack will not automatically kill a paralyzed character as it would a sleeping character. Ranged attacks are made against the victim as if he were AC 9.

Paralysis itself has no permanent effects of any kind. It lasts for [[/r 2d4 #Turns]] (unless a different number is given in the monster or spell description). The cleric spell cure light wounds can be used to remove the paralysis but will not cure any damage when used for this purpose.
Paralyzed.name: Paralyzed

Parry.description: This maneuver allows a character to focus on blocking incoming attacks for the entire combat round instead of making an attack roll. By doing so, they impose a -4 penalty on all melee and thrown weapon attacks made against them (but not missile weapon attacks). This option is accessible to certain classes starting at specific levels, as detailed in their experience tables.
Parry.name: Parry

Pass Plant.description:
This spell allows the druid to teleport between two trees of the same type. The trees must be large enough to enclose the druid. Upon casting, the druid can step into one tree and immediately step out of another within range.

Teleportation Range by Tree Type:

Tree TypeRange
Oak600 yards
Ash, Elm, Linden, Yew360 yards
Evergreen trees300 yards
Other trees240 yards
Pass Plant.name: Pass Plant

Passwall.description:
This spell creates a hole 5' in diameter and 10' deep in solid rock or stone only. The hole may be oriented horizontally or vertically.

End of Duration: When the spell ends, the stone reappears. Any creature still in the hole at that time must make a saving throw vs. turn to stone. On a success, the creature is ejected from the nearest end of the tunnel; on a failure, the creature is trapped and killed.
Passwall.name: Passwall

Pearl.description: Pearl is a gemstone with a smooth, round surface and a lustrous, iridescent sheen. It reflects soft colors like white, pink, and silver, highlighting its elegant and natural beauty. Pearls are highly valued in jewelry for their classic and radiant appearance.
Pearl.name: Pearl
Pearl.unidentifiedDesc: Pearl is a gemstone with a smooth, round surface and a lustrous, iridescent sheen. It reflects soft colors like white, pink, and silver, highlighting its elegant and natural beauty. Pearls are highly valued in jewelry for their classic and radiant appearance.

Pellets +1.description:
Ammunition for a sling. These sling stones/pellets are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Pellets +1.name: Pellets +1

Pellets +2.description:
Ammunition for a sling. These sling stones/pellets are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Pellets +2.name: Pellets +2

Pellets +3.description:
Ammunition for a sling. These sling stones/pellets are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Pellets +3.name: Pellets +3

Pellets +4.description:
Ammunition for a sling. These sling stones/pellets are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Pellets +4.name: Pellets +4

Pellets +5.description:
Ammunition for a sling. These sling stones/pellets are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Pellets +5.name: Pellets +5

Permanence.description:
This spell allows the caster to make one other magic-user spell of 7th level or lower permanent. However, this spell cannot be used on:

  • Spells with an instantaneous or permanent duration (e.g., dispel magic, fireball, lightning bolt).
  • Any clerical spells.
  • Any 8th or 9th level magic-user spells.

Rules & Restrictions:

  • The DM may decide that certain spell combinations are unbalanced and disallow them.
  • Dispel Magic cast by the original caster or a higher-level caster can remove the permanence effect (normal chances for success apply).
  • Items can only have one permanent spell, except weapons (see below).
  • Creatures can only have two permanent spells. Attempting a third will automatically fail.
  • Weapons can have up to five permanent spells, but each beyond the first has a 25% chance of failure. If a failure occurs, the weapon is completely destroyed.

Common Uses of Permanence:

On Creatures:

  • Detect Magic
  • Protection from Evil
  • Read Languages
  • Read Magic
  • Detect Invisible
  • Fly

On Areas:

  • Light
  • Phantasmal Force
  • Confusion
  • Cloudkill

Magical Items & Permanence:

A permanence spell does not enchant objects; it only binds a spell to an object, making it more fragile than a true enchanted item. A magic-user does not need Permanence to create permanent magical items.
Permanence.name: Permanence
Permanence.spellEffect: Causes one magical effect to become permanent

Persuasion.description: The Persuasion skill allows a character to influence others through convincing arguments, charm, or logical reasoning. It is used to sway opinions, negotiate peace, or convince someone to take a particular course of action. Successful Persuasion can resolve conflicts, gain allies, or secure valuable information.
Persuasion.name: Persuasion

Phantasmal Force.description:
This spell creates an illusion that affects everything within the specified area. The illusion can be of anything the caster has seen before. If the caster creates something they have not seen, targets receive a bonus to their saving throws to disbelieve the illusion.

Non-attacking illusions disappear when touched. If the illusion mimics an attack (like a magic missile or a collapsing wall), the target may save vs. spells to negate its effects. The illusionary creature has AC 9 and disappears when struck.

The phantasmal force persists as long as the caster maintains concentration. If the caster moves, is damaged, or fails a saving throw, concentration is lost and the illusion vanishes. The spell causes no real damage. Those "killed" by it merely fall unconscious for [[/r 1d4 #turns]] turns, and any effects like "turning to stone" result in temporary paralysis.
Phantasmal Force.name: Phantasmal Force

Pick Pockets.description: The character can attempt to pick pockets or take small items from people without being noticed.
Pick Pockets.name: Pick Pockets

Pike +1.description: A pike is an extremely long spear, 7’ to 15’ long. It can only be wielded using two hands. See polearm rules for special usage.
Pike +1.name: Pike +1
Pike +1.unidentifiedDesc: A pike is an extremely long spear, 7’ to 15’ long. It can only be wielded using two hands. See polearm rules for special usage.

Pike@UV2uwnF90kcSTHnz.description: A pike is an extremely long spear, 7’ to 15’ long. It can only be wielded using two hands. See polearm rules for special usage.
Pike@UV2uwnF90kcSTHnz.name: Pike
Pike@UV2uwnF90kcSTHnz.unidentifiedDesc: A pike is an extremely long spear, 7’ to 15’ long. It can only be wielded using two hands. See polearm rules for special usage.

Piloting (choose type).description: This skill represents the ability to control and maneuver a specific type of vehicle, such as a ship, airship, or magical conveyance. The chosen type must be specified when the skill is selected. Piloting involves steering, navigating obstacles, and managing the vehicle in various conditions, such as weather or combat situations.
Piloting (choose type).name: Piloting (choose type)

Planar Geography.description: This skill provides the character with a general knowledge of the Prime, inner, outer, Astral, and Ethereal Planes. The skill includes knowledge of techniques for traveling between these planes, as well as common inhabitants and natural phenomena found within these planes. Characters skilled in Planar Geography are familiar with the traits of these planes, such as time, gravity, and elemental influences.
Planar Geography.name: Planar Geography

Plant Door.description:
This spell allows the druid to pass freely through any plant growth or barrier, no matter how dense. Trees, vines, and other plants will bend or magically open to create a passage for the druid, who can carry equipment while moving through but cannot bring other creatures with them.

The druid may also hide inside a large tree after casting this spell, though they cannot see what is happening outside the tree while within.
Plant Door.name: Plant Door
Plant Door.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Plate Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of large metal plates—the largest being the breastplate—linked together with chain mail. Plate mail gives a character an armor class of 3. It is the best armor that can be bought second hand or looted, since suit armor must be custom made.
Plate Mail.name: Plate Mail
Plate Mail.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of large metal plates—the largest being the breastplate—linked together with chain mail. Plate mail gives a character an armor class of 3. It is the best armor that can be bought second hand or looted, since suit armor must be custom made.

Plate Mail +1.description:
This is a magic suit of armor primarily composed of large metal plates—the largest being the breastplate—linked together with chain mail. Plate mail gives a character an armor class of 3. It is the best armor that can be bought second hand or looted, since suit armor must be custom made.

Magic armor weighs half that of its nonmagic counterpart.
Plate Mail +1.name: Plate Mail +1
Plate Mail +1.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of large metal plates—the largest being the breastplate—linked together with chain mail. Plate mail gives a character an armor class of 3. It is the best armor that can be bought second hand or looted, since suit armor must be custom made.

Polearm.description: This weapon covers all other polearm varieties that are not individually listed in the weapons list. Some of these weapons include the bardiche, bill, glaive, partizan, ranseur, spetum and voulge. See rules for specials.
Polearm.name: Polearm
Polearm.unidentifiedDesc: This weapon covers all other polearm varieties that are not individually listed in the weapons list. Some of these weapons include the bardiche, bill, glaive, partizan, ranseur, spetum and voulge. See rules for specials.

Poleaxe@bdF776Lh1mZnFNEa.description: A poleaxe consists of an axe blade (usually single sided, but occasionally double sided) with a 6’ to 8' long shaft. It is wielded in both hands like a large two-handed axe.
Poleaxe@bdF776Lh1mZnFNEa.name: Poleaxe
Poleaxe@bdF776Lh1mZnFNEa.unidentifiedDesc: A poleaxe consists of an axe blade (usually single sided, but occasionally double sided) with a 6’ to 8' long shaft. It is wielded in both hands like a large two-handed axe.

Polymorph Any Object.description:
This spell functions similarly to the Polymorph Others spell but extends its effects to objects as well as creatures. The spell transforms one target into another form, following the rules outlined below.

Target Limitations:

  • Objects: If the object is part of a larger whole (e.g., a wall section), the spell affects a volume of up to 10' × 10' × 10'.
  • Creatures: A creature may attempt a saving throw vs. spells (at a -4 penalty) to resist the effect.
  • Hit Dice Limit: A creature with more than twice the caster’s level in Hit Dice is immune (e.g., a 20th level caster cannot affect a 41+ HD creature).

Duration Based on Transformation:

  • Same Kingdom: If the transformation remains within the same kingdom (e.g., animal to animal), the effect is permanent until dispelled.
  • Adjacent Kingdom: If changing between adjacent kingdoms (e.g., animal → vegetable or vegetable → mineral), the effect lasts 1 hour per caster level ([[/r @actor.details.level*360 #Duration in rounds]]).
  • Distant Kingdom: If changing between distant kingdoms (e.g., animal → mineral), the effect lasts 1 turn per caster level ([[/r @actor.details.level*60 #Duration in rounds]]).

Additional Rules & Notes:

  • Newly created creatures are not automatically friendly to the caster.
  • Polymorph does not affect age or hit points—these remain unchanged.
  • The spell can be reversed via a Dispel Magic spell (normal chances of success apply).
  • For additional polymorphing rules, refer to Polymorph Self and Polymorph Others.
Polymorph Any Object.name: Polymorph Any Object
Polymorph Any Object.spellEffect: Changes form of one object or creature

Polymorph Other.description:
This spell transforms the target into another living creature, provided the new form has no more than twice as many Hit Dice as the original. The spell fails if this condition is not met.

Effects of Transformation: The target's hit points remain unchanged, but they gain all special abilities, tendencies, and behaviors of the new form. For example, a hobgoblin transformed into a mule would think and act as a mule.

This spell cannot create an exact duplicate of a specific individual but only changes the creature’s type or race. For instance, transforming into a “human” does not grant levels or special skills beyond a basic human form.

Saving Throw: The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to avoid transformation. The spell lasts until dispelled or the creature dies.
Polymorph Other.name: Polymorph Other

Polymorph Self.description:
This spell allows the caster to take on the physical form of another living creature, provided the new form’s Hit Dice are equal to or less than the caster's. If this condition is not met, the spell fails.

Physical Abilities: The caster retains their own AC, hit points, attack rolls, and saving throws, and does not gain special abilities (like a ghoul's paralysis) or immunities of the new form. However, they gain the physical capabilities of the form. For example, a caster polymorphed into a frost giant would gain giant strength and the ability to throw boulders, but not cold immunity. A dragon form would allow flight but not breath attacks or spellcasting.

Limitations: The caster cannot cast spells while polymorphed. The spell lasts for 6 turns + 1 turn per caster level, until dispelled, or until the caster is killed. This spell cannot be used to assume the form of a specific individual.
Polymorph Self.name: Polymorph Self
Polymorph Self.spellDuration: 6 turns + 1 turn per level of the caster

Possessed.description: When a creature is possessed, its body is under the control of an outside force, and it will act on that force's behalf. The possessed body is used to interact with the physical world, while the controlling force remains separate. The possessed body will typically be used to carry out the goals of the controlling force, which may include attacking others.
Possessed.name: Possessed

Potion of Agility.description: This potion increases the drinker's Dexterity score to 18 for 7-12 turns [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Agility duration]]. All applicable Dexterity bonuses, such as improved Armor Class and ranged attack bonuses, are applied during this time. The potion takes effect immediately upon consumption.
Potion of Agility.name: Potion of Agility
Potion of Agility.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Animal Control.description: Upon consuming this potion, the user can control up to [[/r 3d6 #Potion of Animal Control Hit Dice worth of animals]] Hit Dice worth of animals (normal or giant, but not fantastic or magical) for the potion’s duration. Affected animals will be afraid and leave the area when the control ends. The user must see the animals to control them, and cannot force them to harm themselves. The controlled creatures can make a saving throw vs. spells to resist. The potion's effect lasts for [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Animal Control duration]] 7-12 turns.
Potion of Animal Control.name: Potion of Animal Control
Potion of Animal Control.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Antidote.description:
This potion grants immunity to certain poisons and provides a +2 bonus to saving throws against poison. The weakest version protects against poisons from creatures with 3 Hit Dice or less, while stronger antidotes counter poisons from more powerful creatures. Poisons avoided during the potion's duration have no effect after it ends.

Roll [[/br 1d10]] to determine which poisons it counters.

1-4: Protects against poisons from creatures of 3 Hit Dice or less.
5-7: Protects against poisons from creatures of 7 Hit Dice or less.
8-9: Protects against poisons from creatures of 15 Hit Dice or less.
10: Protects against all types of poison.
The effect lasts for one hour after consumption.
Potion of Antidote.name: Potion of Antidote
Potion of Antidote.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Blending.description: This potion allows the drinker to blend into their surroundings, making them nearly impossible to detect visually. Unlike a potion of invisibility, normal actions do not dispel the effect. The potion lasts for 7-12 turns [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Blending duration]], with the exact duration known only to the DM.
Potion of Blending.name: Potion of Blending
Potion of Blending.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Bug Repellent.description: This potion repels all types of bugs, including arachnids (spiders, ticks, scorpions), insects (ants, beetles, flies), and chilopods (centipedes, millipedes). Normal bugs cannot touch the user after drinking the potion. Giant-sized bugs will ignore the user unless they succeed on a saving throw vs. spells. If the save succeeds, the potion has no effect on the giant bug. The potion also grants a +4 bonus to any saving throws against magically summoned or controlled bugs. The potion lasts for [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Bug Repellent duration]] turns.
Potion of Bug Repellent.name: Potion of Bug Repellent
Potion of Bug Repellent.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Flying.description:
The user may fly at up to 120' per round without tiring (as the effects of the magic-user spell).

This potion is contained in a delicate vial, its contents swirling with an enigmatic shimmer that defies description. A subtle, elusive fragrance wafts from it, hinting at possibilities beyond the ordinary.
Potion of Flying.name: Potion of Flying
Potion of Flying.unidentifiedDesc: This potion is contained in a delicate vial, its contents swirling with an enigmatic shimmer that defies description. A subtle, elusive fragrance wafts from it, hinting at possibilities beyond the ordinary.

Potion of Giant Strength.description:
Damage Increase: All weapon attacks inflict double normal damage.

Boulder Throwing: The user can throw small boulders with a range of 60/130/200 feet, dealing 3d6 points of damage per hit.

Compatibility Restriction: The potion does not work if the user is already benefiting from a strength-adjusting magical item (e.g., gauntlets of ogre power).

The potion swirls with a frosty blue hue, tiny crystalline flecks catching the light as it moves. Its scent is sharp and bracing, like icy mountain air, with an underlying metallic tang. On the tongue, it delivers a bitter chill and leaves a faint, numbing sensation, as if touched by frost.
Potion of Giant Strength.gmNotes:
A potion of Giant Strength. Lasts 1d6+1 turns.
Damage Increase: All weapon attacks inflict double normal damage.
Boulder Throwing: The user can throw small boulders with a range of 60/130/200 feet, dealing 3d6 points of damage per hit.
Compatibility Restriction: The potion does not work if the user is already benefiting from a strength-adjusting magical item (e.g., gauntlets of ogre power).
Potion of Giant Strength.name: Potion of Giant Strength
Potion of Giant Strength.unidentifiedDesc: The potion swirls with a frosty blue hue, tiny crystalline flecks catching the light as it moves. Its scent is sharp and bracing, like icy mountain air, with an underlying metallic tang. On the tongue, it delivers a bitter chill and leaves a faint, numbing sensation, as if touched by frost.

Potion of Healing.description: This potion restores 2-7 hit points [[/r 1d6+1 #Potion of Healing hit points restored.]] or cures paralysis for a single creature. Its effects take place immediately upon consumption.
Potion of Healing.name: Potion of Healing
Potion of Healing.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Invisibility.description: This potion grants the effects of the invisibility spell. It makes the drinker and their carried items invisible. Any item will become visible again once it leaves the drinker’s possession. The potion may be consumed in up to six sips, each providing invisibility for one turn.
Potion of Invisibility.name: Potion of Invisibility
Potion of Invisibility.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Invulnerability.description: This potion grants a +2 bonus to the user's Armor Class and saving throws for the duration of the effect. However, if consumed more than once in a week, it only causes sickness and has no additional effect. The duration is [[/br 1d6+6 #Potion of Invulnerability duration]] turns.
Potion of Invulnerability.name: Potion of Invulnerability
Potion of Invulnerability.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Potion of Neutralize Poison.description: This potion contains a shimmering green liquid that neutralizes any poison affecting the drinker. It is effective against poisons that have been ingested, inhaled, or injected, but must be consumed within one hour of exposure to work. The drinker is immediately cured of all poison effects upon consumption.
Potion of Neutralize Poison.name: Potion of Neutralize Poison
Potion of Neutralize Poison.unidentifiedDesc: The flask or vial holds a swirling and mysterious concoction inside.

Pouch, Belt.description: A small pouch made of leather or cloth, typically worn on a belt. It can hold up to 50 coins and is used to carry small valuables or other small items.
Pouch, Belt.name: Pouch, Belt
Pouch, Belt.unidentifiedDesc: A small pouch made of leather or cloth, typically worn on a belt. It can hold up to 50 coins and is used to carry small valuables or other small items.

Power Word Blind.description:
With this spell, the caster may blind one victim within 120'. The effect is automatic—no saving throw is allowed. The duration of the blindness depends on the victim's current hit points.

Effect Based on Hit Points:

  • 1-40 HP: Blinded for [[/r 1d4 #Days Blinded]] days.
  • 41-80 HP: Blinded for [[/r 2d4 #Hours Blinded]] hours.
  • 81+ HP: The spell has no effect.

Blinded Condition:

  • Blinded creatures suffer a -4 penalty to all saving throws.
  • Blinded creatures also suffer a +4 penalty to their armor class.

Removing the Blindness:

  • A Cure Blindness or Cureall spell can remove the effect, but only if cast by a cleric whose level is equal to or higher than the caster of Power Word Blind.
Power Word Blind.name: Power Word Blind
Power Word Blind.spellEffect: Blinds 1 creature with 80 HP or less

Power Word Kill.description:
This spell allows the caster to instantly kill or stun one or more creatures within 120 feet, with no saving throw unless stated otherwise.

Effects:

  • Single Target: If the target has 1-60 HP, it is instantly slain (no saving throw).
  • If the target has 61-100 HP, it is stunned for [[/r 1d4 #Turns Stunned]] (as Power Word Stun).
  • No creature with 101+ HP is affected.
  • Multiple Targets: Instead of a single victim, the caster may choose to slay up to five creatures if each has 20 HP or less (no saving throw).
  • Exception: A magic-user or any creature capable of casting magic-user spells may attempt a saving throw vs. spells at -4 penalty to resist the effect.
Power Word Kill.name: Power Word Kill
Power Word Kill.spellEffect: Slays or stuns one or more creatures

Power Word Stun.description:
This spell stuns a single creature within 120' with no saving throw.

Effect:

  • If the target has 1-35 hit points, it is stunned for [[/r 2d6 #Stunned for this many turns.]] turns.
  • If the target has 36-70 hit points, it is stunned for [[/r 1d6 #Stunned for this many turns.]] turns.
  • Creatures with 71 or more hit points are unaffected.
Power Word Stun.name: Power Word Stun
Power Word Stun.spellEffect: Stuns 1 creature of 70 hp or less

Predict Weather.description: This spell enables the druid to learn the accurate weather forecast for the next 12 hours within an area of 1 mile in diameter per level of the caster. For example, a 20th-level druid would know the weather within a 20-mile diameter (10-mile radius). This spell does not allow the caster to control the weather, merely to predict it.
Predict Weather.name: Predict Weather

Prismatic Wall.description:
This spell creates a multi-layered magical barrier composed of seven colors, each with unique properties and defenses.

Properties:

  • The wall is 2 inches thick, with 1/8-inch gaps between colors.

  • The effect must be either:

    • A 10' radius sphere centered on the caster.
    • A 500 square foot flat surface (vertical or horizontal).
  • The wall is immovable (even by a wish).
  • The caster may pass through freely with any chosen items.
  • Other creatures or objects making contact suffer effects from each layer they pass through.
  • Extends into the Ethereal Plane, preventing planar travel through it.

Bypassing the Wall:

  • A wish spell or rod of cancellation removes only the three outermost layers.
  • Each layer must be removed in order with the appropriate spell.

Prismatic Wall Layers & Effects:

Color

Effect

Spell to Remove

Red

Blocks all magical missiles; inflicts [[/r 12 #Fire Damage]].

Any magical cold

Orange

Blocks all non-magical missiles; inflicts [[/r 24 #Lightning Damage]].

Any magical lightning

Yellow

Blocks all breath weapons; inflicts [[/r 48 #Acid Damage]].

Magic missile spell

Green

Blocks all detection spells; save vs. poison or die if touched.

Passwall spell

Blue

Blocks all poisons, gases, and gaze attacks; save vs. petrification or be turned to stone.

Disintegrate spell

Indigo

Blocks all matter; save vs. spells or be gated to a random outer plane (50% chance of being lost forever).

Dispel magic spell

Violet

Blocks all magic; save vs. wands or be struck unconscious and insane (curable only by Cureall or a Wish).

Continual light spell

Special Interactions:

  • Anti-Magic Shell: Prevents passage but does not dispel the wall.
  • Planar Travel: The wall extends into adjacent planes, preventing teleportation through it.
  • Physical Attacks: The wall is indestructible.
Prismatic Wall.name: Prismatic Wall

Produce Fire.description:
This spell creates a small flame in the caster's hand. The flame sheds light like a torch and does not harm the caster. It can ignite combustible materials like lanterns, torches, or oil without damaging the magical flame itself.

The caster can make the flame disappear and reappear at will, once per round. The flame can be thrown or dropped up to 30 feet away, but it disappears one round after leaving the caster's hand. Any fire it ignites continues burning.
Produce Fire.name: Produce Fire

Profession (choose type).description: The character is accomplished at one type of non-labor profession, such as politics, cooking, estate management, horse grooming, or scribing. With a successful skill roll, the character can earn a living through this profession and provide expert commentary on related subjects. The player must specify the exact profession the character is skilled in, and a character may have multiple Profession skills to represent expertise in different fields.
Profession (choose type).name: Profession (choose type)

Projected Image.description:
This spell creates a perfect illusionary duplicate of the caster at any location within 240'. The projected image mimics the caster’s movements and actions precisely and remains active without requiring concentration.

Effects:

  • The image is visually indistinguishable from the caster, except by touch.
  • The caster can cast spells from the image’s location; however, the caster must still be able to see the target of the spell.
  • The image is immune to missile attacks and spells—they pass through harmlessly.
  • If the image is touched or struck in melee combat, it immediately vanishes.
Projected Image.name: Projected Image

Prone.description:
A character who has fallen (e.g., been knocked over in combat) is easy to hit: Attackers receive a +4 bonus to their attack rolls when attacking a fallen foe.

A fallen foe also has a -4 penalty to all saving throws and a -2 penalty to attack rolls while on the ground.

A character on the ground takes one round of movement to stand up; also, for the rest of the round after he has stood up, the character still suffers the penalties of a fallen character.
Prone.name: Prone

Protected.description:
This effect creates an invisible magical barrier surrounding the spell target's body, less than an inch away.

In addition, enchanted creatures cannot touch the spell target. (An enchanted creature is one that cannot be harmed by normal weapons and can only be affected by magical weapons. A creature that can only be harmed by silver weapons, such as a werewolf, is not considered enchanted.

Creatures that are magically summoned or controlled, like a charmed character, are also classified as enchanted.) The barrier completely protects the spell target from all melee or hand- to - hand attacks from these creatures, although it does not block attacks from missile weapons.Enchanted creatures using missile weapons still suffer the - 1 attack penalty but can hit the spell target.

This effect does not block magic missile spells used by magic - users.

If the spell target attacks an enchanted creature while this effect is active, the barrier's properties change slightly. Enchanted creatures can then touch the spell target, but they still suffer the attack roll penalty.The attack penalty and the spell target's saving throw bonus remain until the effect ends.
Protected.name: Protected

Protection from Evil.description:
This spell creates an invisible magical barrier around the caster, extending less than an inch away from their body. It grants a +1 bonus to all saving throws and imposes a -1 penalty to attack rolls made against the caster. The spell also protects the caster from attacks by enchanted creatures in melee combat.

Enchanted Creatures: Creatures that cannot be harmed by non-magical weapons, creatures that can only be hit by magical weapons, or creatures that are magically summoned or controlled (such as a charmed creature). This does not include creatures that require silver weapons, like werewolves.

Enchanted creatures are unable to touch the caster with melee attacks but can still use missile weapons (at a -1 penalty to attack rolls). The barrier does not affect magic missile spells. If the caster attacks any creature in melee, the spell still provides the attack roll penalty and saving throw bonus but no longer prevents contact by enchanted creatures.
Protection from Evil.name: Protection from Evil

Protection from Evil (C).description:
This spell creates and invisible magical barrier all around the caster's body (less than an inch away). Here’s the revised text with all references to "cleric" changed to "caster":

While the spell is in effect, characters and monsters attacking the caster suffer a -1 penalty to their attack rolls, and the caster gains a +1 bonus to all saving throws.

Additionally, enchanted creatures are unable to touch the caster! (An enchanted creature is one that normal weapons cannot affect, only magical weapons can hit. A creature that can only be hit by a silver weapon—like a werewolf—is not considered enchanted. Any creature that is magically summoned or controlled, such as a charmed character, is also considered enchanted.) This barrier completely protects the caster from all melee or hand-to-hand attacks from such creatures; however, it does not prevent attacks from missile weapons. Enchanted creatures using missile weapons still suffer the -1 penalty to attack rolls but can still hit the caster.

This spell does not affect a magic missile spell used by magic-users.

If the caster attacks an enchanted creature during the spell's duration, the spell’s effect changes slightly. Enchanted creatures are then able to touch the caster, but still suffer the attack roll penalty; the penalty and the caster's saving throw adjustments remain until the spell's duration ends.
Protection from Evil (C).name: Protection from Evil (C)

Protection from Evil 10' Radius.description:
This spell creates an invisible magical barrier around the caster, extending in a 10' radius (20' diameter). This barrier protects against attacks from creatures with an alignment different from the caster's.

Effects on Allies: Each creature within the barrier gains a +1 bonus to all saving throws, while attacks against them suffer a -1 penalty on the attack roll.

Enchanted Creatures: Enchanted creatures (e.g., magically summoned or controlled creatures) cannot engage in melee with anyone within the barrier. However, if someone within the barrier attacks an enchanted creature, this melee protection ends for that creature, though the +1 save bonus and -1 attack penalty remain in effect.

Missile and Magical Attacks: Missile and magical attacks from outside the barrier can target those inside, suffering only the -1 attack penalty.
Protection from Evil 10' Radius.name: Protection from Evil 10' Radius

Protection from Evil 10' Radius (C).description:
This spell creates an invisible barrier around the caster, extending 10' in all directions. It grants each creature within the barrier a +1 bonus to all saving throws, while attacks against those inside suffer a -1 penalty on attack rolls.

Effect: Enchanted creatures (such as magically summoned or controlled beings) cannot engage in melee with anyone inside the barrier. However, if a protected creature attacks an enchanted one, the barrier no longer prevents melee attacks, though saving throw bonuses and attack roll penalties remain active.

Missile and magical attacks from outside the barrier still suffer the -1 attack penalty but are otherwise unaffected.
Protection from Evil 10' Radius (C).name: Protection from Evil 10' Radius (C)

Protection from Lightning.description:
This spell grants the recipient immunity to a specified amount of electrical damage. The protection amount depends on the druid's experience level: for each level, one die (1d6) of lightning damage is negated. The protected amount is subtracted from the dice of damage that would otherwise be dealt.

Example: A 20th-level druid protected by this spell negates up to 20d6 lightning damage. This would allow the druid to absorb two full *Call Lightning* attacks (8d6 each), plus half of a third attack (8 + 8 + 4 = 20). Any damage beyond this would be taken as normal, and the recipient still makes any applicable saving throws.
Protection from Lightning.name: Protection from Lightning
Protection from Lightning.spellDuration: 1 turn per level of the caster

Protection from Normal Missiles.description:
This spell grants the recipient complete protection from all small, nonmagical missiles, such as arrows, quarrels, and thrown spears. All such missile attacks automatically miss the target.

Limitations: Large missiles (like catapult stones) and magical missiles (like magic arrows) are unaffected by this spell and can still hit the recipient.

The spell can be cast on any one creature within a range of 30'.
Protection from Normal Missiles.name: Protection from Normal Missiles

Protection from Poison.description:
This spell grants the recipient complete immunity to all poisons for the spell’s duration, including poison from gas traps and *Cloudkill* spells. This protection also extends to any items carried by the recipient, protecting them against poison effects (e.g., a spirit’s poisonous aura).

Bonus to Saving Throws: The recipient also gains a +4 bonus on saving throws against poisonous breath weapons, such as a green dragon’s breath. This bonus does not apply to non-poisonous breath effects, like a gorgon’s petrifying breath.
Protection from Poison.name: Protection from Poison
Protection from Poison.spellDuration: One turn per level of the caster
Protection from Poison.spellEffect: Gives one creature immunity to all poison

Purify Food and Water.description: This spell makes spoiled or poisoned food and water safe for consumption. It can purify one ration of preserved food (either iron or standard rations), six waterskins of water, or enough regular food to feed twelve people. If cast on mud, the spell causes the dirt to settle, leaving behind a pool of pure, clear water. The spell does not affect any living creatures.
Purify Food and Water.name: Purify Food and Water

Quarrels.description: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.
Quarrels.name: Quarrels

Quarrels (silver).description: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.
Quarrels (silver).name: Quarrels (silver)

Quarrels +1.description:
Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Quarrels +1.name: Quarrels +1
Quarrels +1.unidentifiedDesc: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.

Quarrels +2.description:
Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Quarrels +2.name: Quarrels +2
Quarrels +2.unidentifiedDesc: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.

Quarrels +3.description:
Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Quarrels +3.name: Quarrels +3
Quarrels +3.unidentifiedDesc: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.

Quarrels +4.description:
Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Quarrels +4.name: Quarrels +4
Quarrels +4.unidentifiedDesc: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.

Quarrels +5.description:
Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt. These arrows are magical and provide a to-hit and damage bonus.

Important: As a class A weapon, these missiles become nonmagical once used, even if the attack roll indicated a miss.
Quarrels +5.name: Quarrels +5
Quarrels +5.unidentifiedDesc: Ammunition for a crossbow. Sometimes called a bolt.

Quartz.description: Quartz is a clear, transparent gemstone with a crystalline structure. It often appears glass-like, reflecting light with a sparkling brilliance. Its purity and clarity make it a popular choice for jewelry and decorative pieces. There are several different types and colors of quartz.
Quartz.name: Quartz
Quartz.unidentifiedDesc: Quartz is a clear, transparent gemstone with a crystalline structure. It often appears glass-like, reflecting light with a sparkling brilliance. Its purity and clarity make it a popular choice for jewelry and decorative pieces. There are several different types and colors of quartz.

Quest*.description:
This spell compels the target to undertake a specific task or quest as commanded by the caster. The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to resist; if successful, the spell has no effect.

Typical Tasks: The task might include slaying a particular monster, rescuing a prisoner, retrieving a magical item, or embarking on a pilgrimage. If the task is impossible or suicidal, the spell fails automatically.

Duration: The spell remains in effect until the specified task is completed. This spell compels the target to fulfill the task but does not compel them to do so willingly. Once completed, the target may hold a grudge against the caster, potentially seeking revenge depending on the circumstances of the quest.
