Curse: A target who refuses to undertake the quest is cursed until they resume the task. The nature of this curse is determined by the GM and may be twice the usual strength of a standard curse.
Quest*.name: Quest*
Quest*.spellEffect: Compels one creature to perform a task

Quick Draw.description: The Quick Draw skill allows a character to swiftly draw and ready a weapon or item, such as a sword or potion, even in stressful situations like combat. This skill can grant an advantage in initiative or allow an immediate action that would normally take longer to perform.
Quick Draw.name: Quick Draw

Quill Pen.description: A large feather sharpened into a writing point.
Quill Pen.name: Quill Pen
Quill Pen.unidentifiedDesc: A large feather sharpened into a writing point.

Quiver.description: This is a container for arrows or quarrels; it is usually made of leather. A lesser-quality quiver is included in the basic cost of a load of ammunition, as noted on the Ammunition Table.
Quiver.name: Quiver
Quiver.unidentifiedDesc: This is a container for arrows or quarrels; it is usually made of leather. A lesser-quality quiver is included in the basic cost of a load of ammunition, as noted on the Ammunition Table.

Raise Dead Fully*.description:
This spell is an improved version of Raise Dead, capable of restoring any living creature—not just humans and demihumans—to life.

Effects on Humans & Demihumans:

  • The recipient awakens immediately, fully healed.
  • They can fight, use abilities, and cast spells without penalty.
  • Any afflictions they had at death (curses, diseases, etc.) remain.

Effects on Other Creatures: All restrictions from Raise Dead apply, including time limits and required rest.

Time Limit: A 17th-level cleric can raise a body that has been dead for up to 4 months. For each level beyond 17th, the limit increases by 4 months.

  • 17th level: 4 months
  • 18th level: 8 months
  • 19th level: 12 months
  • +4 months per level beyond 17th

Effects on Undead: If cast on an undead creature, the spell has the following results:

  • 7 HD or less: The undead is immediately destroyed (no saving throw).
  • 7-12 HD: The undead must make a saving throw vs. spells at -4 penalty; failure results in destruction.
  • 12+ HD: The undead takes [[/r 6d10 #damage]] damage; a saving throw vs. spells reduces the damage by half.
Raise Dead Fully*.name: Raise Dead Fully*

Raise Dead*.description:
This spell allows the cleric to raise any human, dwarf, halfling, or elf from the dead. The body must be present, and any missing parts will cause corresponding disabilities in the raised character.

Effect: An 8th-level cleric can raise a body that has been dead up to four days. Each level above 8th extends this limit by four additional days (e.g., a 10th-level cleric can raise bodies dead for up to twelve days).

The character is raised with 1 hit point and is weakened: unable to fight, cast spells, or move faster than half speed. These penalties last for two weeks of complete bed rest, which cannot be hastened by magical healing.

Undead Effect: When cast on an undead creature within range, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells with a -2 penalty or be destroyed. Vampires that fail the save retreat to their coffins in gaseous form. Against undead creatures stronger than vampires, the spell deals 3d10 damage (saving throw for half).
Raise Dead*.name: Raise Dead*
Raise Dead*.spellEffect: Raises one dead human or demihuman, or damages undead

Rapid Fire.description:
A successful Check enables a character to fire a bow twice instead of once. Each shot is made with a penalty of ‐3 to hit. The first arrow is fired according to which side wins initiative, the second arrow is always fired at the end of the round.

From GAZ13.
Rapid Fire.name: Rapid Fire

Ration, Iron.description: Preserved food for one person for one week. Includes items like dried meat, hardtack, and preserved fruits and vegetables. It lasts up to two months under normal conditions and one week in harsh conditions, such as dungeons.
Ration, Iron.name: Ration, Iron
Ration, Iron.unidentifiedDesc: Preserved food for one person for one week. Includes items like dried meat, hardtack, and preserved fruits and vegetables. It lasts up to two months under normal conditions and one week in harsh conditions, such as dungeons.

Ration, Standard.description: Untreated food sufficient for one person for one week. It is prone to spoilage in damp environments, such as dungeons, and is best for overland travel.
Ration, Standard.name: Ration, Standard
Ration, Standard.unidentifiedDesc: Untreated food sufficient for one person for one week. It is prone to spoilage in damp environments, such as dungeons, and is best for overland travel.

Read Languages (B).description: At 4th level, a Bard can decipher non-magical writings, such as ancient scripts, inscriptions, or coded messages, with an 80% chance of success. This requires one turn of study per passage. A failed attempt means the Bard cannot understand the text until they gain another level. This skill does not allow the Bard to read magical writings or scrolls.
Read Languages (B).name: Read Languages (B)

Read Languages@wNNNgISgsuDtGapt.description: A character with is ability can decipher written languages (including treasure maps and codes) with a base chance of success.
Read Languages@wNNNgISgsuDtGapt.name: Read Languages

Read Languages@ws0ObLFkCK62OpKq.description: This spell allows the caster to read, but not speak, any unknown languages, codes, or symbols—including treasure maps or secret scripts—for the spell’s duration.
Read Languages@ws0ObLFkCK62OpKq.name: Read Languages

Read Magic.description:
This spell allows the caster to read any magical words or runes, such as those found on scrolls or inscribed on items. It does not allow the caster to speak the words, only to read and understand them. A spellcaster cannot understand unfamiliar magical writings without using this spell.

Once a caster reads a scroll or rune with this spell, they can read or speak that magic again without using this spell. All spell books are written in magical words, and only their owners may read them without using this spell.
Read Magic.name: Read Magic

Read Scroll (B).description: A Thief of 10th level or higher can attempt to cast spells from magic-user scrolls. This requires one round of reading, and the scroll is consumed upon use. There is a 10% chance of backfire, which may cause the spell to fail, produce a random effect, or target the wrong creature (DM’s discretion). Thieves cannot use cleric or druid scrolls.
Read Scroll (B).name: Read Scroll (B)

Recorder.description: A woodwind instrument with a whistle mouthpiece, popular in various forms of music.
Recorder.name: Recorder

Reincarnation.description:
This spell allows the caster to return a deceased character to life by magically creating a new body for their life force to inhabit. The spell requires at least a small part of the dead character's body to work.

Effects:

  • The new body may not be the same race as the original. The DM may choose or roll on the provided tables.
  • If reincarnated as a different race, the character loses all racial abilities of the former body and gains those of the new form.
  • If reincarnated as a monster, the monster must be semi-intelligent (at least) and must be able to have the character's original alignment.
  • Class Restrictions: If a non-human character is reincarnated as a human, the DM may allow them to choose a new class. If an elf, dwarf, or halfling is reincarnated into another race, they follow the racial limitations.

Reincarnation Results:

1d8 RollNew Body Type
1Human
2Human
3Human
4Dwarf
5Elf
6Halfling
7Original Race
8Monster (see below)

Monster Reincarnation:

1d6 RollLawfulNeutralChaotic
1Blink DogWhite ApeBugbear
2GnomeBear*Gnoll
3NeanderthalCentaurKobold
4Giant OwlGriffonManticore
5PegasusLizard ManOrc
6TreantPixieTroglodyte

* Any normal bear
Reincarnation.name: Reincarnation

Remove Barrier*.description:
This spell instantly destroys one magical barrier created by a cleric. It can also dispel certain barriers created by a magic-user.

Effects: *Remove Barrier* will destroy a cleric's *Barrier* spell and can also dispel the following magic-user spells:

  • Wall of Ice
  • Wall of Fire
  • Clothform
  • Woodform
  • Wall of Stone

Limitations: This spell does not affect the following spells: *Wall of Iron*, *Stoneform*, *Ironform*, or *Steelform*.
Remove Barrier*.name: Remove Barrier*

Remove Charm*.description:
This spell removes all charm effects within a 20' x 20' x 20' area.

Dispel Effects:

  • Removes all charm person, charm monster, or Mass Charm effects.
  • Also removes any charm effect from magical items.
  • Prevents new charm effects in the area for 1 turn.
Remove Charm*.name: Remove Charm*
Remove Charm*.spellEffect: Removes all charm effects in a 20' x 20' x 20' area

Remove Curse*.description:
This spell removes one curse from a character, item, or area. Some powerful curses, especially on magical items, may only be temporarily lifted by *Remove Curse*, requiring a higher-level *Remove Curse* or a cleric's *Dispel Evil* spell to remove permanently. The DM determines if a curse requires additional magic to remove.

Reverse Spell - Curse: The reverse of this spell, *Curse*, imposes a misfortune or penalty on the target. Curses are limited only by the caster's imagination, but overly powerful curses may backfire on the caster at the DM's discretion. Typical curse effects include a -4 penalty on attack rolls, -2 on saving throws, or a halved prime requisite.

The target may attempt a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the curse.
Remove Curse*.name: Remove Curse*

Remove Curse* (C).description:
This spell removes one curse from a character, item, or area. Some curses, especially those on magical items, may only be lifted temporarily. For permanent removal, a dispel evil spell or a remove curse cast by a higher-level caster may be required (at the DM's discretion).

The reverse of this spell, curse, imposes a penalty or misfortune on the target, with effects limited only by the caster's imagination. If the curse is too powerful, it may rebound on the caster (DM's discretion). Typical curses include a -4 penalty to attack rolls, a -2 penalty to saving throws, halving of a prime requisite, or a -4 penalty on others' reaction rolls. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the curse.
Remove Curse* (C).name: Remove Curse* (C)

Remove Fear*.description:
When the spellcaster casts this spell and then touches any living creature, it will calm the creature and remove any fear. If the creature has been affected by a fear spell or effect that normally does not allow a saving throw, the remove fear spell can still be effective. If the spellcaster uses the spell on someone afflicted by a magical fear effect, the victim gets to make a saving throw vs. spells, with a bonus to the roll equal to the spellcaster's level of experience (up to a maximum bonus of +6). If the saving throw is successful, the victim's fear is dispelled. Regardless of the spellcaster's level or any bonuses, a roll of 1 will always fail.

The reversed form of the spell, cause fear, will make any one creature flee for two turns. The victim may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect. This reversed spell has a range of 120'.
Remove Fear*.name: Remove Fear*

Remove Geas*.description:
This spell removes the effects of an unwanted geas placed on a creature.

Effects:

  • The spell will completely remove a geas and all penalties associated with ignoring it.
  • If the caster is of a lower level than the original geas' caster, there is a chance of failure (5% per level difference).
Remove Geas*.name: Remove Geas*
Remove Geas*.spellEffect: Removes a geas from one creature

Remove Quest*.description:
The reversed form of the quest spell, *Remove Quest* dispels an unwanted quest or removes a quest-related curse. The base chance of successfully removing the quest is 50%, modified by ±5% for each level difference between the caster of *Remove Quest* and the original caster of the quest.

For example, an 11th-level cleric attempting to remove a quest imposed by a 13th-level caster has a 40% chance of success, while a 36th-level cleric removing a quest cast by a 20th-level cleric has a 99% chance of success (capped to prevent automatic success).
Remove Quest*.name: Remove Quest*
Remove Quest*.spellEffect: Removes an unwanted quest or curse

Remove Traps.description: After detecting a trap, the character can attempt to disarm it safely. Success is based on a percentage determined by their level.
Remove Traps.name: Remove Traps

Requiem Melody.description:
This haunting spell-song fills the target with unbearable grief and sorrow, rendering them incapable of rational action.

Effects:

  • The target suffers a -1 penalty to all attack and damage rolls (no saving throw).
  • The target must make a saving throw vs. spells to resist further effects.

On a Failed Saving Throw:

  • The target begins crying uncontrollably and falls into despair.
  • They must attack themselves with any available weapon or bare hands.
  • Self-inflicted damage is real, and weapon mastery bonuses do not apply.
  • This effect lasts for a number of rounds equal to the bard’s Constitution score.

On a Successful Saving Throw:

  • The penalty to attack and damage rolls remains as long as the bard continues singing.
  • The bard can sing for a maximum number of rounds equal to their Constitution score.

After the Song Ends:

  • The bard must make a Wisdom check to resist the psychic backlash.
  • If successful, the bard is stunned for [[/r 1d4 #Stunned rounds]].
  • If failed, the bard passes out for 1 round per round spent singing.

Additional Details:

  • This spell only affects creatures with an Intelligence score of 3 or higher.
  • The bard can end the song early to avoid the backlash.
Requiem Melody.name: Requiem Melody
Requiem Melody.spellEffect: Overwhelms a target with despair, causing self-inflicted harm

Resist Cold.description: When this spell is cast, all creatures within 30' of the spellcaster are protected from freezing temperatures without harm. Those affected also receive a +2 bonus to all saving throws against cold-based attacks. Additionally, any cold damage dealt to them is reduced by 1 point per die, with a minimum of 1 point of damage per die. The effect moves with the spellcaster.
Resist Cold.name: Resist Cold

Resist Fire.description: For the duration of this spell, the recipient is immune to damage from normal fire and heat. They also receive a +2 bonus to all saving throws against magical fire (such as dragon breath or fireball). Additionally, any damage taken from such magical fire is reduced by 1 point per die of damage, with each die dealing at least 1 point of damage. For red dragon breath, the damage is reduced by 1 point per Hit Die of the dragon, but never below 1 point per Hit Die.
Resist Fire.name: Resist Fire

Resistance (MY).description:
The mystic receives only half damage (rounded down) from all spells and breath weapons that cause damage, or one-quarter damage (rounded down) if the saving throw is successful. Any attack that inflicts damage on him will deal a minimum of 1 point of damage, even if rounding suggests 0 points of damage.

Roll a save vs. breath weapons for breath weapons and vs. spell for spells.
Resistance (MY).name: Resistance (MY)

Restore*.description:
This spell restores one full level of experience lost due to energy drain (such as from a vampire's attack). It does not provide additional levels if no level has been lost.

Limitations:

  • Only one level is restored per casting.
  • It cannot restore more than one level, nor increase a level beyond what was originally lost.

Cost to the Cleric:

  • Upon casting, the cleric temporarily loses one experience level, as if struck by a wight.
  • The cleric’s loss is not permanent—it is recovered after resting for [[/r 2d10 #days]].
Restore*.name: Restore*
Restore*.spellEffect: Restores 1 level lost to energy drain

Reverse Gravity.description:
This spell causes all creatures and objects within a 30' x 30' x 30' cube to fall upward for 2 seconds (1/5 of a round).

Effect:

  • Affects all creatures and objects in the area.
  • They "fall" up to 65' instantly.
  • Hitting a ceiling or obstruction causes 1d6 damage per 10' fallen.
  • After 2 seconds, gravity returns to normal, causing victims to fall back down and take additional falling damage.
  • NPCs affected must make a morale check.

Example:

In a 40' tall room, giants hit the ceiling (4d6 damage) and then fall back to the floor (another 4d6 damage), taking a total of 8d6 damage.
Reverse Gravity.name: Reverse Gravity
Reverse Gravity.spellEffect: Causes victims in a 30' cubic volume to fall upward

Riding (choose type).description: This skill covers the ability to ride and control a specific type of mount, such as a horse, griffon, or dragon. The chosen type must be specified when the skill is selected. Riding involves managing the mount in various situations, including combat, hazardous terrain, and high-speed maneuvers. The skill can also be used to calm and handle a frightened or unruly mount.
Riding (choose type).name: Riding (choose type)

Right of Sanctuary (AV).description:
An Avenger may visit any castle, ruin, or dungeon ruled by an intelligent Chaotic monster or character and, using their alignment tongue, formally demand Sanctuary. If granted, the Avenger is given temporary protection and hospitality, as per the custom of Sanctuary.

An Avenger may also attempt to deceive non-Chaotic rulers by posing as a knight and requesting Sanctuary. If the ruler is successfully fooled (and no alignment-detecting magic exposes the deception), they will provide the same hospitality they would grant a true knight.
Right of Sanctuary (AV).name: Right of Sanctuary (AV)

Ring of Protection +1.description: This ring improves the wearer's armor class by 1. It also has the effect of improving all saving throws by 1.
Ring of Protection +1.name: Ring of Protection +1
Ring of Protection +1.unidentifiedDesc: An odd ring that seems to fit any finger perfectly.

Ring of Protection +2.description: This ring improves the wearer's armor class by 2. It also has the effect of improving all saving throws by 2.
Ring of Protection +2.name: Ring of Protection +2
Ring of Protection +2.unidentifiedDesc: An odd ring that seems to fit any finger perfectly.

Ring of Strength +1.description: While worn, this ring increases the wearers strength ability score by 1.
Ring of Strength +1.name: Ring of Strength +1
Ring of Strength +1.unidentifiedDesc: An odd ring that seems to fit any finger perfectly.

Rope (50' length).description: A heavy climbing rope that can support up to three fully loaded humans, approximately 7,500 coins in total weight. It can be tied to an iron spike for climbing steep surfaces or used to tie up prisoners and pull open doors.
Rope (50' length).name: Rope (50' length)
Rope (50' length).unidentifiedDesc: A heavy climbing rope that can support up to three fully loaded humans, approximately 7,500 coins in total weight. It can be tied to an iron spike for climbing steep surfaces or used to tie up prisoners and pull open doors.

Ruby.description: Ruby is a gemstone known for its deep red color and brilliance. It typically features a smooth, polished surface and a faceted appearance, enhancing its clarity and vibrant hue. Rubies are highly valued in jewelry for their rich color and elegant sparkle.
Ruby.name: Ruby
Ruby.unidentifiedDesc: Ruby is a gemstone known for its deep red color and brilliance. It typically features a smooth, polished surface and a faceted appearance, enhancing its clarity and vibrant hue. Rubies are highly valued in jewelry for their rich color and elegant sparkle.

Sack, Large.description: A 2' x 4' burlap, cloth, or leather bag that can hold up to 600 coins. It is typically carried over a shoulder or tied onto a cart or saddle, making it useful for carrying large amounts of treasure or bulky items.
Sack, Large.name: Sack, Large
Sack, Large.unidentifiedDesc: A 2' x 4' burlap, cloth, or leather bag that can hold up to 600 coins. It is typically carried over a shoulder or tied onto a cart or saddle, making it useful for carrying large amounts of treasure or bulky items.

Sack, Small.description: A 1' x 2' cloth or leather bag that can hold up to 200 coins. It can be carried over the shoulder or tied onto a cart or saddle. Often used to store small items or treasure.
Sack, Small.name: Sack, Small
Sack, Small.unidentifiedDesc: A 1' x 2' cloth or leather bag that can hold up to 200 coins. It can be carried over the shoulder or tied onto a cart or saddle. Often used to store small items or treasure.

Sacred Retinue (PA).description: A Paladin may only travel with a number of hirelings equal to or less than their effective cleric level (one-third of their Paladin level, rounding down). For example, if a Paladin can cast spells or turn undead as a 5th-level cleric, they may have up to five hirelings accompany them.
Sacred Retinue (PA).name: Sacred Retinue (PA)

Saddle Bags (large).description:
Saddle bags are leather bags designed to fit over the back of a riding saddle and provide some storage on a ridden animal. The bags are tied to the saddle to prevent them from falling off. A person can throw them over their shoulder to make sure any valuables that are
in the saddlebags are not stolen while the rider is of their mount. The size is in relation to the size of the riding animal.

Weight held (pounds/coins)50/500
Volume held (cu. ft.)5
Saddle Bags (large).name: Saddle Bags (large)
Saddle Bags (large).unidentifiedDesc:
Saddle bags are leather bags designed to fit over the back of a riding saddle and provide some storage on a ridden animal. The bags are tied to the saddle to prevent them from falling off. A person can throw them over their shoulder to make sure any valuables that are
in the saddlebags are not stolen while the rider is of their mount. The size is in relation to the size of the riding animal.

Weight held (pounds/coins)50/500
Volume held (cu. ft.)5

Sapphire.description: Sapphire is a gemstone known for its deep blue color and brilliance. It has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted appearance, showcasing its clarity and vibrant hue. Sapphires are highly prized in jewelry for their stunning color and elegant sparkle.
Sapphire.name: Sapphire
Sapphire.unidentifiedDesc: Sapphire is a gemstone known for its deep blue color and brilliance. It has a smooth, polished surface with a faceted appearance, showcasing its clarity and vibrant hue. Sapphires are highly prized in jewelry for their stunning color and elegant sparkle.

Scale Mail.description: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates that have metal scales or studs sewn onto them for added protection. Scale mail gives a character an armor class of 6
Scale Mail.name: Scale Mail
Scale Mail.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates that have metal scales or studs sewn onto them for added protection. Scale mail gives a character an armor class of 6

Scale Mail +1.description:
This is a magic suit of armor primarily composed of leather plates that have metal scales or studs sewn onto them for added protection. Scale mail gives a character an armor class of 6, but this armor provides an additional bonus.

Magic armor weighs half that of its nonmagic counterpart.
Scale Mail +1.name: Scale Mail +1
Scale Mail +1.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of leather plates that have metal scales or studs sewn onto them for added protection. Scale mail gives a character an armor class of 6

Science (choose type).description: The character is an expert in one branch of scientific study, such as astronomy, geology, metallurgy, etc. This expertise allows the character to provide specialized knowledge and make expert judgments within that field. The player must indicate the specific branch of science their character has mastered. Characters may take this skill multiple times to represent expertise in different scientific disciplines.
Science (choose type).name: Science (choose type)

Scroll Case.description: An oiled leather tube with a cap. Not completely watertight.
Scroll Case.name: Scroll Case
Scroll Case.unidentifiedDesc: An oiled leather tube with a cap. Not completely watertight.

Scroll Case (water-tight).description:
A water-tight oiled leather tube with a fancy sealed cap.

Holds three scrolls.
Scroll Case (water-tight).name: Scroll Case (water-tight)
Scroll Case (water-tight).unidentifiedDesc: An oiled leather tube with a cap. Not completely watertight.

Scroll of Stone to Flesh.description: This scroll contains the magic-user spell *Stone to Flesh*, which is a 6th-level spell. When read aloud, it can turn a statue or an amount of stone up to 10' x 10' x 10' into flesh. Commonly used to restore those petrified by effects like a gorgon’s breath. The reverse spell, *Flesh to Stone*, will transform a living creature into stone unless the target succeeds on a save versus petrification.
Scroll of Stone to Flesh.name: Scroll of Stone to Flesh

Set Spear vs. Charge.description:
A character on foot armed with a spear, pike, sword, shield, or lance can set the weapon against a charge. A charge occurs when a monster rushes towards the character, covering at least 20 yards before attacking. This maneuver can also be used against another character's lance attack.

To "set vs. charge," the character braces the weapon against the ground, pointing it at the approaching enemy. Strength and magic bonuses apply to both the attack and damage rolls. If the attack is successful, the character deals double damage, with adjustments applied after doubling.

The character must declare the set vs. charge maneuver before entering melee combat with the charging opponent. For example, if the character’s party wins initiative and expects a charge, they can declare this maneuver. Similarly, if charging monsters are spotted several rounds in advance, the character can set their weapon against the charge ahead of time.

Typically, the attack is made during the monster's movement phase, as soon as it comes within weapon range. If the attack succeeds and kills the monster, it prevents the creature from attacking. If the attack does not kill the monster, it can then attack during its own melee phase of the combat sequence.
Set Spear vs. Charge.name: Set Spear vs. Charge

Shapechange.description:
This spell allows the caster to completely transform into another creature or object while retaining their own mind, hit points, and saving throws.

Transformation Details:

  • The caster gains the new form’s Armor Class, attack rolls, special attack forms, immunities, and abilities.
  • The caster cannot cast spells unless in a bipedal humanoid form (demihuman, goblin, ogre, giant, etc.).
  • The caster cannot take the form of a specific individual, Elemental Ruler, or Immortal.
  • The caster cannot use spellbooks or scrolls in non-humanoid forms.
  • If the caster assumes another class's form, he does not gain that class's abilities.

Size Limitations:

  • The caster cannot assume huge inanimate forms.
  • The maximum size for an inanimate object is 1 foot per caster level and 100 cn per caster level.

Restrictions:

  • The caster may only change into creatures or objects that he has personally seen.
  • The caster cannot invent new creatures (e.g., a ten-armed troll unless they exist in the campaign).
  • The caster inherits the weaknesses of the chosen form (e.g., a dragon form is vulnerable to swords +2, +5 vs. dragons).
  • The caster may change form at will, but each transformation requires 1 full round of concentration.
  • The effect cannot be made permanent and is subject to dispel magic.
  • The caster cannot pass through protection from evil or anti-magic shell effects.
Shapechange.name: Shapechange
Shapechange.spellEffect: Allows caster to change form completely

Shield +1.description: A magic shield is a large solid piece of wood or metal that is either held in one hand or strapped to one arm. It is used to parry melee attacks and provide cover from missile attacks. A shield is normally used in conjunction with armor and provides and extra bonus of –1 (plus magic bonus) to the character’s armor class. Wooden shields may be used by druids, since they are made primarily of natural materials.
Shield +1.name: Shield +1
Shield +1.unidentifiedDesc: A shield is a large solid piece of wood or metal that is either held in one hand or strapped to one arm. It is used to parry melee attacks and provide cover from missile attacks. A shield is normally used in conjunction with armor and provides and extra bonus of –1 to the character’s armor class. If used without other armor, a shield provides a bonus of –1 to a character’s natural armor class of 9, for a total armor class of 8. Wooden shields may be used by druids, since they are made primarily of natural materials.

Shield Weapon (Any).description: A shield weapon is a hybrid of a protective shield and a weapon, equipped with blades, spikes, or other protrusions designed for offense. It serves a dual purpose, offering standard defensive capabilities while allowing an additional attack during combat when paired with a one-handed weapon. These weapons, typically used by fighters, thieves, and demihumans, come in various sizes, with larger versions requiring two hands. While versatile, shield weapons are prone to breaking under specific conditions, such as precise attack rolls, adding an element of risk to their use.
Shield Weapon (Any).name: Shield Weapon (Any)
Shield Weapon (Any).unidentifiedDesc: A shield weapon is a hybrid of a protective shield and a weapon, equipped with blades, spikes, or other protrusions designed for offense. It serves a dual purpose, offering standard defensive capabilities while allowing an additional attack during combat when paired with a one-handed weapon. These weapons, typically used by fighters, thieves, and demihumans, come in various sizes, with larger versions requiring two hands. While versatile, shield weapons are prone to breaking under specific conditions, such as precise attack rolls, adding an element of risk to their use.

Shield Weapon (Any) +1.description: A magic shield weapon is a hybrid of a protective shield and a weapon, equipped with blades, spikes, or other protrusions designed for offense. It serves a dual purpose, offering standard defensive capabilities while allowing an additional attack during combat when paired with a one-handed weapon. These weapons, typically used by fighters, thieves, and demihumans, come in various sizes, with larger versions requiring two hands. While versatile, shield weapons are prone to breaking under specific conditions, such as precise attack rolls, adding an element of risk to their use.
Shield Weapon (Any) +1.name: Shield Weapon (Any) +1
Shield Weapon (Any) +1.unidentifiedDesc: A shield weapon is a hybrid of a protective shield and a weapon, equipped with blades, spikes, or other protrusions designed for offense. It serves a dual purpose, offering standard defensive capabilities while allowing an additional attack during combat when paired with a one-handed weapon. These weapons, typically used by fighters, thieves, and demihumans, come in various sizes, with larger versions requiring two hands. While versatile, shield weapons are prone to breaking under specific conditions, such as precise attack rolls, adding an element of risk to their use.

Shield, Horned@c1Pb7jq7pyg6uRn6.description: This is a small, circular shield measuring about one foot in diameter. It is securely strapped to the wielder’s arm rather than being handheld. A sturdy spike protrudes from the center of the shield, allowing it to double as a weapon. Its robust construction ensures that it is resistant to breakage during combat.
Shield, Horned@c1Pb7jq7pyg6uRn6.name: Shield, Horned
Shield, Horned@c1Pb7jq7pyg6uRn6.unidentifiedDesc: This is a small, circular shield measuring about one foot in diameter. It is securely strapped to the wielder’s arm rather than being handheld. A sturdy spike protrudes from the center of the shield, allowing it to double as a weapon. Its robust construction ensures that it is resistant to breakage during combat.

Shield, Knife@qfCLTbwrUKRukz0d.description: This is a compact buckler equipped with one or two short blades extending from its edges. These protrusions allow it to serve both as a defensive tool and an offensive weapon. Its small size makes it easier to maneuver compared to larger shields.
Shield, Knife@qfCLTbwrUKRukz0d.name: Shield, Knife
Shield, Knife@qfCLTbwrUKRukz0d.unidentifiedDesc: This is a compact buckler equipped with one or two short blades extending from its edges. These protrusions allow it to serve both as a defensive tool and an offensive weapon. Its small size makes it easier to maneuver compared to larger shields.

Shield, Sword@hzYAVJ6gLy56aebO.description: This is a medium-sized shield, designed with one or two blades attached. Depending on the shield's shape, the blades extend from the sides if it is round, or from the ends if it is oblong. This combination provides both defensive protection and an additional offensive option in combat.
Shield, Sword@hzYAVJ6gLy56aebO.name: Shield, Sword
Shield, Sword@hzYAVJ6gLy56aebO.unidentifiedDesc: This is a medium-sized shield, designed with one or two blades attached. Depending on the shield's shape, the blades extend from the sides if it is round, or from the ends if it is oblong. This combination provides both defensive protection and an additional offensive option in combat.

Shield, Tusked@hShLOFsdthE8CIwc.description: This is a large shield featuring one to four short blades projecting from its sides, and it may also include a central spike for added offensive capability. Due to its size, this shield requires the use of both hands, preventing the wielder from using another weapon or shield simultaneously. Characters wielding this shield always lose individual initiative to opponents not using two-handed weapons. It is unsuitable for halflings and similarly small creatures such as goblins.
Shield, Tusked@hShLOFsdthE8CIwc.name: Shield, Tusked
Shield, Tusked@hShLOFsdthE8CIwc.unidentifiedDesc: This is a large shield featuring one to four short blades projecting from its sides, and it may also include a central spike for added offensive capability. Due to its size, this shield requires the use of both hands, preventing the wielder from using another weapon or shield simultaneously. Characters wielding this shield always lose individual initiative to opponents not using two-handed weapons. It is unsuitable for halflings and similarly small creatures such as goblins.

Shield@efbE0gN8tqL8K94z.description: A shield is a large solid piece of wood or metal that is either held in one hand or strapped to one arm. It is used to parry melee attacks and provide cover from missile attacks. A shield is normally used in conjunction with armor and provides and extra bonus of –1 to the character’s armor class. If used without other armor, a shield provides a bonus of –1 to a character’s natural armor class of 9, for a total armor class of 8. Wooden shields may be used by druids, since they are made primarily of natural materials.
Shield@efbE0gN8tqL8K94z.name: Shield
Shield@efbE0gN8tqL8K94z.unidentifiedDesc: A shield is a large solid piece of wood or metal that is either held in one hand or strapped to one arm. It is used to parry melee attacks and provide cover from missile attacks. A shield is normally used in conjunction with armor and provides and extra bonus of –1 to the character’s armor class. If used without other armor, a shield provides a bonus of –1 to a character’s natural armor class of 9, for a total armor class of 8. Wooden shields may be used by druids, since they are made primarily of natural materials.

Shield@u93tgQ9zyIS1ka9X.description:
This spell creates a magical barrier around the caster, less than an inch away from their body. It grants an AC of 2 against missiles and AC 4 against all other attacks. The barrier moves with the caster, and it does not interfere with the caster’s movements or attacks.

If a magic missile is shot at the caster, the caster can make a saving throw vs. spells. If successful, the missile is negated by the shield and has no effect.
Shield@u93tgQ9zyIS1ka9X.name: Shield

Shielded.description:
Shield

A magical barrier envelops the affected individual, forming less than an inch from their body and moving with them. While this status is active, the individual's Armor Class is set to 2 against missile attacks and 4 against all other attacks.

If the individual is targeted by a magic missile, they may make a saving throw vs. spells for each missile. On a successful save, the magic missile is absorbed by the barrier and evaporates without causing harm.
Shielded.name: Shielded

Shipbuilding.description: This is the skill of designing and building ships. It allows a character to supervise the construction of professional-quality ships, whether made by muscle or by magic. Successful use of the skill lets characters evaluate ships they encounter to determine who built them and when.
Shipbuilding.name: Shipbuilding

Shovel.description: A shovel used for digging holes in the ground and whacking people upside the head.
Shovel.name: Shovel
Shovel.unidentifiedDesc: A shovel used for digging holes in the ground and whacking people upside the head.

Shrink Plants*.description: The reverse of *Growth of Plants*, this spell causes normal plants within the area of effect to shrink, becoming passable. It can be used to negate the effects of *Growth of Plants* but does not affect plant-like monsters such as treants.
Shrink Plants*.name: Shrink Plants*

Signaling (choose type).description: This skill allows the character to leave messages that can only be understood by another Signaling specialist of the same culture, trade guild, military force, or "school." The player must specify the type and culture of signals the character studies, such as military trumpet signals, naval flag signals, smoke signals, or drum signals.
Signaling (choose type).name: Signaling (choose type)

Silence 15' Radius.description: This spell creates an area of total silence within a 15' radius, making it impossible to converse or cast spells inside the affected area for the duration of the spell. Those within the sphere can still hear sounds from outside. If the spell is cast on a creature, the target must make a saving throw vs. spells. If the saving throw fails, the effect moves with the creature. If successful, the silence remains stationary, and the creature can leave the affected area.
Silence 15' Radius.name: Silence 15' Radius

Silenced.description: This condition makes it impossible to converse or cast spells inside the affected area for the duration of the spell. Those within the sphere can still hear sounds from outside.
Silenced.name: Silenced

Singing.description: The Singing skill enables a character to perform vocal music with skill and emotion. It is used in performances to entertain, in rituals to invoke magic, or in social situations to charm or persuade. A successful Singing check can captivate an audience, enhance the effects of other abilities, or even distract or charm creatures through melody and lyrics.
Singing.name: Singing

Sleep.description:
This spell puts 2-16 Hit Dice of creatures to sleep within a 40' square area. It affects creatures with 4+1 HD or less and does not work against undead or very large creatures, such as dragons. Creatures outside the area of effect are not affected.

Slapping, kicking, or shaking a sleeping creature will wake it. A single blow with an edged weapon can kill a sleeping creature, regardless of its hit points.

Your Dungeon Master will roll [[/r 2d8 #Sleep total hit dice affected]] to determine the total Hit Dice or experience levels of creatures affected by the spell. No saving throw is allowed.

The spell will put the targets to sleep for [[/r 4d4 #Sleep duration in turns]] turns.
Sleep.name: Sleep
Sleep.spellEffect: 2d8 Hit Dice of living creatures within a 40' square area

Sling +1.description: A sling is a long (4’ to 6’) leather cord with a pouch half way along. The wielder straps one end of the cord around their wrist and holds the other end in the same hand. They then place a lead pellet in the pouch and swing the cord over their head. At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.
Sling +1.name: Sling +1
Sling +1.unidentifiedDesc: A sling is a long (4’ to 6’) leather cord with a pouch half way along. The wielder straps one end of the cord around their wrist and holds the other end in the same hand. They then place a lead pellet in the pouch and swing the cord over their head. At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.

The wielder straps one end of the cord around their wrist and holds the other end in the same hand. They then place a lead pellet in the pouch and swing the cord over their head. At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.
Sling@mvbNrNhrCVQQy1BZ.name: Sling
Sling@mvbNrNhrCVQQy1BZ.unidentifiedDesc: A sling is a long (4’ to 6’) leather cord with a pouch half way along. The wielder straps one end of the cord around their wrist and holds the other end in the same hand. They then place a lead pellet in the pouch and swing the cord over their head. At the mid-point of the swing, they let go of the loose end, which releases the pellet. Slings normally require pellets as ammunition, although they can be used with stones taken from the ground, albeit with a –1 penalty on to-hit and damage rolls.

Slow*.description:
The reversed version of *Haste*, *Slow* reduces the movement and attack speed of up to 24 creatures within a 60' diameter area to half their normal rate.

Effect: Slowed creatures move and attack at half speed but are otherwise unaffected, including spellcasting and magical device usage. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect.
Slow*.name: Slow*
Slow*.spellEffect: Up to 24 creatures move at half speed

Slowed.description: Slowed creatures move and attack at half speed but are otherwise unaffected, including spellcasting and magical device usage. Each affected creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect.
Slowed.name: Slowed

Smash.description:
This maneuver allows a character to perform a powerful hand-to-hand attack. When using this option, the character automatically loses initiative and takes a -5 penalty to their attack roll (but still applies their Strength and magic bonuses).

If the attack hits, the character adds their Strength bonus, magic bonuses, and their full Strength score to the weapon's normal damage.

For example, a character with a Strength of 17 (+2 to attack and damage) using a sword +2 (+2 to attack, 1d8 + 2 damage) would execute the attack as follows: the attack roll is made with a net penalty of -1 (+2 +2 -5). If successful, they roll 1d8 + 21 (17 + 2 + 2) for damage!
Smash.name: Smash

Snake Charm.description:
This spell allows the spellcaster to charm a number of Hit Dice of snakes equal to their level, with no saving throw allowed. For example, a 5th-level spellcaster could charm one 5 HD snake, five 1 HD snakes, or any combination of snakes totaling 5 Hit Dice or less. The charmed snakes will rise up and sway, but will not attack unless provoked.

If the spell is cast on snakes that are attacking the spellcaster, the duration is [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Snake Charm duration in rounds]] rounds. Otherwise, the spell lasts for [[/r 1d4 + 1 #Snake Charm duration in turns]] turns. Once the spell ends, the snakes return to their normal behavior, but they will not automatically be hostile unless provoked.
Snake Charm.name: Snake Charm
Snake Charm.spellEffect: Charms 1 HD of snakes per level of the caster

Snares.description: This is the skill of building traps to capture animals, monsters, and unwanted visitors. A successful skill roll means the trap functions properly. The DM can assign modifiers to the skill roll based on the time the character had to set up the trap, the availability of materials, etc.
Snares.name: Snares

Song of Binding.description:
This powerful spell-song paralyzes creatures that hear its melody, rendering them unable to act.

Effects:

  • The bard may affect up to:

    • 4 Medium-sized creatures (up to 7' tall).
    • 2 Large-sized creatures (7+' to 12' tall).
    • 1 Huge-sized creature (12+' to 25' tall).
  • The song has no effect on creatures larger than 25' (Gargantuan size).
  • All affected targets must hear the song for at least 1 round before they can be paralyzed.
  • Each victim may make a saving throw vs. Paralysis to resist the effect.
  • On a failed save, the creature is paralyzed for [[/r @actor.details.level #Paralyzed rounds]].

Ending the Effect:

  • The paralysis lasts for 1 round per level of the bard.
  • It may be removed by normal means, such as the spell free person.
  • The paralysis may also be dispelled by the reverse of this song (if available).
Song of Binding.name: Song of Binding
Song of Binding.spellEffect: Paralyzes creatures who hear the song

Song of Freedom.description:
This spell-song is the opposite of Song of Binding. When sung, it grants those affected an opportunity to break free from paralysis.

Effects:

  • Up to four creatures within range are affected.
  • Each affected creature that is currently paralyzed may make a new saving throw vs. Paralysis every round.
  • A successful saving throw immediately removes the paralysis effect.
  • The spell-song lasts for 1 round per level of the bard.

Additional Notes:

  • The song permanently negates any existing paralysis for creatures that successfully save.
  • This spell-song has the same range and limitations as Song of Binding.
Song of Freedom.name: Song of Freedom
Song of Freedom.spellEffect: Allows paralysed creatures to make additional saving throws each round

Speak With Animals.description: The mystic can communicate with any normal or giant animal as frequently as he wishes; the animals comprehend his words, and he understands theirs, although no animal is obligated to converse with him.
Speak With Animals.name: Speak With Animals

Speak with Animals.description:
When casting this spell, the spellcaster must name one type of animal (such as wolves). For the duration of the spell, the spellcaster can communicate with all animals of that type within 30'; the effect moves with the caster.

The spell allows the caster to speak to any normal or giant forms of the named animal type, but only to one type at a time. The spell cannot be used to communicate with intelligent animals or fantastic creatures.

The animals typically react favorably (with a +2 bonus to reaction rolls) and may be persuaded to perform a favor for the spellcaster if the reaction roll is high enough. The animal must be capable of understanding and carrying out the request.
Speak with Animals.name: Speak with Animals

Speak with Anyone.description: The mystic can communicate with any living creature that possesses a language of any kind, as frequently as he wishes. The creature being addressed is not required to engage in conversation with him.
Speak with Anyone.name: Speak with Anyone

Speak with Monsters*.description:
This spell grants the cleric the ability to communicate with any living or undead creatures within 30'. Even unintelligent monsters will understand and respond.

Effects:

  • Creatures spoken to will not attack the cleric while in conversation.
  • However, if attacked, they may defend themselves or flee.
  • The cleric may ask only one question per round.

The spell lasts for one round per level of the cleric.
Speak with Monsters*.name: Speak with Monsters*
Speak with Monsters*.spellDuration: 1 round per level of the cleric

Speak with Plants.description:
This spell allows the caster to communicate with plants within a 30' radius, treating them as if they have intelligence. The caster may ask simple favors, such as making a path through dense undergrowth, which the plants will grant if able.

Effect: Enables communication with plant creatures, including plantlike monsters such as treants.
Speak with Plants.name: Speak with Plants

Speak with the Dead.description:
By means of this spell, a caster may ask three questions of a deceased spirit if the body is within range.

A caster of 6th or 7th level can contact recently deceased spirits (those dead up to 4 days). Casters of levels 8-14 have slightly more power (contacting spirits up to 4 months dead), and casters of levels 15-20 have even more (speaking with corpses up to 4 years dead). No time limits apply to casters of 21st level or greater.

The spirit will always reply in a tongue known to the caster, but can only offer knowledge of things up to the time of its death. If the spirit's alignment is the same as the caster's, it will provide clear and brief answers; however, if the alignments differ, the spirit may reply in riddles.
Speak with the Dead.name: Speak with the Dead

Spear +1.description: The magic spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.
Spear +1.name: Spear +1
Spear +1.unidentifiedDesc: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.

Spear +2.description: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.
Spear +2.name: Spear +2
Spear +2.unidentifiedDesc: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.

Spear@tfbRwWqAkCsIotTj.name: Spear
Spear@tfbRwWqAkCsIotTj.unidentifiedDesc: The spear is a thrusting head attached to one end of a medium-to-long pole (6'-8'). Fighters, dwarves, elves, and mystics can use the set spear vs. charge maneuver.

Spell Research.description:
A character can attempt to create a new spell, provided it is of a level they can cast. The process requires:

  • 1,000 gp per spell level

  • Two weeks of research per spell level

  • Rare components, often necessitating an adventure to obtain

  • A fully stocked laboratory or library

The chance of success depends on the character's Intelligence score and level, with modifications for spell difficulty. If a research attempt fails, the process must be restarted, but each failure grants a +5% cumulative bonus to future attempts.

Typically, a character does not have a sufficient library for advanced research until reaching 18th level, or at least 9th level if they have collected extensive magical tomes. While research is technically possible at any level, lower-level characters may struggle to meet the requirements.
Spell Research.name: Spell Research

Spellbook.description: The spell book is a sizable, bulky item, approximately 2 feet square and 2–6 inches thick, weighing at least 20 pounds. It cannot fit inside any normal sack, regardless of size, but can be carried in a backpack or saddlebag. Written in magical script, the spell book can only be read by its owner unless another individual uses a read magic spell.
Spellbook.name: Spellbook
Spellbook.unidentifiedDesc: The spell book is a sizable, bulky item, approximately 2 feet square and 2–6 inches thick, weighing at least 20 pounds. It cannot fit inside any normal sack, regardless of size, but can be carried in a backpack or saddlebag. Written in magical script, the spell book can only be read by its owner unless another individual uses a read magic spell.

Spellbook, travelling.description:
A Spellbook is an essential feature of any Magic-User's kit. This is where their spells and formulae are stored, and is used to prepare for spellcasting.

A smaller, more portable option is the leather-bound Traveling spellbook. This book is typically about 10” x 6.5” in size with sixty-four pages. It can store up to thirty-two spells. Either will fit into a backpack or satchel. In general, a Magic-Users' starting book is assumed to be a Traveling book.

The initial spellbook of a Magic-User is given as a gift from their instructors.
Spellbook, travelling.name: Spellbook, travelling
Spellbook, travelling.unidentifiedDesc:
A Spellbook is an essential feature of any Magic-User's kit. This is where their spells and formulae are stored, and is used to prepare for spellcasting.

A smaller, more portable option is the leather-bound Traveling spellbook. This book is typically about 10” x 6.5” in size with 64 pages. It can store up to 64 levels of spells. Either will fit into a backpack or satchel. In general, a Magic-Users' starting book is assumed to be a Traveling book, but a player may start with a Reference book if the GM allows it.

The initial spellbook of a Magic-User is given as a gift from their instructors.

Spells or Magic Staff.description: The saving throw for Spells or Magic Staff includes resistance against magical effects cast by rods, staves, wands, or through spells. A successful save, rolled on a d20, often reduces or negates the spell's effects entirely. This saving throw is applicable to numerous magical attacks, such as charm spells, fireballs, or paralysis effects, and covers damage, control, or debilitating conditions caused by magical devices or spellcasters. The target number for success is based on the character's class and level.
Spells or Magic Staff.name: Spells or Magic Staff

Staff +1.description: A staff is one of the most simple weapons. It consists of just a length of wood 5’ to 7’ in length, which is wielded in two hands. Often, the head of the staff has some sort of ornamentation.
Staff +1.name: Staff +1
Staff +1.unidentifiedDesc: A staff is one of the most simple weapons. It consists of just a length of wood 5’ to 7’ in length, which is wielded in two hands. Often, the head of the staff has some sort of ornamentation.

Staff@A4nQHbJt1qy5ByzL.description: A staff is one of the most simple weapons. It consists of just a length of wood 5’ to 7’ in length, which is wielded in two hands. Often, the head of the staff has some sort of ornamentation.
Staff@A4nQHbJt1qy5ByzL.name: Staff
Staff@A4nQHbJt1qy5ByzL.unidentifiedDesc: A staff is one of the most simple weapons. It consists of just a length of wood 5’ to 7’ in length, which is wielded in two hands. Often, the head of the staff has some sort of ornamentation.

Stakes (3) and Mallet.description: Three large (18”) wooden stakes and a wooden mallet, often used for destroying vampires or securing ropes and tents. They can also be used to pin down an opponent or object to the ground.
Stakes (3) and Mallet.name: Stakes (3) and Mallet
Stakes (3) and Mallet.unidentifiedDesc: Three large (18”) wooden stakes and a wooden mallet, often used for destroying vampires or securing ropes and tents. They can also be used to pin down an opponent or object to the ground.

Statue.description:
This spell allows the caster to transform into a stone statue at will for the duration. The caster may change to or from statue form once per round.

Effects While in Statue Form:

  • Armor Class: -4
  • Immune to normal weapons
  • Immune to fire and cold (normal and magical)
  • Immune to gas attacks, drowning, and suffocation (does not breathe)
  • Cannot move or cast new spells
  • Can concentrate on ongoing spells
  • Still takes damage from magical weapons and spells (e.g., lightning bolt)

Additional Rules:

  • Not immune to petrification effects (e.g., gorgon breath) but can revert to normal after 1 round.
  • When attacked by fire or cold spells in normal form, the caster gains a +2 initiative bonus to change into statue form before being hit.
Statue.name: Statue
Statue.spellEffect: Allows caster to turn to stone

Stealth (choose terrain).description: The Stealth skill allows a character to move silently and remain unseen in a specific type of environment, such as forests, urban areas, or caves. The chosen terrain must be specified when the skill is selected. Characters with this skill can avoid detection, set up ambushes, or scout ahead without revealing their presence. The effectiveness of this skill may depend on the terrain's features and the character’s preparation.
Stealth (choose terrain).name: Stealth (choose terrain)

Steelform.description:
This spell creates a mass of steel equal to 500 square feet, with a thickness of up to 2 inches. The shape and arrangement of the steel are determined by the caster.

Creation Time:

  • Simple designs (walls, basic shapes) take 1 round.
  • Moderate designs (stairs, basic structures) take 1 turn (10 rounds).
  • Complex designs (fine weapons, intricate details) take up to 12 turns (2 hours), as determined by the DM.

Rules & Mechanics:

  • The created steel is one solid piece with no moving parts.
  • The original caster may cast Steelform again on an existing Steelform structure to modify it for up to two hours.
  • When satisfied, the caster can "lock" the steel in place, preventing further modifications via Steelform.
  • The steel must rest on solid ground or a similar support.
  • Unlike Wall of Iron, the steel does not have to be vertical.
  • The caster may create tough sides that allow later Steelform castings to seamlessly fuse to them.

Weapon-Quality Steel:

  • The steel created by this spell is high-quality and suitable for crafting weapons and armor.
  • A skilled weapon or armor maker can use Steelform to create finely crafted items.
  • For example, a swordmaker could cast this spell to create a high-quality sword in 12 turns (2 hours) or less.

Durability:

  • Steel created by Steelform cannot be dispelled.
  • The steel lasts permanently until broken or destroyed by effects such as Disintegrate or Rust Monsters.

  • Following Fortifications Table guidelines, a steel wall has:

    • Armor Class: -10 (2)
    • Hit Points: 20 per inch of thickness
Steelform.name: Steelform

Sticks to Snakes.description:
This spell transforms [[/r 2d8 #sticks into snakes]] sticks into snakes, which may be poisonous (50% chance per snake). The snakes obey the caster's commands but will revert to sticks when slain or when the spell's duration ends.

Snake Stats: AC 6; HD 1; AT 1 bite; Dmg 1d4; MV 90' (30'); Save F1; ML 12; AL Neutral; SA poison (50% chance per snake to be poisonous).

Non-poisonous snakes grant 10 XP each, while poisonous ones grant 13 XP each.
Sticks to Snakes.name: Sticks to Snakes
Sticks to Snakes.spellEffect: Turns up to 16 sticks into snakes

Still Night.description:
This haunting melody creates a sphere of absolute silence, 20' in diameter, centered on the bard. Within this sphere, no sound may escape, but those inside can still hear sounds from the outside. The effect moves with the bard for the duration of the spell.

Effects:

  • Prevents all sound from being heard outside the sphere.
  • Nullifies all spellcasting within the sphere (verbal components cannot be spoken).
  • The sphere moves with the bard while the effect lasts.
  • Creatures inside can still hear sounds coming from outside the sphere.
Still Night.name: Still Night
Still Night.spellEffect: Creates a sphere of absolute silence (20' diameter)

Stone to Flesh*.description:
This spell transforms one statue (or up to a 10' x 10' x 10' section of stone) into flesh. The spell is commonly used to restore a creature that has been petrified by effects such as a gorgon’s breath.

When cast on a petrified character, the recipient is restored with all previous abilities and equipment intact.
Stone to Flesh*.name: Stone to Flesh*

Stoneform.description:
This spell creates a mass of 1,000 cubic feet of stone, which the caster can shape into a variety of solid forms. The created stone is nonmagical and cannot be dispelled.

Shape & Casting Time:

  • A simple shape (wall, block, column) takes 1 round to form.
  • A basic structure (staircase, archway) takes 1 turn (10 minutes).
  • A complex design (statue, ornate fountain) takes up to 12 turns (2 hours).

The object must be a single solid piece with no moving parts. The caster may later use Stoneform to modify an existing creation for up to 2 hours. Once satisfied, the caster can finalize the form with a last casting, preventing further modification.

Restrictions & Properties:

  • The stone must rest on solid ground or similar support.
  • It cannot be formed in an occupied space.
  • Multiple castings can be seamlessly joined together.
  • The caster may choose the type of stone (within reason).
  • It is immune to dispel magic and lasts indefinitely unless physically destroyed.

Durability:

  • Stone walls have an AC of -4 (AC 6 if simplified) and 100 HP per 1' thickness.
  • Most exterior walls are about 7" thick and have 60 HP.
Stoneform.name: Stoneform

Storytelling.description: The Storytelling skill allows a character to weave captivating tales that can entertain, inspire, or impart wisdom. This skill is used to recount legends, share news, or persuade others through narrative. A successful Storytelling check can captivate an audience, spread information effectively, or even sway public opinion through the power of a well-told story.
Storytelling.name: Storytelling

Striking.description:
This spell allows any one weapon to inflict 1d6 additional points of damage per attack (similar to a magical staff of striking). The weapon will inflict this extra damage with every successful blow for as long as the spell lasts. This bonus does not apply to attack rolls, but only to damage rolls.

If the caster casts this spell on a normal weapon, the weapon may then damage creatures which are normally affected only by magic weapons; the weapon will do 1d6 points of damage per strike (regardless of the normal damage of the weapon).
Striking.name: Striking

Stunned.description:
Certain types of spells, attacks, or magical effects can stun a character. The duration of the stun is determined by the type of attack; the description of each type of attack that can stun will describe its duration.

A stunned character suffers the following penalties:

  1. The stunned character cannot attack anyone for the first turn he is stunned (or until the stun wears off, if that is faster); after the first turn, he is at a -4 to hit until the stun wears off.

  2. He moves at one-third the normal movement rate for whatever speed he is attempting.

  3. He suffers a -4 penalty to all his saving throws.

  4. He suffers a +4 penalty to his armor class (thus an AC 5 becomes a 9).

  5. He cannot concentrate, cast spells, or use magical items.

  6. He cannot use general skills.

  7. Any weapon mastery the character possesses above Basic level is reduced to Basic level.

The cleric spell cure light wounds can be used to remove the stun effect but will not cure any damage when used for this purpose.
Stunned.name: Stunned

Stunned (1 round).description:
With the one-round stuns caused in unarmed combat, the victim cannot make any attacks until the stun wears off. (In some other types of stun, the stun might go on awhile, allowing the stunned character to attack, ineffectually, after a certain amount of time has passed.)

Also, while stunned, the victim moves at one-third the normal movement rate for whatever speed he is attempting. He suffers a -4 penalty to all his saving throws. He suffers a +4 penalty to his armor class (thus an AC 5 becomes a 9). He cannot concentrate, cast spells, or use magical items. He cannot use general skills. Any weapon mastery skill he possesses above Basic level is reduced to Basic level.
Stunned (1 round).name: Stunned (1 round)

Suit Armor.description: This is a suit primarily composed of overlapping metal plates, with chain mail underneath. Also known as jousting plate, suit armor must be specially made to fit its owner—and is often worn by nobility as a status symbol as much as for protection. However, it does provide more protection than any other (non-magical) armor. Suit armor gives a character an armor class of 0, and also reduces all damage done to the character by area effect attacks (such as Fireball spells and dragon’s breath) by one point per die of damage. If the suit armor is magical, it reduces such damage by an additional point per two points of enhancement bonus. Unfortunately, since suit armor is designed for tourney use and parades where the wearer spends their time on horseback, it is very bulky and noisy when worn on foot. When on foot, someone wearing suit armor can he heard moving up to 120’ away, negating any chance of surprise; and only has a 1 in 6 chance per round of being able to stand unaided if knocked prone.
Suit Armor.name: Suit Armor
Suit Armor.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of overlapping metal plates, with chain mail underneath. Also known as jousting plate, suit armor must be specially made to fit its owner—and is often worn by nobility as a status symbol as much as for protection. However, it does provide more protection than any other (non-magical) armor. Suit armor gives a character an armor class of 0, and also reduces all damage done to the character by area effect attacks (such as Fireball spells and dragon’s breath) by one point per die of damage. If the suit armor is magical, it reduces such damage by an additional point per two points of enhancement bonus. Unfortunately, since suit armor is designed for tourney use and parades where the wearer spends their time on horseback, it is very bulky and noisy when worn on foot. When on foot, someone wearing suit armor can he heard moving up to 120’ away, negating any chance of surprise; and only has a 1 in 6 chance per round of being able to stand unaided if knocked prone.

Suit Armor +1.description:
This is a magic suit of armor primarily composed of overlapping metal plates, with chain mail underneath. Also known as jousting plate, suit armor must be specially made to fit its owner—and is often worn by nobility as a status symbol as much as for protection. However, it does provide more protection than any other (non-magical) armor. Suit armor gives a character an armor class of 0 plus magic bonus, and also reduces all damage done to the character by area effect attacks (such as Fireball spells and dragon’s breath) by one point per die of damage. If the suit armor is magical, it reduces such damage by an additional point per two points of enhancement bonus. Unfortunately, since suit armor is designed for tourney use and parades where the wearer spends their time on horseback, it is very bulky and noisy when worn on foot. When on foot, someone wearing suit armor can he heard moving up to 120’ away, negating any chance of surprise; and only has a 1 in 6 chance per round of being able to stand unaided if knocked prone.

Magic armor weighs half that of its nonmagic counterpart.
Suit Armor +1.name: Suit Armor +1
Suit Armor +1.unidentifiedDesc: This is a suit primarily composed of overlapping metal plates, with chain mail underneath. Also known as jousting plate, suit armor must be specially made to fit its owner—and is often worn by nobility as a status symbol as much as for protection. However, it does provide more protection than any other (non-magical) armor. Suit armor gives a character an armor class of 0, and also reduces all damage done to the character by area effect attacks (such as Fireball spells and dragon’s breath) by one point per die of damage. If the suit armor is magical, it reduces such damage by an additional point per two points of enhancement bonus. Unfortunately, since suit armor is designed for tourney use and parades where the wearer spends their time on horseback, it is very bulky and noisy when worn on foot. When on foot, someone wearing suit armor can he heard moving up to 120’ away, negating any chance of surprise; and only has a 1 in 6 chance per round of being able to stand unaided if knocked prone.

Summon Animals.description:
This spell allows the druid to summon any or all normal animals within 360'. Only normal, non-magical creatures of animal intelligence are affected, including mammals, reptiles, and amphibians. It does not affect insects, arthropods, humans, or demihumans.

Animal Types: The druid may summon specific types or every animal within range. The total Hit Dice of responding animals equals the druid’s level, with small creatures (frogs, mice, squirrels, small birds) treated as 1/10 HD each.

Behavior: Animals respond by coming at their fastest movement rate, understand the druid’s speech, and will assist the druid as able. If harmed, a summoned animal will usually flee, breaking the spell for that animal. If the druid is attacked as a summoned animal arrives, the animal will attack the druid’s opponent, fleeing only if it fails a morale check.

This spell can also be used to calm hostile animals encountered while adventuring.
Summon Animals.name: Summon Animals

Summon Elemental.description:
This spell summons a single 16 Hit Dice elemental to obey the druid’s commands.

Effects:

  • The caster may summon one elemental per casting (air, earth, fire, or water).
  • A druid may only summon one of each elemental type per day.
  • The elemental will understand spoken commands and will obey them within its abilities.
  • No concentration is needed to control the elemental.
  • The druid may dismiss the elemental at will, returning it to its home plane.
  • A dispel magic or dispel evil spell will also send the elemental back.
Summon Elemental.name: Summon Elemental

Summon Object.description:
This spell allows the caster to retrieve one nonliving object from their home, instantly summoning it into their hand. The object must meet the following conditions:

Object Requirements:

  • Weighs no more than 500 cn (50 lbs).
  • No larger than a staff or small chest.
  • The caster must be very familiar with the object and its exact location.
  • The object must have been prepared in advance by sprinkling it with a special powder costing 1,000 gp.

Spell Limitations:

  • The spell only summons one object at a time; contents of a chest do not travel with it.
  • If another being possesses the item, it will not appear, but the caster will know approximately who and where the possessor is.
  • The spell works from any location, even across different planes of existence.
Summon Object.name: Summon Object
Summon Object.spellEffect: Retrieves one object from caster's home

Summon Weather.description:
The druid magically pulls existing weather conditions from a nearby area to their location.

Effects:

  • The druid does not control the weather, but can summon an existing condition to their location.
  • At levels 12-15, the spell pulls weather from up to 5 miles away.
  • Each level beyond 15th adds 1 extra mile to the range (e.g., a 20th-level druid can summon weather from 10 miles away).
  • Only druids of 25th level or higher may summon severe weather (hurricanes, blizzards, etc.).
Summon Weather.name: Summon Weather

Survival (choose terrain).description: This skill allows the character to find food, shelter, and water in a single type of terrain (e.g., desert, forest/jungle, mountain/hill, open sea, plains, arctic). The character can forage automatically in fertile areas and uses the skill roll to determine success in searching for resources in more challenging environments. When supporting others, the character receives a +1 penalty to the roll per additional person.
Survival (choose terrain).name: Survival (choose terrain)

Survival@chuJwAFSZjZnW2qR.description:
This spell grants the recipient complete protection against all non-magical environmental hazards. While the spell is in effect, the recipient does not need air, food, water, or sleep.

Protection Includes:

  • Survival in extreme heat or cold (such as deserts or blizzards).
  • Breathing in airless environments (underground, underwater, space, etc.).
  • Survival in vacuum or toxic natural atmospheres.
  • Immunity to environmental damage from other planes (such as the Elemental Plane of Fire).

Limitations:

  • Does not protect against magical damage, including spells.
  • Does not prevent attack damage, poisons, breath weapons, or physical blows.
Survival@chuJwAFSZjZnW2qR.name: Survival
Survival@chuJwAFSZjZnW2qR.spellEffect: Protects one creature against all non-magical damage from the environment

Survival@nHQ68PUUgA9WCGxA.description:
This spell protects the recipient from all non-magical environmental damage, allowing them to endure extreme conditions without harm.

Protection Effects:

  • Prevents damage from normal heat or cold.
  • Eliminates the need for air, food, water, or sleep while active.
  • Protects against all natural environmental hazards, even in other planes of existence.

Limitations:

  • Does not protect against magical damage of any kind.
  • Does not prevent damage from attacks, poisons, breath weapons, or physical blows.

Example Uses:

  • Desert or Blizzard: Prevents harm from extreme temperatures.
  • Underwater or Underground: Enables survival without air.
  • Space Travel: Protects against vacuum exposure.
  • Elemental Plane of Fire: Prevents conditional fire damage from the natural environment.
Survival@nHQ68PUUgA9WCGxA.name: Survival
Survival@nHQ68PUUgA9WCGxA.spellEffect: Protects one creature against non-magical environmental damage

Swim.description: The Swim ability allows a character or creature to move through water, typically at a specified speed. It enables navigation in aquatic environments and may have limitations, such as the need for air or effects from water conditions.
Swim.name: Swim

Sword.description:
When this spell is cast, a glowing sword made of magical energy appears next to the caster. The caster may direct the sword to attack any creature within 30 feet simply by concentrating.

Combat Details:

  • The sword attacks twice per round.
  • It attacks using the caster's attack rolls and level.
  • Deals damage as a two-handed sword (1d10).
  • Can hit any target, including those requiring magical weapons to be harmed.

Rules & Mechanics:

  • The caster must concentrate to control the sword.
  • If concentration is broken, the sword stops attacking but remains in existence.
  • The sword remains for 1 round per caster level.
  • It cannot be destroyed except by Dispel Magic (normal success chance) or a Wish.
Sword.name: Sword

Sword, Bastard (1H) +1.description: A bastard sword, also known as a longsword, is a sword with a long (3’ to 4’) narrow blade that is used either one-handed or two-handed. The same weapon proficiency covers both forms of usage.
Sword, Bastard (1H) +1.name: Sword, Bastard (1H) +1
Sword, Bastard (1H) +1.unidentifiedDesc: A bastard sword, also known as a longsword, is a sword with a long (3’ to 4’) narrow blade that is used either one-handed or two-handed. The same weapon proficiency covers both forms of usage.

Sword, Bastard (2H) +1.description: A bastard sword, also known as a longsword, is a sword with a long (3’ to 4’) narrow blade that is used either one-handed or two-handed. The same weapon proficiency covers both forms of usage.

Sword, Bastard (2H)@9fob9ePbWx5SsdkS.name: Sword, Bastard (2H)
Sword, Bastard (2H)@9fob9ePbWx5SsdkS.unidentifiedDesc: A bastard sword, also known as a longsword, is a sword with a long (3’ to 4’) narrow blade that is used either one-handed or two-handed. The same weapon proficiency covers both forms of usage.

Sword, Normal +1.description: A normal sword is a one-handed sword with a straight or curved blade 2’ to 3’ long. This category of sword encompasses a variety of different styles of sword, ranging from scimitars to broadswords and even rapiers.
Sword, Normal +1.name: Sword, Normal +1
Sword, Normal +1.unidentifiedDesc: A normal sword is a one-handed sword with a straight or curved blade 2’ to 3’ long. This category of sword encompasses a variety of different styles of sword, ranging from scimitars to broadswords and even rapiers.

Sword, Normal +2.description: A normal sword is a one-handed sword with a straight or curved blade 2’ to 3’ long. This category of sword encompasses a variety of different styles of sword, ranging from scimitars to broadswords and even rapiers.
Sword, Normal +2.name: Sword, Normal +2
Sword, Normal +2.unidentifiedDesc: A normal sword is a one-handed sword with a straight or curved blade 2’ to 3’ long. This category of sword encompasses a variety of different styles of sword, ranging from scimitars to broadswords and even rapiers.

Sword, Short +1.description: A short sword is a sword with a straight 18” to 2’ blade. Primarily used as a stabbing rather than slashing weapon, this small blade can be used in one hand.
Sword, Short +1.name: Sword, Short +1
Sword, Short +1.unidentifiedDesc: A short sword is a sword with a straight 18” to 2’ blade. Primarily used as a stabbing rather than slashing weapon, this small blade can be used in one hand.

Sword, Short@5Ymnj5Zixi4qy6r3.description: A short sword is a sword with a straight 18” to 2’ blade. Primarily used as a stabbing rather than slashing weapon, this small blade can be used in one hand.
Sword, Short@5Ymnj5Zixi4qy6r3.name: Sword, Short
Sword, Short@5Ymnj5Zixi4qy6r3.unidentifiedDesc: A short sword is a sword with a straight 18” to 2’ blade. Primarily used as a stabbing rather than slashing weapon, this small blade can be used in one hand.

Sword, Two-Handed +1.description:
This weapon, also called the great sword, is the largest type of sword. It is similar to the normal sword (above) but much longer, usually being 4 1/2' to 6 1/2' long.

This sword is a two-handed weapon; the wielder of the weapon may not use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters not using a two-handed weapon. Halflings and small nonhumans such as goblins cannot use this weapon.
Sword, Two-Handed +1.name: Sword, Two-Handed +1
Sword, Two-Handed +1.unidentifiedDesc:
This weapon, also called the great sword, is the largest type of sword. It is similar to the normal sword (above) but much longer, usually being 4 1/2' to 6 1/2' long.

This sword is a two-handed weapon; the wielder of the weapon may not use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters not using a two-handed weapon. Halflings and small nonhumans such as goblins cannot use this weapon.
