This sword is a two-handed weapon; the wielder of the weapon may not use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters not using a two-handed weapon. Halflings and small nonhumans such as goblins cannot use this weapon.
Sword, Two-Handed@zCLw6dqJW8j5LITE.name: Sword, Two-Handed
Sword, Two-Handed@zCLw6dqJW8j5LITE.unidentifiedDesc:
This weapon, also called the great sword, is the largest type of sword. It is similar to the normal sword (above) but much longer, usually being 4 1/2' to 6 1/2' long.

This sword is a two-handed weapon; the wielder of the weapon may not use a shield and always loses individual initiative to characters not using a two-handed weapon. Halflings and small nonhumans such as goblins cannot use this weapon.

Symbol.description:
This spell creates a written magical drawing (a rune) of great power. The caster must choose one of six possible symbols when memorizing the spell. The rune may be placed on an object (such as a door or wall) or even in mid-air, but it remains fixed in place and cannot move.

When any living creature:

  • Passes over or through the rune
  • Touches the object bearing the rune
  • Reads the rune (foolishly)

The rune's effect takes place immediately, with no saving throw.

Saving Throw Exception:

A magic-user or any creature capable of casting magic-user spells may make a saving throw vs. spells if they merely read or touch the symbol (rather than pass through it). If the save succeeds, the symbol has no effect.

Symbol Effects:

There are six standard symbol types:

  • Death: Instantly slays any creature with 75 HP or less. Creatures with 76+ HP are unaffected.
  • Discord: Causes the victim to attack allies or suffer confusion (as the confusion spell). Permanent until removed by dispel magic or a cleric's cureall spell.
  • Fear: The victim flees at full Running Speed for 30 rounds (as a wand of fear).
  • Insanity: The victim becomes insane, unable to attack, cast spells, or use special abilities or items. The effect is permanent until removed by dispel magic or a cleric's cureall spell.
  • Sleep: The victim falls into an unbreakable sleep and cannot be awakened except by dispel magic or waiting [[/r 1d10+10 #Hours asleep]] hours.
  • Stunning: Affects creatures with 150 HP or less, stunning them for [[/r 2d6 #Turns stunned]] (as power word stun).

Additional Notes:

  • All symbols appear to be normal writings.
  • The rune remains active permanently until triggered or dispelled.
  • The DM may introduce additional symbols with effects such as polymorph, teleport, charm, or geas.
Symbol.name: Symbol

Telekinesis.description:
This spell allows the caster to move a creature or object by sheer concentration. The weight of the object can be up to 200 cn (20 lbs) per caster level. For example, a 10th-level caster could move an object up to 2,000 cn (200 lbs).

The object can be moved in any direction at a rate of up to 20' per round. The caster must concentrate, and the movement stops if concentration is broken.

Saving Throws: An unwilling creature may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid being moved. If an item is being held, the holder may make a saving throw with a -2 penalty. For items carried but not held, the owner may attempt to grab it with a saving throw at a -5 penalty.
Telekinesis.name: Telekinesis
Telekinesis.spellEffect: 200 cn of weight per level of caster

Teleport Any Object.description:
This spell functions similarly to the Teleport spell, but it affects nonliving objects in addition to creatures. The spellcaster must touch the target object or creature, causing it to instantly teleport to the chosen location.

Teleportation Mechanics:

  • Chance of Error: If teleporting an object, the standard teleport error rules apply.
  • Too High: The object falls and may break.
  • Too Low: The object is instantly destroyed.
  • If the caster teleports himself, there is no chance for error.
  • The destination must be a solid surface. The caster cannot deliberately teleport an object into another solid object or into open air.

Weight Limitations:

  • The caster may teleport objects up to 500 cn (50 lbs) per caster level.
  • If teleporting a solid part of a larger object (such as a section of a wall), the spell affects a maximum of 10' x 10' x 10' of material.
  • If the object or creature exceeds the weight limit, the spell fails.

Resisting the Teleport:

  • If the object is held or carried by another creature, that creature may make a saving throw vs. spells (at -2) to prevent the teleport.
  • If the caster targets a creature, the creature may choose to make a saving throw vs. spells (at -2) to resist the effect.
Teleport Any Object.name: Teleport Any Object

Teleport@9odcKQwwvJit7xwl.description:
This spell instantly transports the caster or another creature within 10' to any unoccupied destination on the same plane. Distance does not matter, and the recipient arrives at the destination with all carried equipment. An unwilling target can make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid teleportation.

Restrictions on Destination: The caster cannot deliberately teleport to an occupied space, and must choose a solid surface for arrival (such as ground level or a building top), not mid-air.

Teleportation Accuracy: Teleporting carries a risk of inaccuracy based on the caster’s familiarity with the location. Familiarity levels—Casual, General, and Exact—impact the chance of success. The DM rolls d% and consults the table below.

Knowledge of DestinationSuccessToo HighToo Low
Casual (visited once or twice, or by description)01-5051-7576-00
General (visited often or studied magically)01-8081-9091-00
Exact (detailed personal study)01-9596-9900

Teleport Results:

  • Success: The recipient arrives at the chosen location.
  • Too High: The recipient arrives 1d10 x 10' above the destination, taking 1d6 points of damage per 10' fallen, unless flying or levitating.
  • Too Low: The recipient arrives 1d10 x 10' below the destination. Teleporting into solid objects results in instant death unless an open area (e.g., a cave) exists there, at the DM's discretion.
Teleport@9odcKQwwvJit7xwl.name: Teleport

Teleport@DopHWlFppHP2WGmD.description: The Teleport ability allows a character or creature to instantly move from one location to another without traversing the space in between, as long as the new location is within their sight or a known place.
Teleport@DopHWlFppHP2WGmD.name: Teleport

The Epic.description:
This spell-song allows the bard to create a realistic and awe-inspiring battle scene through illusionary magic. Those who witness it must resist its effects or be stunned in amazement.

Effects:

  • The bard creates an illusion of a battle scene anywhere within range, covering an area of 20' x 20' x 20'.
  • All creatures that see it must make a saving throw vs. spells or be stunned for [[/r 1d4 #Stunned rounds]].
  • The illusion can depict warriors, wizards, or entire armies, shaped by the bard’s imagination.

Illusion Mechanics:

  • Anyone interacting with the illusion may attempt a new saving throw vs. spells to see through it.
  • The illusion has an armor class of 9 and disappears when touched.
  • If a creature "dies" within the illusion, they instead fall unconscious for [[/r 1d6 #Unconscious rounds]].

Additional Details:

  • The bard controls all visual elements of the illusion but cannot create sound or physical interaction.
  • Like phantasmal force, this illusion can trick enemies into reacting as if it were real.
  • The illusion remains for the spell’s duration unless dispelled or disbelieved.
The Epic.name: The Epic
The Epic.spellEffect: Creates an illusory battle scene that stuns onlookers

The Eternal Wanderer.description:
By singing this enchanted melody, the bard grants themselves and nearby allies the ability to travel with supernatural endurance and speed.

Effects:

  • All affected creatures have their movement rates tripled for the duration.
  • While moving under this effect, recipients do not tire and suffer no fatigue.
  • Travelers may cover great distances in a short time, with no physical strain.

Rest Requirement:

After the spell ends, all affected creatures must rest for a duration equal to the time spent traveling under its effects.

Range & Area of Effect:

The spell affects the bard and all allies within 10 feet, plus an additional 2 feet per level of the bard.
The Eternal Wanderer.name: The Eternal Wanderer
The Eternal Wanderer.spellEffect: Triples movement speed and prevents fatigue

The Hero's Chant.description:
This spell-song functions similarly to a bless spell, providing combat and morale benefits to the bard and nearby allies. However, the bard must continue singing for the effect to remain active.

Effects:

  • All affected creatures gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls and +1 to damage rolls.
  • They also gain a +1 bonus to all saving throws.
  • Morale is improved, granting a +1 bonus to morale checks.

Duration:

  • The bard may sing for a number of rounds equal to his or her Constitution score.
  • If the bard exceeds this limit, he or she will fall unconscious for 1d4 turns [[/r 1d4 #Unconscious Turns]].
  • If the bard stops singing before reaching the limit, there are no ill effects.

Area of Effect:

  • Affects the bard and all allies within 10' + 2' per bard level.
The Hero's Chant.name: The Hero's Chant

The Seeker of Magic.description:
This mystical song reveals the magical nature of all enchanted items within a 20' x 20' x 20' area. All magical items, including those being worn or carried, will emit a soft blue halo for the duration of the spell.

Effects:

  • All magical items within the area glow with a blue halo.
  • Chance to Identify: The bard has a 3% chance per level to correctly identify the exact nature of a magical item.
  • Limitations: The bard cannot determine the number of charges an item has (if any).
The Seeker of Magic.name: The Seeker of Magic
The Seeker of Magic.spellEffect: Reveals the magical nature of items in a 20' x 20' x 20' area

Thief.description:
A thief is a human adventurer specializing in stealth, agility, and subterfuge. They excel in tasks like lockpicking, trap disarming, and infiltration, relying on dexterity and cunning to navigate challenges rather than brute force.

Key Characteristics:

  • Prime Requisite: Dexterity, granting a 5% experience bonus for scores of 13–15 and 10% for 16 or higher.
  • Combat Skills: Thieves may use any one-handed melee weapon and missile weapons but cannot wield two-handed weapons. They are restricted to leather armor and cannot use shields.
  • Hit Dice: Thieves roll a d4 for hit points per level until 9th level, after which they gain 2 hit points per level.

  • Special Abilities:

    • Open Locks, Find and Remove Traps, Climb Walls, Move Silently, Hide in Shadows, Pick Pockets, and Hear Noise.
    • At 4th level, they can read non-magical languages (80% chance).
    • At 10th level, they can cast magic-user spells from scrolls (10% chance of backfire).
    • Backstabbing: A thief gains +4 to attack rolls when unnoticed and deals double damage on a successful hit.

Advancement:

  • At 9th level, a thief becomes a "Master Thief" and may establish a hideout, such as a fortified house or network of secret chambers.
  • The hideout attracts 2d6 1st-level apprentice thieves who seek training under the master thief.
  • A thief may rise in the ranks of the Thieves' Guild, eventually leading a branch or even the guild itself.

Stronghold Options:

  • Thieves often rely on the local Thieves' Guild for resources when establishing a hideout. The guild may help them become a guildmaster or expand into new territories.
  • If the thief remains unaffiliated, they are considered a rogue, maintaining guild membership for support but operating independently.

Thieves thrive on their agility, sharp wits, and resourcefulness, providing unique skills to adventuring parties while navigating the fine line between heroics and illicit activity.
Thief.name: Thief

Thieves' Tools.description: Required for picking locks, these items are usable only by thieves. A typical set includes fine wire, various lockpicks, etc. Although the tools may be used many times if successful, they will break on failure. There are enough lockpicks and other components for 10 uses.
Thieves' Tools.name: Thieves' Tools
Thieves' Tools.unidentifiedDesc: Required for picking locks, these items are usable only by thieves. A typical set includes fine wire, various lockpicks, etc. Although the tools may be used many times if successful, they will break on failure. There are enough lockpicks and other components for 10 uses.

Timestop.description:
This powerful spell allows the caster to act freely while everything else seems frozen in time. The caster gains 1d4 + 1 rounds of action, during which other creatures and objects appear motionless.

Effects:

  • From the caster's perspective, time stops, granting [[/r 1d4+1 #Timestop Rounds]] of free actions.
  • The caster may perform one action per magical round while the spell is active.
  • Other creatures are invulnerable to attacks and spells while under the spell's effect.
  • Spells with durations other than instantaneous can be cast and will take effect when time resumes.

Limitations:

  • The caster can still be harmed by magical and non-magical fire, cold, gas, and similar effects.
  • The caster cannot interact with objects held by frozen creatures.
  • The caster can move objects that are not fixed, including those worn or carried by others.
  • The spellcaster is completely undetectable by those in normal time.
  • The caster cannot pass through a protection from evil or anti-magic shell while the spell is active.
Timestop.name: Timestop
Timestop.spellEffect: Allows caster to act freely while time stops

Tinder Box.description: A small box containing flint, steel, and tinder (wood shavings). Used to start fires for camp or torches. Under dry conditions, a fire starts on a roll of 1 or 2 on a d6. May be tried once per round.
Tinder Box.name: Tinder Box
Tinder Box.unidentifiedDesc: A small box containing flint, steel, and tinder (wood shavings). Used to start fires for camp or torches. Under dry conditions, a fire starts on a roll of 1 or 2 on a d6. May be tried once per round.

Topaz.description: Topaz is a gemstone that can appear in golden-yellow or light blue colors. It has a smooth, polished surface with a brilliant, faceted appearance, showcasing its clarity and reflective properties. Topaz is prized for its vibrant hue and sparkling brilliance, making it a popular choice in jewelry.
Topaz.name: Topaz
Topaz.unidentifiedDesc: Topaz is a gemstone that can appear in golden-yellow or light blue colors. It has a smooth, polished surface with a brilliant, faceted appearance, showcasing its clarity and reflective properties. Topaz is prized for its vibrant hue and sparkling brilliance, making it a popular choice in jewelry.

Torch.description: This is any 1' to 2' long piece of wood, its head sometimes covered with an inflammable substance such as pitch. It casts light in a 30' radius and burns for one hour (six turns). See the description from the Weapons Table for information on using a torch as a weapon; clerics can use it as a weapon.
Torch.name: Torch
Torch.unidentifiedDesc: This is any 1' to 2' long piece of wood, its head sometimes covered with an inflammable substance such as pitch. It casts light in a 30' radius and burns for one hour (six turns). See the description from the Weapons Table for information on using a torch as a weapon; clerics can use it as a weapon.

Torch (weapon).description: This is just a regular torch, but wielded as a weapon. If the torch is unlit, then it only does 1d2 damage. The torch is considered to be a flaming club, and is covered under the club weapon mastery.
Torch (weapon).name: Torch (weapon)
Torch (weapon).unidentifiedDesc: This is just a regular torch, but wielded as a weapon. If the torch is unlit, then it only does 1d2 damage. The torch is considered to be a flaming club, and is covered under the club weapon mastery.

Tracking.description: The character can follow tracks. The DM may adjust the chance of success depending on the circumstances such as age of the tracks, type of terrain, number of tracks being followed, and other factors. A successful skill check indicates the character has successfully followed the tracks to their destination or the next significant point.
Tracking.name: Tracking

Transport Through Plants.description:
The druid magically teleports from one plant to another anywhere in the world.

Effects:

  • The druid steps into a living plant and emerges from another plant elsewhere.
  • The destination plant may be specifically chosen or randomly determined by the DM.
  • Unlimited range, but both plants must be on the same plane of existence.
  • If either plant is dead, the spell fails.
  • The caster may bring up to two willing creatures through the transport.
  • May be cast once per day.
Transport Through Plants.name: Transport Through Plants

Travel@0YsvPReEgJGz7v1P.description:
This spell grants the caster incredible mobility, allowing flight, planar travel, and even transformation into gaseous form.

Effects:

  • The caster can fly at a rate of 360' (120'), similar to the Fly spell.
  • Once per turn, the caster may shift into a nearby plane by concentrating for one round.
  • The cleric may bring one additional creature per 5 levels (rounded down), provided they are touching at the moment of planar travel.
  • Unwilling creatures may make a saving throw vs. spells to resist being taken.

Gaseous Form:

  • By concentrating for one full round, the caster may become gaseous.
  • In gaseous form, the caster and all carried equipment transform into mist.
  • While gaseous, the cleric may move at 720' (240') but cannot attack, cast spells, or use items.
  • In this form, the caster is immune to non-magical damage but cannot pass through a Protection from Evil spell or Anti-Magic Shell.
Travel@0YsvPReEgJGz7v1P.name: Travel

Travel@iQALAILzrYSGlnyf.description:
This spell grants the caster great mobility, including aerial flight, planar travel, and the ability to become gaseous. It lasts for one turn per caster level.

Flight:

  • The caster can fly as per the Fly spell, at a speed of 360' (120').

Planar Travel:

  • The caster can enter a nearby plane of existence by concentrating for one round.
  • A maximum of one plane per turn can be traversed.
  • The caster may bring one additional creature per five levels (rounded down).
  • To bring others, they must be touching the caster at the moment of transition.
  • Unwilling creatures may make a saving throw vs. spells to resist the effect.
  • The caster cannot send others while remaining behind—he must accompany them.

Gaseous Form:

  • The caster may assume gaseous form by concentrating for one full round.
  • If interrupted, no transformation occurs.
  • Unlike the potion of gaseous form, all carried equipment transforms as well.
  • In gaseous form, the caster moves at double flight speed (720' / 240').
  • The caster cannot use items or cast spells while gaseous.
  • Only magical attacks (weapons or spells) can harm the caster in gaseous form.
  • The caster cannot pass through a Protection from Evil effect or an Anti-Magic Shell.
Travel@iQALAILzrYSGlnyf.name: Travel

Trident +1.description: A trident is a short (4’ to 6’) spear which is split at the end into three tines, like a fork. Each tine is usually barbed. A trident is used in one hand either in melee or as a thrown weapon, and is often used as a fishing spear, since the barbs on the points can lift the fish out of the water when the trident is withdrawn.
Trident +1.name: Trident +1
Trident +1.unidentifiedDesc: A trident is a short (4’ to 6’) spear which is split at the end into three tines, like a fork. Each tine is usually barbed. A trident is used in one hand either in melee or as a thrown weapon, and is often used as a fishing spear, since the barbs on the points can lift the fish out of the water when the trident is withdrawn.

A trident is used in one hand either in melee or as a thrown weapon, and is often used as a fishing spear, since the barbs on the points can lift the fish out of the water when the trident is withdrawn.
Trident@yxTxTKRhWTzhjYZu.name: Trident
Trident@yxTxTKRhWTzhjYZu.unidentifiedDesc: A trident is a short (4’ to 6’) spear which is split at the end into three tines, like a fork. Each tine is usually barbed. A trident is used in one hand either in melee or as a thrown weapon, and is often used as a fishing spear, since the barbs on the points can lift the fish out of the water when the trident is withdrawn.

Troglodyte Stench.description: The stench of a troglodyte can cause a -2 penalty to all attack rolls in melee combat.
Troglodyte Stench.name: Troglodyte Stench

Truesight.description:
With *Truesight*, the cleric gains the ability to see all things as they truly are within a 120' radius. The spell reveals all hidden, invisible, and ethereal objects or creatures, functioning as the *detect invisible* spell.

Additionally, the cleric perceives any secret doors, and can see through any form of disguise, polymorph, or other alterations. Deception is impossible. The spell also reveals creatures' alignments, experience, and power levels.
Truesight.name: Truesight
Truesight.spellEffect: Reveals true forms of all things within 120'

Turn Undead (AV).description:
Rule: An avenger can turn undead, as if he were a cleric of one-third his actual experience level (round all fractions down).

Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Paladin / Avenger's Level
Undead9-1112-1415-1718-2021-2324-2627-3233-36
SkeletonTDDDDDDD+
ZombieTTDDDDDD
Ghoul7TTDDDDD
Wight97TTDDDD
Wraith1197TTDDD
Mummy--1197TTDD
Spectre----1197TTD
Vampire------1197TT
Phantom--------1197T
Haunt----------1197
Spirit------------119
Nightshade--------------11
Lich----------------
Special----------------

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.

An Avenger can turn undead as a cleric of one-third their level, but with a key difference. If the result is "turn" or "destroy," the Avenger may instead choose to control the undead. This control lasts for 1 turn per Avenger level—for example, a 17th-level Avenger could maintain control for 17 turns. While controlled, the undead behave as if charmed, obeying the Avenger as if they were allies.

If a cleric successfully turns or destroys the undead during the control's duration, the effect is immediately broken and cannot be renewed. However, if the control expires naturally, the undead will flee as if turned.
Turn Undead (AV).name: Turn Undead (AV)

Turn Undead (C).description:
Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Cleric's Level
Undead123456789-1011-1213-1415-1617-2021-2425-2829-3233-36
Skeleton7TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+D+D#D#D#
Zombie97TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+D+D#D#
Ghoul1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+D+D#
Wight--1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+D+
Wraith----1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+D+
Mummy------1197TTDDDDDDD+D+D+
Spectre--------1197TTDDDDDDD+D+
Vampire----------1197TTDDDDDDD+
Phantom------------1197TTDDDDDD

Spirit----------------1197TTDDDD
Nightshade------------------1197TTDDD
Lich--------------------1197TTTT
Special----------------------1197TTT

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D#: Automatic destroy; destroys 4d6 Hit Dice of undead.

Clerics have the divine power to repel or even destroy certain undead creatures, such as skeletons, zombies, and more powerful types. This ability is known as Turn Undead. When encountering these undead beings, the cleric can choose to either engage them in combat with weapons or spells, or attempt to turn them.

To turn undead, the cleric simply announces the intention to do so to the Dungeon Master. No holy symbol or other item is needed unless the DM specifies otherwise. The success of this attempt depends on the cleric’s level and the type of undead faced, as indicated on the Turning Undead table.

If the cleric succeeds, one or more undead creatures will flee or be destroyed immediately, depending on the result. However, a failed attempt means that particular undead creature cannot be turned by the cleric again during the same encounter. Multiple attempts are allowed in future encounters.

Should the attempt succeed, the Dungeon Master rolls to determine how many Hit Dice worth of undead are turned. At least one undead creature will always be affected. A turned undead creature will retreat as far as possible, but it has not been destroyed and may return after some time.
Turn Undead (C).name: Turn Undead (C)

Turn Undead (PA).description:
Rule: A paladin can turn undead, as if he were a cleric of one-third his actual experience level (round all fractions down).

Roll [[/r 2d6 #Turn Undead]] for entries with numbers.

Paladin / Avenger's Level

Nightshade--------------11

Notes:

  • 7, 9, or 11: Number needed to turn successfully.
  • T: Automatic turn; turns 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D: Automatic destroy; destroys 2d6 Hit Dice of undead.
  • D+: Automatic destroy; destroys 3d6 Hit Dice of undead.

A Paladin can turn undead as a cleric of one-third their level, rounding down. For example, a 6th or 7th level Paladin turns undead with the ability of a 2nd-level cleric.
Turn Undead (PA).name: Turn Undead (PA)

Turn Wood.description:
With this spell, the druid creates an invisible wave of magical force that repels all wooden objects within range. The wave originates within 30 feet of the caster and extends into a 120-foot-long and 60-foot-tall area in a direction chosen by the druid.

Once the wave is created, it immediately begins moving in a straight line at a rate of 10 feet per round. The druid may halt the wave at any time, but once stopped, it remains stationary for the remainder of the spell’s duration and cannot be moved again.

Effects of the Wave

  • All wooden objects touched by the wave become stuck to it and are pushed along as it moves.
  • Objects caught in the wave are not damaged, but they are effectively unusable while trapped.
  • Any wooden weapons (such as bows, crossbows, spears, javelins, clubs, quarterstaffs, and slings) become useless while within the effect.
  • Magical wooden items (such as wands and staves) are also caught in the wave, unless they are being actively wielded by a creature with a stronger magical force than the wave itself (at the DM’s discretion).
  • Wooden doors, gates, and barriers are unaffected unless not securely fastened—a loose wooden fence might be swept along, while a sturdy wooden door in a stone wall would remain in place.

Applications & Limitations

  • The wave cannot move permanent wooden constructions (such as buildings, wooden towers, or firmly rooted trees).
  • Secured wooden objects, such as a wooden door locked within a stone frame, will not be affected.
  • The druid does not need to concentrate to maintain the effect; however, they may dismiss the wave early by concentrating for one full round.
  • The wave continues to move forward until it reaches the maximum range of 360 feet, at which point it stops and remains fixed in place for the rest of the spell’s duration.

This spell is highly effective in mass combat scenarios, particularly against archers, cavalry, or siege engines. It is also useful in naval battles, as it can push away wooden rowboats, masts, or cargo.
Turn Wood.name: Turn Wood

Turn to Stone or Paralysis.description: The saving throw against "Stone or Paralysis" protects a character from attacks or effects that could freeze them in place (paralysis) or turn them into stone. If the saving throw is failed, the character becomes immobilized or petrified, depending on the effect. Paralysis leaves a character aware but unable to act, while petrification turns the character and their carried equipment into a stone statue. The duration or permanence of these effects is specified by the source, and successful saving throws avoid them entirely​​​.
Turn to Stone or Paralysis.name: Turn to Stone or Paralysis

Turquoise.description: Turquoise is a vibrant blue-green gemstone often featuring natural veining or matrix patterns. It has a smooth, polished surface and is highly valued for its striking color and unique texture, making it popular in jewelry and decorative arts.
Turquoise.name: Turquoise
Turquoise.unidentifiedDesc: Turquoise is a vibrant blue-green gemstone often featuring natural veining or matrix patterns. It has a smooth, polished surface and is highly valued for its striking color and unique texture, making it popular in jewelry and decorative arts.

Unarmed Strike.description: During the hand-to-hand combat phase of a combat round, a player may strike their target with their fist, foot (kick), head (butt), elbow, or knee. If the attacker intends to use their fist, they must be empty-handed, or may drop or put away an item in their striking hand.
Unarmed Strike.name: Unarmed Strike

Unarmed Strike (MY).description:

Unarmed Strike (MY).name: Unarmed Strike (MY)

Use Magic Items (M).description: Magic-Users can utilize various magical items, such as wands, staves, and scrolls, that are typically unavailable to non-spellcasting classes. This ability allows them to activate magical effects stored within these items.
Use Magic Items (M).name: Use Magic Items (M)

Ventriloquism.description: This spell allows the caster to make their voice seem to come from another location within range, such as a statue, animal, or a dark corner. The "source" of the voice must be within the spell's range.
Ventriloquism.name: Ventriloquism

Veterinary Healing.description:
This skill is similar to the Healing skill but pertains to creatures other than humans or demihumans, such as monsters, animals, and other nonhuman creatures. A successful skill roll allows the character to restore [[/r 1d3 #Veterinary Healing (Hit Points Restored)]] hit points to a creature. This skill can be taken in two ways:

  • General Veterinary Healing: A +1 penalty applies for each type of creature the character treats.
  • Specialized Veterinary Healing: Pertains to one specific class of creatures (e.g., equines), with no penalty for that class but a +2 penalty for all others.

A character with this skill who attempts to treat humans or demihumans must roll with a +3 penalty.
Veterinary Healing.name: Veterinary Healing

Vial (glass).description: A small, clear glass vial commonly used to store liquids, potions, or other substances. It is fragile and can easily break if dropped or struck. This vial can hold up to 8 ounces of liquid.
Vial (glass).name: Vial (glass)
Vial (glass).unidentifiedDesc: A small, clear glass vial commonly used to store liquids, potions, or other substances. It is fragile and can easily break if dropped or struck. This vial can hold up to 8 ounces of liquid.

View From Afar.description:
This spell-song grants the bard the ability to perceive distant locations, much like a crystal ball.

Effects:

  • Allows the bard to see a location up to five miles away.
  • The bard must know the name of the location and provide a brief description to focus on it.
  • The bard can rotate their point of view up to 360 degrees but cannot move.
  • By naming new locations, the bard can switch views within the spell’s duration, though this is less precise than a wizard eye.

Limitations:

  • The bard cannot see through solid objects.
  • Locations protected by magical wards or enchantments are blocked.
  • The bard enters a trance-like state while the spell is active, completely unaware of their surroundings.
  • If the bard takes any damage, their concentration is broken and the spell immediately ends.
View From Afar.name: View From Afar
View From Afar.spellEffect: Allows the bard to remotely view distant locations

Wall of Fire.description:
This spell creates a thin, vertical wall of fire in any shape or dimension, totaling 1,200 square feet (e.g., 10' x 120', 20' x 60', 30' x 40'). The wall is opaque and blocks sight, and it cannot be created in a space already occupied by another object.

Duration: The wall remains as long as the caster concentrates on it without moving.

Breaking Through: Creatures with less than 4 Hit Dice cannot pass through the wall. Creatures with 4 HD or more may pass through, taking 1d6 fire damage in the process. Undead and cold-using creatures (e.g., white dragons, frost giants) each take double damage (2d6) when breaking through.
Wall of Fire.name: Wall of Fire

Wall of Ice.description:
This spell creates a thin, opaque wall of ice covering up to 1,200 square feet (e.g., 10' x 120' or 30' x 40'). The caster chooses the shape, but the wall must rest on the ground or similar support and cannot overlap with other objects.

Breaking Through: Creatures with less than 4 Hit Dice cannot break through the wall. Creatures with 4 HD or more can break through, taking 1d6 damage in the process. Fire-type creatures suffer double damage (2d6) when breaking through.
Wall of Ice.name: Wall of Ice

Wall of Iron.description:
This spell creates a vertical iron wall within 120' of the caster. The wall must rest on solid ground or similar support and cannot be conjured into an occupied space.

Wall Size:

  • 2' thick, up to 500 square feet in total area.
  • Examples: 10' x 50', 20' x 25', etc.

Durability & Effects:

  • The wall is permanent unless disintegrated, dispelled, or physically broken.
  • It resists all but giant-sized physical attacks.
  • Immune to most spells, including fireball and lightning bolt.
  • A rust monster destroys the wall instantly.

Physical Damage:

  • If toppled, the wall deals [[/r 10d10 #Damage from wall of iron toppling.]] (10-100) damage to whatever it hits.
  • For battering attacks, see Chapter 9 (page 118).

Hit Points: The wall has hit points equal to the caster's level.
Wall of Iron.name: Wall of Iron

Wall of Stone.description:
This spell creates a vertical stone wall, 2' thick. The caster selects the wall’s dimensions and shape, up to a maximum area of 500 square feet (e.g., 10' x 50', 20' x 25'). The entire wall must be within 60' of the caster.

Placement and Durability: The wall must be created on the ground or a similar support and cannot occupy a space that already contains another object. The wall lasts until it is either dispelled or physically broken.

Falling Wall: If the wall topples, it causes 10d10 damage to whatever it hits and then shatters.
Wall of Stone.name: Wall of Stone

Wand of Cold.description:
This wand creates a cone of cold, 60' long and 30' wide at the far end. All within the cone take 6d6 points of cold damage, but they may make a saving throw vs. wands for half damage.

This dark, polished wand feels heavy in your hand, its surface etched with frost-like patterns. The tip is capped with a translucent blue crystal that resembles ice, and a faint mist occasionally emanates from it, hinting at the chilling power within.
Wand of Cold.name: Wand of Cold
Wand of Cold.unidentifiedDesc: This dark, polished wand feels heavy in your hand, its surface etched with frost-like patterns. The tip is capped with a translucent blue crystal that resembles ice, and a faint mist occasionally emanates from it, hinting at the chilling power within.

Wand of Enemy Detection.description:
When a charge is expended, this item causes all enemies within 60 feet (including those who are hidden or invisible) to emit a glowing light, as if they were aflame.

This wand is crafted from dark, smooth wood, featuring a slightly twisted design. At the tip, a striking gem shaped like an eyeball glows with a fiery red hue, while faint, glowing runes spiral along its length.
Wand of Enemy Detection.name: Wand of Enemy Detection
Wand of Enemy Detection.unidentifiedDesc: This wand is crafted from dark, smooth wood, featuring a slightly twisted design. At the tip, a striking gem shaped like an eyeball glows with a fiery red hue, while faint, glowing runes spiral along its length

Wand of Fear.description:
This wand generates a cone of fear that extends 60 feet long and 30 feet wide at its far end. Anyone caught within the cone must make a saving throw against wands or flee from the user at three times their normal speed for 30 rounds.

This wand is crafted from dark, polished wood, featuring a sleek and slightly curved design. At the end, it is adorned with a menacing skull motif, intricately carved and detailed, giving it a foreboding presence. The skull's eye sockets glow faintly with an eerie light, while the shaft of the wand is etched with subtle, arcane symbols.
Wand of Fear.name: Wand of Fear
Wand of Fear.unidentifiedDesc: This wand is crafted from dark, polished wood, featuring a sleek and slightly curved design. At the end, it is adorned with a menacing skull motif, intricately carved and detailed, giving it a foreboding presence. The skull's eye sockets glow faintly with an eerie light, while the shaft of the wand is etched with subtle, arcane symbols.

Wand of Illusion (M).description:
A Wand of Illusion is a magical item that allows the user to create a phantasmal force effect, similar to the magic-user spell. To maintain the illusion, the user must concentrate, which limits their movement to half of their normal speed. This wand is useful for creating distractions, deceiving enemies, or crafting elaborate visual effects to enhance storytelling and gameplay.

This slender, iridescent rod is about two feet long, adorned with intricate runes that shimmer softly in the light. The tip features a multifaceted crystal that sparkles like a prism, casting tiny rainbows around it. Cool to the touch, the wand hums with a faint, magical energy, inviting curiosity and wonder. Its elegant design hints at hidden potential.
Wand of Illusion (M).name: Wand of Illusion (M)
Wand of Illusion (M).unidentifiedDesc: This slender, iridescent rod is about two feet long, adorned with intricate runes that shimmer softly in the light. The tip features a multifaceted crystal that sparkles like a prism, casting tiny rainbows around it. Cool to the touch, the wand hums with a faint, magical energy, inviting curiosity and wonder. Its elegant design hints at hidden potential.

Wand of Secret Door Detection (M).description:
The user may find any secrer door within 20', using one charge per secret door found.

This elegantly crafted wand is made from a shimmering silver wood, adorned with intricate carvings of ancient symbols. Its tip glows faintly with a soft, ethereal light, pulsating gently as if alive. When held, the wand seems to hum with a subtle energy, guiding its wielder with an intuitive warmth. A delicate crystal embedded in the handle refracts light in mesmerizing patterns, hinting at its hidden abilities.
Wand of Secret Door Detection (M).name: Wand of Secret Door Detection (M)
Wand of Secret Door Detection (M).unidentifiedDesc: This elegantly crafted wand is made from a shimmering silver wood, adorned with intricate carvings of ancient symbols. Its tip glows faintly with a soft, ethereal light, pulsating gently as if alive. When held, the wand seems to hum with a subtle energy, guiding its wielder with an intuitive warmth. A delicate crystal embedded in the handle refracts light in mesmerizing patterns, hinting at its hidden abilities.

Warp Wood.description:
This spell causes wooden weapons to bend and become useless. It affects one arrow for each level of the caster. A spear, javelin, or magical wand counts as two arrows, and a club, bow, or staff counts as four.

The spell does not affect other wooden items. If a magical wooden item is targeted, the wielder may make a saving throw vs. spells to avoid the effect. Items carried but not held get no saving throw. Magical items with "pluses" might not be affected, with a 10% chance per "plus" (for example, an arrow +1 has a 10% chance to be unaffected).
Warp Wood.name: Warp Wood

Water Breathing@BpqXZwoqpKj1q4nx.description: This spell enables the recipient to breathe underwater at any depth for the duration of the spell. It does not affect the recipient's movement underwater nor interfere with breathing air if the recipient emerges from the water.
Water Breathing@BpqXZwoqpKj1q4nx.name: Water Breathing

Water Breathing@k0yDKHOUXeE2pwoZ.description: This spell enables the recipient to breathe underwater at any depth for one full day. It does not affect movement underwater and does not interfere with breathing air.
Water Breathing@k0yDKHOUXeE2pwoZ.name: Water Breathing

Waterskin/Wineskin.description: A flexible container made of leather or a preserved animal bladder, with a capacity of two quarts. When filled, it has an encumbrance of 30 coins; when empty, 5 coins. A normal-sized person drinks about 2qts of water per day.
Waterskin/Wineskin.name: Waterskin/Wineskin
Waterskin/Wineskin.unidentifiedDesc: A flexible container made of leather or a preserved animal bladder, with a capacity of two quarts. When filled, it has an encumbrance of 30 coins; when empty, 5 coins. A normal-sized person drinks about 2qts of water per day.

Weather Control@ASkheAFBTyF3q6vU.description:
This spell allows the magic-user to alter the weather within a 240-yard radius. The spell works only outdoors and affects all creatures in the area, including the caster. The effects last as long as the caster concentrates without moving. If the caster is aboard a moving vessel, the effect moves with it.

Weather Conditions & Effects:

  • Rain: Missile attacks suffer a -2 penalty. After 30 minutes (3 turns), the ground becomes muddy, halving movement speed.
  • Snow: Visibility reduced to 20 feet, and movement is halved. Rivers and streams may freeze. Mud remains after the snow thaws, continuing to halve movement.
  • Fog: Visibility limited to 20 feet. Movement speed is halved. Creatures may become lost and move in the wrong direction.
  • Clear Skies: Cancels bad weather effects (rain, snow, fog), but does not remove secondary effects such as mud.
  • Intense Heat: Movement speed is halved. Any excess water (rain, snow, or magically created water) evaporates.
  • High Winds: Missile attacks and flying are impossible. Movement is halved. At sea, ships sailing with the wind move 50% faster. In desert environments, a sandstorm is created, causing 20' visibility and halving movement.
  • Tornado: A whirlwind is created under the caster's control, acting as a 12 HD air elemental. At sea, treat this effect as a storm or gale.

Concentration Required: The spell ends immediately if the caster stops concentrating.
Weather Control@ASkheAFBTyF3q6vU.name: Weather Control

Weather Control@xXwbkfTsctrqdPdz.description:
This spell grants the druid the power to manipulate the weather within a 240-yard radius.

Effects:

  • The caster may create one specific weather condition that affects all creatures in the area, including the caster.
  • The spell requires concentration, and the caster must remain still.
  • If the caster is moved (e.g., on a ship), the effect moves with them.
  • The spell only functions outdoors.

Weather Effects:

  • Rain: Missile attacks suffer a -2 penalty. After 3 turns, the ground becomes muddy, halving movement speed.
  • Snow: Visibility is reduced to 20', and movement is halved. Rivers and streams may freeze. Mud persists after thawing.
  • Fog: Visibility drops to 20', movement is halved. Creatures within may become lost.
  • Clear: Cancels rain, snow, and fog, but does not remove secondary effects (e.g., mud).
  • Intense Heat: Movement is halved. Excess water sources (rain, snow, puddles) dry up.
  • High Winds: No flying or missile attacks are possible. Movement is halved. Ships sailing with the wind move 50% faster. In deserts, creates a sandstorm (20' visibility, half movement).
  • Tornado: Creates a whirlwind under the druid’s control, acting as a 12 HD air elemental. At sea, it functions as a storm or gale.
Weather Control@xXwbkfTsctrqdPdz.name: Weather Control

Web.description:
This spell conjures a thick, sticky web that fills the affected area. The web traps creatures, restricting movement and blocking passage. Giants or creatures with great strength can break through the web in 2 rounds, while a human of average strength will take [[/r 2d4 #Escape Time in Turns]] turns to break free.

Flames, such as from a torch, will burn away the web in 2 rounds, dealing [[/r 1d6 #Fire Damage]] damage to anyone caught in it. Magical items like gauntlets of ogre power reduce escape time to 4 rounds.
Web.name: Web

Whip (10').description:
This weapon consists of a long, braided leather strap with a handle, ranging in length from 5 to 30 feet. It is a hand-to-hand weapon capable of causing damage (1d2 points) or entangling opponents. Before each combat round, the wielder must declare whether they are attempting to deal damage or entangle. In either case, a normal attack roll is required.

If the attack hits, the whip either deals 1d2 points of damage or, if attempting to entangle, forces the target to make a saving throw vs. death ray, potentially with a bonus. The saving throw bonus and the outcome of the entangling attempt are determined using the Weapon Special Effects Table. On a failed saving throw, the target suffers one of the following effects:

  • Entangle: The victim is unable to attack, cast spells, or move until they succeed on a saving throw.
  • Slow: The victim's movement and attack rates are halved, and they cannot cast spells.
  • Delay: The victim automatically loses initiative in the next round.

This weapon is primarily a tactical tool and is often used by thieves or other characters who prefer to support front-line fighters without directly engaging in melee combat.

A whip can only entangle creatures with a solid form; it has no entangling effect on wraiths, spectres, ethereal creatures, or monsters composed of water (e.g., water elementals). However, these beings still take normal damage from the whip. (Note that a regular whip cannot harm creatures that require magical weapons to hit; such cases require a magical whip.)
Whip (10').name: Whip (10')
Whip (10').unidentifiedDesc:
This weapon consists of a long, braided leather strap with a handle, ranging in length from 5 to 30 feet. It is a hand-to-hand weapon capable of causing damage (1d2 points) or entangling opponents. Before each combat round, the wielder must declare whether they are attempting to deal damage or entangle. In either case, a normal attack roll is required.

If the attack hits, the whip either deals 1d2 points of damage or, if attempting to entangle, forces the target to make a saving throw vs. death ray, potentially with a bonus. The saving throw bonus and the outcome of the entangling attempt are determined using the Weapon Special Effects Table. On a failed saving throw, the target suffers one of the following effects:

  • Entangle: The victim is unable to attack, cast spells, or move until they succeed on a saving throw.
  • Slow: The victim's movement and attack rates are halved, and they cannot cast spells.
  • Delay: The victim automatically loses initiative in the next round.

This weapon is primarily a tactical tool and is often used by thieves or other characters who prefer to support front-line fighters without directly engaging in melee combat.

A whip can only entangle creatures with a solid form; it has no entangling effect on wraiths, spectres, ethereal creatures, or monsters composed of water (e.g., water elementals). However, these beings still take normal damage from the whip. (Note that a regular whip cannot harm creatures that require magical weapons to hit; such cases require a magical whip.)

Whistle.description: A small wooden or metal whistle that can be used to make a loud signal. The distance that the sound can be heard from depends on the environment.
Whistle.name: Whistle
Whistle.unidentifiedDesc: A small wooden or metal whistle that can be used to make a loud signal. The distance that the sound can be heard from depends on the environment.

Wine.description: A quart of common wine. It does not include a container and is often carried in a wineskin. Useful for social occasions or in some cases, as a barter item.
Wine.name: Wine
Wine.unidentifiedDesc: A quart of common wine. It does not include a container and is often carried in a wineskin. Useful for social occasions or in some cases, as a barter item.

Wish.description:
The Wish spell is the most powerful spell a magic-user can cast. It is never found on scrolls but may be placed in rare magical items, such as rings. Only magic-users of 36th level with a Wisdom score of 18 or greater may cast this spell.

Wording the Wish:

The player must clearly state or write the exact wish. The wording is critically important, as the wish will usually follow the literal meaning of the words spoken—regardless of the caster's intentions.

The DM is responsible for maintaining game balance. Poorly worded wishes may have unintended consequences, while selfish or greedy wishes may be deliberately twisted by the DM. If a wish is unreasonable, the DM may simply rule that it has no effect.

Examples of Faulty Wishes:

  • "I wish that I knew everything about this dungeon." - The character gains full knowledge for a moment but then immediately forgets everything.
  • "I wish for a million gold pieces." - The gold pieces may appear, but they might land on the caster (crushing them) and then vanish.
  • "I wish to permanently gain the gaze power of a basilisk while retaining all my abilities." - This could result in the caster growing an additional basilisk head.

Wish Limitations & Effects:

  • A wish cannot be used to gain experience points or levels.
  • A properly worded wish can substitute for any magic-user spell of 8th level or lower or any clerical or druidic spell of 6th level or lower at the DM’s discretion.
  • If the wish is used to harm a creature, the target may make a saving throw vs. spells. If successful, the effect is halved, and the other half rebounds on the caster (who may save with a -4 penalty).
  • If the wish is used to inconvenience rather than harm (such as teleporting a victim into a prison cell), no saving throw is allowed.

Special Uses of a Wish:

  • A wish can create treasure, up to 50,000 gold pieces. However, the caster loses 1 XP per gold piece gained, and this loss cannot be restored.
  • A wish can temporarily change one ability score to a minimum of 3 or maximum of 18, lasting six turns.
  • Permanent ability score increases require casting a number of wishes equal to the desired score (e.g., raising Strength from 15 to 16 requires 16 wishes within one week).
  • Wishes cannot permanently lower ability scores.

Racial & Class Effects:

  • A wish cannot raise a human character beyond 36th level, but it can grant a demihuman one additional Hit Die (maximum HD: Halflings 9, Elves 11, Dwarves 13).
  • A wish can change a demihuman to a human (or vice versa), allowing them to advance as a new class at the same level.
  • If a wish is used to change another character’s class, the target may make a saving throw vs. spells with a +5 bonus to resist.

Altering Past Events:

A wish can alter events from the past 24 hours. However, it cannot fully overturn impossible odds. Examples include:

  • A lost battle may be changed into a less severe defeat.
  • A character’s death could instead become a near-death experience.
  • A permanent loss may be converted into a temporary one.

Important Note:

If an effect is stated to be unchangeable "even with a wish", this limitation overrides the spell’s normal capabilities.

Game Balance & DM Discretion:

The DM must ensure that wishes remain within reason. A wish cannot alter fundamental game mechanics (such as preventing dragons from using their breath weapons). The more unreasonable a wish is, the less likely it is to succeed as intended.
Wish.name: Wish
Wish.spellEffect: Alters reality based on the caster’s wording

Wish (C).description:
Wish is the most powerful spell available to a cleric, capable of altering reality itself. However, its effects are subject to strict interpretation by the DM.

Requirements

  • Only clerics of 36th level with 18+ Wisdom may cast this spell.
  • Wishes are never found on scrolls but may exist in rare items such as rings.

Wording the Wish

The caster must clearly state their wish. The exact wording is crucial, as the spell follows the literal meaning rather than the intent. The DM may interpret the wish strictly, generously, or even maliciously.

  • If a wish is made with greed or malice, the DM should distort its results.
  • The DM may disallow unreasonable wishes, causing the spell to fail.
  • After a misinterpreted wish, the DM should explain the flaw in the phrasing.

Examples of badly phrased wishes:

  • "I wish to know everything about this dungeon." → The character knows all but forgets it in a second.
  • "I wish for a million gold pieces." → The gold lands on the character, crushing them, then disappears.
  • "I wish for permanent basilisk gaze powers." → The caster grows an extra basilisk head.

Allowed Effects

Spell Substitution: A wish can replicate:

  • Any 8th-level or lower magic-user spell
  • Any 6th-level or lower cleric/druid spell
  • This use of a wish is least likely to be distorted.

Harming Others

If a wish directly harms a creature:

  • The victim gets a saving throw vs. spells.
  • If they succeed, half of the effect rebounds onto the caster, who also saves (at -4 penalty).
  • If the wish only inconveniences (e.g., teleporting them into a prison), no saving throw is allowed.

Gaining Treasure

A wish can conjure up to 50,000 gp, but:

  • The caster loses 1 XP per gold piece gained.
  • This XP loss cannot be restored by any means.

Ability Score Changes

  • A wish can temporarily raise an ability score to a maximum of 18 for 6 turns.

  • A wish can permanently raise an ability score by 1 point per number of wishes used:

    • Raising Strength from 15 to 16 requires 16 wishes.
    • Raising it from 16 to 17 requires 17 more wishes.
    • All wishes must be cast within 1 week.
    • Wishes cannot permanently lower ability scores.

Maximum Experience Levels

  • A wish cannot exceed the 36th-level cap for human characters.
  • However, a wish can grant demihumans +1 Hit Die (new max: 9 for halflings, 11 for elves, 13 for dwarves).

Race Changes

A wish can permanently change a character's race:

  • Demihumans become human fighters of the same level.
  • Elves become magic-users or fighters (chosen by the wish caster).
  • Humans become demihumans, but never above their racial level cap.
  • If unwilling, the target gains a +5 bonus to their saving throw vs. spells to resist the change.

Rewriting Past Events

A wish may alter one event from the previous day:

  • Turning a lost battle into a victory (if feasible).
  • Changing a death to a near-death survival.
  • Changing a permanent loss to a temporary one.

The DM may warn players if their wish exceeds the spell's limits.

Important Restrictions

  • Effects labeled as "unchangeable even by a wish" cannot be altered.
  • Wishes cannot alter game mechanics (e.g., "dragons cannot breathe fire anymore").
  • Unreasonable or greedy wishes are less likely to succeed.
Wish (C).name: Wish (C)

Wizard Eye.description:
This spell creates an invisible eye, through which the caster can see. The eye is the size of a normal eye and grants the caster infravision with a range of 60'.

Movement: The wizard eye floats through the air at a speed of up to 120' per turn but cannot pass through solid objects. It cannot move further than 240' from the caster.

Concentration: The caster must concentrate without moving to see through the eye, directing its movement and observing through it for the spell’s duration.
Wizard Eye.name: Wizard Eye

Wizard Lock.description:
This spell functions as a stronger version of the hold portal spell. It can be used on any portal or lock, not just doors, and it remains in effect indefinitely unless dispelled by magic.

A knock spell can bypass the wizard lock temporarily. The caster who placed the lock, as well as any spellcaster or creature with three or more levels (or Hit Dice) greater than the caster, can open the locked portal without removing the spell. Once the portal is closed again, the lock re-engages.
Wizard Lock.name: Wizard Lock

Wizardry.description:
This spell allows the cleric to temporarily wield the magical powers of a magic-user, enabling the use of certain restricted items.

Effects:

  • The cleric may use one magic-user-only item, choosing between:
    • A magic-user device (such as a wand, staff, or rod).
    • A magic-user scroll containing a 1st or 2nd level spell.
  • Spell Level Restriction: The cleric cannot use spells of 3rd level or higher, even if present on the scroll.

Duration:

  • The spell lasts for one turn (10 minutes) or until the cleric uses the item.

Temporary Knowledge:

  • During the spell’s duration, the cleric magically understands how to operate the selected item.
  • For a scroll spell, the cleric is treated as the minimum level required to cast the spell.
Wizardry.name: Wizardry
Wizardry.spellEffect: Allows the use of one magic-user device or scroll spell

Wolfsbane.description: Sold dried or fresh in single sprigs, this herb is used to drive off lycanthropes, who cannot abide its presence. The sprig must be swung or thrown as a weapon to be effective.
Wolfsbane.name: Wolfsbane
Wolfsbane.unidentifiedDesc: Sold dried or fresh in single sprigs, this herb is used to drive off lycanthropes, who cannot abide its presence. The sprig must be swung or thrown as a weapon to be effective.

Woodform.description:
This spell creates a mass of wood, up to 1,000 cubic feet in volume, which may be arranged in any shape the caster desires (e.g., 10' x 10' x 10' block, 25' x 20' x 2' wall).

Casting Time: Varies by design complexity. Simple shapes, like a wall, take 1 round. A staircase may take 10 rounds (1 turn), while more complex designs, like a ship keel, can take up to 12 turns (2 hours). The DM decides casting time for complex designs.

Object Properties: The wood must be created as a single piece with no moving parts. Once created, the wood is permanent, non-dispellable, and cannot be modified by further woodform spells unless cast by the original caster within two hours to make refinements. The caster may create wood with rough edges, which another woodform can later seamlessly join to the first.

The wood must rest on solid ground or a similar support, and cannot occupy a space already containing an object. The type of wood can be chosen by the caster but may be limited by the DM, especially for exotic or magical woods.

Durability: The wood lasts until destroyed by damage (e.g., burning, breaking) or spells like *Disintegrate*. It has an AC of -4 (6) and 60 hit points per 1' thickness, based on the Fortifications Table (page 137). Most exterior wooden walls are 8" thick, giving them 40 hit points.
Woodform.name: Woodform

Word of Recall.description:
This spell instantly teleports the cleric and all equipment they are carrying to their designated sanctuary, regardless of distance.

Sanctuary Requirement: The cleric must have a permanent home (such as a castle) that includes a meditation room. This room serves as the spell’s destination.

Initiative Advantage: During the round this spell is cast, the cleric automatically gains initiative unless surprised.

Restrictions:

  • The spell affects only the cleric and their carried equipment.
  • Other creatures cannot be transported.
Word of Recall.name: Word of Recall

Wrestling@y87CgAv0iENRhZ4E.description:
The Wrestling skill enables a character to grapple, pin, or otherwise subdue opponents using hand-to-hand combat techniques. A successful skill roll improves the character's Wrestling Rating (WR), providing a +1 bonus per skill level.

In wrestling combat, a character with Wrestling skill gains a bonus on their Wrestling Rating for initiating or resisting grapples and pins. The higher the skill level, the more effective the character becomes, providing a cumulative +1 to WR per level (e.g., Wrestling +1 skill gives +2 WR).

This skill is especially useful in situations where the character needs to subdue an opponent without lethal force, or in confined spaces where weapons are impractical. Mastery in Wrestling also allows for improved control over an opponent’s movements, reducing their ability to counterattack or escape.
Wrestling@y87CgAv0iENRhZ4E.name: Wrestling
